questions.text: Which of the following structures does not arise from the proliferating trophoblasts?
questions.solution:
Option D: Intra-embryonic mesoderm

  • The blastocyst is partially embedded in the endometrial stroma by the eighth day of development.
  • The cells of the outer layer of a blastocyst are called trophoblast cells.
  • Trophoblast cells are the first cells to differentiate from a fertilized egg.
  • In the second week of development, trophoblast cells differentiate into two different layers:
  • Cytotrophoblasts (inner mononucleated cell layer)
  • Syncytiotrophoblasts (outer multinucleated zone without distinct cell boundaries)
  • The inner cell layer of the blastocyst develops into epiblast and hypoblast.
  • Intra-embryonic mesoderm is developed from the epiblast cell layer.
  • Primary villi are formed by the cytotrophoblast cells when they form cellular columns penetrating and surrounded by the syncytium.

Option A: Cytotrophoblast

  • The cytotrophoblast cell layer is one of the layers formed by the trophoblast cells.
  • Cytotrophoblast cells anchor the growing fetus to uterine tissue and are also involved in producing various hormones.

Option B: Syncytiotrophoblast

  • The syncytiotrophoblast cell layer is one of the layers formed by trophoblast cells.
  • Trophoblast cells facilitate the implantation of blastocyst by producing lytic enzymes.
  • It also produces the human chorionic gonadotropin hormone.

Option C: Primary villi

  • The proliferation of trophoblast cells forms cytotrophoblast cells.
  • Cytotrophoblast cells form the primary villi.

questions.text: Which tongue muscle is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Option A: Palatoglossus

  • Palatoglossus is the only tongue muscle supplied by the vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies all other tongue muscles.

Option B: Genioglossus

  • It is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

Option C: Hyoglossus

  • It is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

Option D: Styloglossus

  • It is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presenting with multiple falls and episodes of dizziness over the past 6 weeks, examination reveals a wide-based gait, impaired rapid alternating movements of the hands, and a coarse tremor when grabbing a pen. Muscle power and sensation are normal. What is the blood supply of the structure involved in the patient's pathology?


	Vertebral artery
	Basilar artery
	Middle cerebral artery
	Posterior cerebral artery
questions.solution:
Options A: Only 1 and 2 are correct

  • This is a case of cerebellar degeneration in which the patient presents with gait and tremors.
  • The structure involved in a patient's pathology is the cerebellum.
  • The cerebellum arises from the rhombencephalon. Specifically, we can say that it arises from the alar plates or rhombic lips (dorsal thickening of the neural tube that forms the sensory areas of the nervous system) of the metencephalon (spans between the pontine flexure and the rhomencephalic isthmus).
  • It is an oval structure situated in the posterior cranial fossa, inferior to the tentorium cerebelli. It has an outer grey matter cortex and white matter internally.
  • The cerebellum is supplied by
    • Superior cerebellar artery: Basilar artery branch
    • Anterior inferior cerebellar: Basilar artery branch
    • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery: Vertebral artery branch

Options B: Only 2 and 3 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 3 is incorrect.
  • The middle cerebral artery does not supply the cerebellum
  • The lateral surface of the cerebrum receives supply from the middle cerebral artery.

Options C: Only 1 and 3 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 3 is incorrect.
  • The middle cerebral artery does not supply the cerebellum.
  • The lateral surface of the cerebrum receives supply from the middle cerebral artery.

Option D: Only 2 and 4 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 4 is incorrect.
  • The posterior cerebral artery does not supply the cerebellum.
  • It supplies the midbrain and the thalamus

questions.text: Among the three cranial nerves shown below, which has the correct pairing?

choices.text: A – Lingual nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – Glossopharyngeal nerve
A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – lingual nerve
A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Lingual nerve C – Hypoglossal nerve
A - Hypoglossal nerve B – lingual nerve C – glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Option C:  A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Lingual nerve C – Hypoglossal nerve

It is the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

  • The lingual nerve is a branch of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. It carries a general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve fibers arise at the level of the medulla oblongata. Its rootlets join to form a nerve that enters the jugular foramen's middle part. It curves medially across the stylopharyngeus muscle during its extracranial course, enters the pharynx through an interval between superior and middle constrictor muscle, and ends by dividing into terminal branches.
  • The nucleus of the hypoglossal nerve is situated in the medulla. Its rootlets are attached in the groove between the pyramid and the olive. It enters the neck through the anterior condylar canal, descends between the internal jugular vein and internal carotid artery, and passes above the hyoid bone in the submandibular region, where it terminates into muscular branches.

Option A: A – Lingual nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – Glossopharyngeal nerve

  • It is not the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

Option B: A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – lingual nerve

  • It is not the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

Option D: A - Hypoglossal nerve B – lingual nerve C – glossopharyngeal nerve

  • It is not the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure corresponding to the caudate nucleus in a 6-year-old child diagnosed with juvenile Huntington's disease, presenting with involuntary movements, seizures, tremors, decreased school performance, and behavioral problems.
questions.solution:
Option B: B

  • The structure marked is the caudate nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a paired, “C”- shaped subcortical structure that lies deep inside the brain near the thalamus.

 

  • Caudate plays a crucial role in various higher neurological actions. Each caudate nucleus is composed of a large anterior head, a body, and a thin tail.
  • Caudate, together with the putamen, is called the striatum. The striatum is the main input source for the basal ganglia.
  • Basal ganglia also include the globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus, and substantia nigra. These structures primarily control voluntary skeletal movement.
  • The caudate nucleus functions in planning the execution of movement, learning, memory, reward, motivation, emotion, and romantic interactions.
  • The dysfunction of the caudate nucleus occurs in various pathologies, including Huntington's and Parkinson's disease, obsessive-compulsive disorder, some forms of dementia, ADHD, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia. In Huntington's disease, there is a huge loss of neurons in the head of the caudate resulting in hydrocephalus ex vacuo.

 

Option A: A

  • The structure marked is the Cingulate gyrus.

Option C: C

  • The structure marked is subthalamic nuclei.

Option D: D

  • The structure marked is the internal capsule.

questions.text: The Uvula vesicae seen in the bladder are formed from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Option A: Median lobe of the prostate

  • The urinary bladder is a part of the urinary system and lies in the pelvis. It is responsible for urine storage and urine expulsion.
  • The urine enters the bladder through the ureters and leaves through the urethra. These openings can be seen in the bladder as internal orifices. All three orifices collectively form the trigone of the bladder.
  • At the apex of trigonum vesicae, there lies the internal urethral orifice. There is a mucus membrane immediately behind the internal urethral orifice. This mucus membrane presents a small elevation known as uvula vesicae
  • So, uvula vesicae is a small elevation situated immediately behind the urethral orifice, which is produced by the underlying median lobe of the prostate.
  • It enlarges with age due to enlargement of the underlying median lobe of the prostate and may inhibit complete bladder emptying resulting in low urine output, the sensation of bladder fulness, and burning micturition.

Option B: Lateral lobe of the prostate

  • The lateral lobe of the prostate does not produce an elevation in the bladder.
  • Uvula vesicae are not formed from the lateral lobe of the prostate.

Option C: Anterior lobe of the prostate

  • The Anterior lobe of the prostate does not produce an elevation in the bladder.
  • Uvula vesicae are not formed from the anterior lobe of the prostate.

Option D: Posterior lobe of the prostate

  • The Posterior lobe of the prostate does not produce an elevation in the bladder.
  • Uvula vesicae are not formed from the posterior lobe of the prostate.

questions.text: Which type of epithelium lines the urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Transitional epithelium

 

  • The slide shows as a multi-layered epithelial tissue in which the cells are all have a fairly round shape. This is the appearance of transitional epithelium (e.g., urinary bladder) when the organ it lines is not distended (stretched out).
  • The superficial/surface lining cells in the diagram are large & globular (umbrella-shaped) towards the lumen. There may be few multinucleated cells at surface layer.
  • The urinary bladder contains transitional epithelium, also called the urothelium. Superficial cells in the transitional epithelium are multinucleated & globular (umbrella-shaped) towards the lumen. It is multilayered & has multiple nuclei. Usually, 3-4 layers of cells are present. The lowermost or basal layer lines the basement membrane, and the uppermost layer faces the lumen of the urinary bladder.
  • The transitional epithelium changes its shape in response to stretch. When the urinary bladder is distended, the top layer of the epithelium becomes flattened like squamous epithelium. In contrast, when the bladder is relaxed, the cells appear cuboidal.
  • Besides the urinary bladder, Transitional epithelium is also present in the ureter, urethra, and ducts of the prostate gland.
  • The transitional epithelium cells form an effective permeability barrier that prevents water or solute transmission across the membrane. 

Option B: Simple columnar epithelium

  • The simple columnar epithelium is long epithelium cells with nuclei at their basal ends.
  • These cells are present in the organs where active absorption and secretion are needed, such as the gallbladder. The simple columnar epithelium lining the common bile duct is responsible for the active transport of water which helps concentrate the bile.

Option D: Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

  • This type of epithelium is present in places where protection is needed. It contains several layers of squamous cells called keratinocytes. The Epidermis of the skin is made up of this type of epithelium.
  • Skin: Multilayered but superficial cells are flat & have flat nuclei, which are keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Pseudo-stratified ciliated columnar epithelium

  • This option is false as it says Pseudo-stratified ciliated columnar epithelium is not present in the urinary bladder.
  • The respiratory epithelium consists of Pseudo-stratified ciliated columnar cells(a single layer of cells that appear stratified).

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the contents of the medial thigh?

choices.text: Adductor magnus, longus and brevis insert onto the linea aspera.
The obturator nerve innervates all the muscles of the medial compartment.
All the muscles of the medial compartment take origin from the ischium.
The obturator nerve is split into anterior and posterior divisions by the adductor longus.

questions.solution:
Option A: Adductor magnus, longus and brevis insert onto the linea aspera

  • The medial compartment of the thigh is a facial compartment that contains the hip adductors, obturator externus, pectineus and the gracilis muscle.
  • The adductor muscles include the adductor longus, brevis and magnus.
  • The adductor magnus is the largest and strongest muscle in the medial compartment of the thigh. It is a composite muscle consisting of two parts; the adductor and hamstring parts also called the ischiocondylar.
  • The adductor muscles originate from the pubic bone and insert into the linea aspera. The hamstring portion of the adductor magnus inserts on the adductor tubercle above the medial femoral epicondyle.
  • The pectineus muscle originates from pubis and insert on pectineal line.
  • Gracilis originates from the inferior pubic ramus and inserts on the pes anserinus on the tibia.
  • Obturator externus originate from lateral surface of obturator membrane and the ischiopubic ramus and inserts onto trochanteric fossa.
  • The nerve supply of the compartment is by the obturator nerve (L2-L4). However, the pectineus muscle is supplied by the femoral nerve.
  • The obturator artery supplies blood to the medial compartment of the thigh.

Option B: The obturator nerve innervates all the muscles of the medial compartment.

  • The obturator nerve (L2–L4) supplies the adductor (longus, brevis, and magnus); gracilis; and external obturator muscles.
  • This nerve controls the adduction and rotation of the thigh.
  • The pectineus is a muscle of the medial compartment but is innervated by the femoral nerve. Its action is flexion and adduction of the thigh at the hip.

Option C: All the muscles of the medial compartment take origin from the ischium.

  • All muscles of the medial compartment take origin from the pubic bone.

Option D: The obturator nerve is split into anterior and posterior divisions by the adductor longus.

  • The obturator nerve is split into anterior and posterior divisions by the adductor brevis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the 1st bone to start ossification.
questions.solution:
Option B: Clavicle

  • This is a case of clavicle fracture.
  • The clavicle is also known as the collar bone.
  • The clavicle is located between the sternum and the scapula and lies horizontally across the root of the neck.
  • The clavicle forms a light strut that connects the upper limb to the thorax and allows the limb to move freely from the trunk.
  • The clavicle is subcutaneous and easily palpable along its entire length.
  • It is roughly S-shaped and resembles a large, old-style key.
  • Clavicle develops by membranocartilaginous ossification.
  • The whole of it ossifies in the membrane except its medial end, which ossifies in the cartilage (endochondral ossification).
  • The clavicle is the 1st bone to start ossification.
  • It ossifies by four ossification centers: 2 primary centers for the shaft and 2 secondary centers, one for each end.

Option A: Femur

  • It is an incorrect option because the clavicle bone is fractured in this case.
  • So, according to this case, it is an incorrect statement.

Option C: Mandible

  • It is an incorrect option because the clavicle bone is fractured in this case.
  • So, according to this case, it is an incorrect statement.

Option D: Nasal bone

  • It is an incorrect option because the clavicle bone is fractured in this case.
  • So, according to this case, it is an incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his brother after a fall on his elbow on an outstretched hand. After radiological findings, the X-rays show the fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, but there is no dislocation of an elbow. A patient is trying to make a fist but can only partially flex the Index and Middle finger. Which of the following nerves is likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Anterior interosseous nerve: The anterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the median nerve, and it innervates specific muscles in the forearm, including the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index and middle fingers. Damage to the anterior interosseous nerve, which can occur with a medial epicondyle fracture, can result in the described inability to fully flex the index and middle fingers.

So, the correct option is D. Anterior interosseous nerve based on the specific symptoms described in the scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Median nerve: The median nerve does innervate the flexor muscles of the forearm, including those involved in finger flexion. However, in the context of a medial epicondyle fracture, damage to the median nerve would typically result in a more widespread motor and sensory deficit in the hand and forearm. The specific presentation described (inability to fully flex the index and middle fingers) is more indicative of anterior interosseous nerve involvement.

Option B: The Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN) is a branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. It primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm, including those responsible for extending the wrist and fingers. Damage to the PIN can result in weakness or paralysis of these extensor muscles, leading to difficulty with wrist and finger extension.

Option C: Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. Damage to the radial nerve would typically lead to difficulty with wrist and finger extension, not finger flexion.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding deep cervical fascia is correct?

choices.text: Axillary sheath is derived from B
Parotid sheath is derived from C

questions.solution:
Option C: C represents Pretracheal fascia

  • C in the diagram represents the pretracheal fascia.
  • Pretracheal fascia extends from the hyoid bone to the pericardium of the heart.
  • Posteriorly, it blends with buccopharyngeal fascia and laterally with carotid sheaths.
  • It supports the infrahyoid muscles, thyroid gland, trachea, and esophagus.

Option A: Axillary sheath is derived from B

  • The axillary sheath is derived from the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia and marked as A in the diagram.

Option B: Parotid sheath is derived from C

  • The parotid sheath is derived from investing layer of deep cervical fascia and is marked as B in the diagram, not C as the option says.

Option D: C covers the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid

  • Pretracheal fascia is labeled as C in the diagram. It does not cover trapezius and sternocleidomastoid.
  • Both these muscles are covered by investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

questions.text: A patient presents to you in your viva examination with obstructive jaundice. Her eyes are yellow, and she is also pale looking. Examiner asks you to tell which of the following statement about the hepatobiliary system, essential in the proper digestion of fats, is correct?

choices.text: The pancreatic duct drains into the hepatic duct.
The common hepatic duct is formed by the union of the common bile and cystic ducts.
Callot's triangle is formed by the hepatic duct, cystic duct, and cystic artery.
The common bile duct runs behind the first part of the duodenum.

questions.solution:
Option D: The common bile duct runs behind the first part of the duodenum

  • The common bile duct may be described in three portions
  • The first part lies in the free edge of the lesser omentum.
  • The second part lies behind the first part of the duodenum.
  • It has three portions supraduodenal, retroduodenal and intramural.

Option A: The pancreatic duct drains into the hepatic duct

  • The pancreatic duct drains into the duodenum via a common opening with the common bile duct.
  • The main pancreatic duct joins the common bile duct at the greater papilla in the second part of the duodenum.

Option B: The common hepatic duct is formed by the union of the common bile and cystic ducts

  • The common hepatic duct is formed by the right and left hepatic duct union.
  • The common bile duct is formed by the union of the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct.

Option C: Calot’s triangle is formed by the hepatic duct, cystic duct, and the cystic artery

  • Calot’s triangle is formed by the common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and the liver's edge.
  • The cystic artery usually runs through this triangle. Another name for Calot's triangle is the hepatobiliary triangle.

questions.text: A researcher is studying adrenal insufficiency, assuming a relationship between extracellular volume and plasma sodium concentration. Which of the following options is physiologically correct in accordance with adrenal insufficiency?

choices.text: Extracellular fluid volume increases and Plasma sodium concentration is decreased
Extracellular fluid volume decreases and Plasma sodium concentration is increased
Extracellular fluid volume increases and Plasma sodium concentration is increased
Extracellular fluid volume decreases and Plasma sodium concentration is decreased

questions.solution:
Option D: Extracellular fluid volume decreases and Plasma sodium concentration is decreased

  • Addison's disease, which results from decreased secretion of the aldosterone, impairs the ability of the kidneys to reabsorb sodium and can cause a modest degree of hyponatremia.
  • Extracellular volume decreases in adrenal insufficiency because of hyponatremic volume contraction.
  • Aldosterone functions to reabsorb sodium, which results in water diffusion in response to the osmotic gradient established by sodium.
  • Decreased aldosterone results in hyponatremia and eventually decreased extracellular fluid volume.
  • Therefore, adrenal insufficiency results in a decrease in both extracellular fluid and plasma sodium.

Option A: Extracellular fluid volume increases and Plasma sodium concentration is decreased

  •  In adrenal insufficiency, extracellular fluid volume and plasma sodium concentration is decreased.

Option B: Extracellular fluid volume decreases and Plasma sodium concentration is increased

  • In adrenal insufficiency, both extracellular fluid volume and plasma sodium concentration is decreased.

Option C: Extracellular fluid volume increases and Plasma sodium concentration is increased

  • In adrenal insufficiency, both extracellular fluid volume and plasma sodium concentration is decreased.

questions.text: The rate of movement of molecules across the membranes changes by concentrations of molecules in both intracellular and extracellular fluids. The following graphs are plotted using the results of a study. Which among the following best relates to the kinetics of Trace B?

choices.text: Transport of Ca++ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum of a smooth muscle cell
Transport of K+ into a muscle cell
Transport of Na+ out of a nerve cell
Transport of O2 across an artificial lipid bilayer

questions.solution:
Option D: Transport of O2 across an artificial lipid bilayer

  • Trace B indicates a process not limited by an intrinsic Vmax.
  • Trace B shows an increase in the rate of movement with an increase in the concentration of oxygen concentration.
  • Trace B does not attain a plateau.
  • Excludes facilitated diffusion and active transport.
  • With the increase in the concentration gradient of oxygen molecules across the artificial lipid bilayer, the rate of movement of oxygen molecules is also increased.
  • The transport of oxygen across an artificial lipid bilayer is not dependent upon the carrier molecules.
  • Oxygen transport across the membranes does not require energy.

Option A: Transport of Ca++ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum of a smooth muscle cell

  • Calcium ions are transported into the sarcoplasmic reticulum of a smooth muscle cell via active transport.
  • In active transport, the movement is limited by the availability of transport carrier molecules and energy sources.
  • In the active transport mechanism, the curve reaches a plateau after the saturation of carrier molecules.
  • Excludes facilitated diffusion and active transport.

Option B: Transport of K+ into a muscle cell

  • The transport of potassium ions into a muscle cell is mediated by facilitated diffusion.
  • Facilitated diffusion is dependent on the number of carrier molecules available.
  • As facilitated diffusion depends on carrier molecules, facilitated diffusion attains a plateau upon saturation of available carrier molecules.
  • Excludes facilitated diffusion and active transport.

Option C: Transport of Na+ out of a nerve cell

  • Active transport is used to transport sodium ions out of a nerve cell.
  • In active transport, the movement is limited by the availability of transport carrier molecules and energy sources.
  • In the active transport mechanism, the curve reaches a plateau after the saturation of carrier molecules.
  • Excludes facilitated diffusion and active transport.

  • Effect of concentration of a substance on rate of diffusion through a membrane by simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion. This shows that facilitated diffusion approaches a maximum rate called the Vmax

questions.text: The following is a diagrammatic representation of an action potential inside the neuron. Membrane voltage is plotted on the y-axis, and time is plotted against the x-axis. Point E denotes the threshold potential on the y-axis. Between points A and B, which of the following is primarily responsible for the change in membrane potential?

choices.text: Movement of K+ into the cell
Movement of K+ out of the cell
Movement of Na+ into the cell

questions.solution:
Option D: Movement of Na⁺ into the cell.

 

  • The diagram in the question stem represents the changes occurring during an action potential.
  • Point A represents the resting membrane potential that is around -70 mV. Resting membrane potential is maintained by the action of Na-K ATPase and the leaky potassium channels.
  • A stimulus that increases the membrane potential from the resting membrane potential to the threshold potential (point E) will lead to the initiation of nerve impulses.
  • On reaching the threshold potential, the voltage-gated sodium channels open and lead to the rapid depolarization of the membrane due to the influx of sodium ions. This is represented by point B in the diagram.
  • The voltage-gated sodium channels close after a short time, and the potassium channels open, leading to the efflux of potassium ions from the cell. This is called repolarization of the membrane and is represented by point C in the diagram.
  • The potassium ions remain open for a relatively long time, leading to continuous efflux of potassium ions. The membrane potential becomes more negative than the resting membrane potential, known as hyper-polarization, denoted by point D on the graph.
  • Eventually, the closure of voltage-gated potassium channels returns the membrane potential to the resting membrane potential (point A).

Option A: Inhibition of the Na+, K+-ATPase.

  • The Na-K pump maintains the resting membrane potential. It also prevents the development of cellular edema by moving more ions outside than inside the cell. As the water follows the solute, a net loss of ions inside the cell prevents the accumulation of water inside the cell. Inhibition of this pump leads to cellular edema and cell death

Option B: Movement of K+ into the cell.

  • The action of the Na-K pump does it. Potassium ions move against their concentration gradient by this pump that uses energy in the form of ATP

Option C: Movement of K+ out of the cell.

  • It occurs during the cell's repolarization (point C) and hyper-polarization (point D).

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about gastric secretion?

choices.text: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion
Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin
Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid
Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

questions.solution:
Option C: Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid

  • Trefoil peptides (TTF) are 40 amino acids peptides related to mucin-associated secretory molecules mediating many physiological roles that maintain and restore gastrointestinal mucosal homeostasis.
  • The surface cells of gastric mucosa secrete primarily mucus and bicarbonate.
  • This protects the stomach from digesting itself, as well as substances, are known as trefoil peptides that stabilize the mucus bicarbonate layer.
  • TTF is constitutively expressed in the gastrointestinal tract and is involved in defense and repair by promoting epithelial restitution.
  • Damage to these proteins causes erosions and even ulcers in the stomach.

Option A: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion

  • The gastric phase accounts for 60% of gastric secretion.

Option B: Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin

  • Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete Histamine.

Option D: Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

  • Gastric secretion 1.5-2.5 L/day

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with diffuse pain in the abdomen and loose stools during the day. He was in his usual state of health 1 day before. The abdominal pain is followed by nausea but not vomiting. On examination, he looks lethargic. Temperature is 98°F, pulse rate is 90 beats per minute, blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 21 per minute. Laboratory values show:

                                    PH = 7.3

                                    Biccarbonate = 15mEq/L

                                    Sodium = 132 mEq/L

                                    Potassium = 3.5 mEq/L

                                    Chloride = 110 mEq/L

 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient??
questions.solution:
Option A: Diarrhoea

  • This patient presents with loose stools, low pH, low bicarbonate, and normal anion gap (132 - {110 + 15}) and is most likely diagnosed with diarrhea because all three other options present with high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Law of electroneutrality = Number of cations & anions should be equal in ICF and ECF.
  • In ECF, Na+ is main cation, Cl- & HCO3- are main anions.
  • We do not measure all cations & anions; it is measured as
  • [Na+] + [K+] + [unmeasured cations] = [Cl-] + [HCO3-] + [unmeasured anions]
  • we can measure all cations, but we cannot measure all anions. So, there is a gap created b/w these two sides.
  • This is called the Anion gap.
  • The anion gap is calculated as

         [Na+] -{[Cl-] + [HCO3-]} = 132 – [ (110) + (15)]

                                               = 7meq/lit

Thus, the normal anion gap is 12± 4 meq/lit

  • In acidosis conditions, HCO3- decreases & thus, the anion gap increases, except in acidosis conditions where the anion of the acid is Cl- where the anion gap will remain normal.
  • In GI fluid loss, the anion gap remains normal

Option B: Renal failure

  • Chronic kidney disease has a very low ability to filter blood toxic compounds like urea, so this condition commonly presents with uremic acidosis.
  • Uremic acidosis presents with high anion gap acidosis (not normal anion gap).

Option C: Lactic acidosis

  • Any condition, which causes an increased production of lactic acid in the body, can cause lactic acidosis.
  • Examples: alcoholism and septic shock.

Option D: Diabetic keto-acidosis

  • This condition is more common in Type 1 Diabetes mellitus due to the complete absence of insulin.
  • Type 2 Diabetes mellitus presents with hyperosmolar nonketotic acidosis.
  • DKA presents with severe dehydration, increased frequency of urination, abdominal pain, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is correctly represented by the graph below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Growth hormone.

  • Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile pattern, with an increase followed by a decreasing pattern.
  • Growth hormone is found at relatively low levels during the day unless specific triggers for its release are present.
  • The secretion of growth hormone is markedly increased during the early period of sleep but is reduced during the later stages. During sleep, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur. Growth hormone characteristically increases during the first 2 hours of deep sleep.
  • The precise mechanism is not understood, but several factors control the stimulation of secretion:
    • Starvation (protein deficiency more important trigger in chronic condition)
    • Hypoglycemia (most potent acute stimulator)
    • Low fatty acids in the blood
    • Exercise
    • Excitement
    • Trauma
    • Ghrelin
  • Also, GnRH has pulsatile secretion (secreted intermittently for a few minutes at a time, once every 1 to 3 hours). Continuous infusion of GnRH downregulates the GnRH receptor, resulting in decreased FSH and LH secretion.

 

  • LH secretion is favored at high frequency (1 GnRH pulse per hour), while FSH secretion is favored at low frequency.

Option A: Insulin

  • Insulin secretion follows the meals and occurs rapidly to form the peak, followed by a decline in plasma levels.
  • When insulin is secreted into the blood, it circulates almost entirely in an unbound form; it has a plasma half-life of only about 6 minutes, so it is mainly cleared from circulation within 10 to 15 minutes.
  • Except for that portion of the insulin that combines with receptors in the target cells, the remainder is degraded by the enzyme insulinase, mainly in the liver, to a lesser extent in the kidneys and muscles.

Option B: Cortisol

  • Cortisol secretion occurs due to stimulation by the ACTH.
  • The secretory rates of Corticotrophin releasing hormones, ACTH and cortisol, are high in the early morning but low in the late evening, as shown in the figure above.
  • The plasma cortisol level ranges between a high of about 20 μg/dl an hour before arising in the morning and a low of about 5 μg/dl around midnight. This effect results from the 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus that causes cortisol secretion.

Option D: Thyroid

  • TSH and TRH control thyroid hormone secretion. As shown in the curve, thyroid hormone secretion follows the release of TSH, which is low during the day and increases at night.
  • Thyroid hormone secretion is not represented by a pulsatile pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in sound transduction by the Organ of Corti?
questions.solution:
• The organ of Corti consists of hair cells, the receptors for transduction.
  • Hair cells are surrounded by endolymph.
  • Endolymph has a rich concentration of K+.
  • Basilar fiber vibration, caused by pressure in the sound wave, leads to shearing between the tectorial membrane and the reticular lamina. It causes bending of stereocilia (at the top of hair cells), resulting in the opening of the K+ channels at the base of the hair cells.
  • The hair cells are depolarized by the influx of K+.
  • It leads to the release of the transmitter by the hair cell at its base where it synapses with the VIII nerve fiber.
  • Impulses are then sent to the VIIIth nerve.

questions.text: All the following clotting factors are derived from the Liver, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: III

  • Factor 3 is derived from Damaged tissue and activated platelets, NOT from the Liver.

Option B: V

  • The clotting factors that are produced by the liver are I, II, V, VII, IX, and X.

Option C: VII

  • The clotting factors that are produced by the liver are I, II, V, VII, IX, and X.

Option D: IX

  • The clotting factors that are produced by the liver are I, II, V, VII, IX, and X.

Learning Objective:

  • Factor 3 is derived from Damaged tissue and activated platelets, NOT from the Liver.
Factors Name Sources
I Fibrinogen Liver
II Prothrombin Liver
III Thromboplasm Damaged tissues & activated platelets
IV Calcium ions Diet, bones and platelets
V Labile factor Liver & Platelets
VII Stable factor Liver

questions.text: A neuroscientist in his research studies the brains of humans during different periods and in certain psychiatric conditions. He observes that a child's brain can learn and recover from injury faster than an adult brain. Moreover, the neuronal circuits of humans keep evolving with changes in learning, behavior, memory, and psychiatric disorders. These circuits are maintained by way of neuronal connections that are both chemical and electrical. Which of the following characteristic of a synapse likely explains these modifications in the brain and is not an advantage of an electrical impulse over a chemical impulse?
questions.solution:
Option C: Plasticity

  • Plasticity is the ability of the brain to change and adapt to new information. It is the capacity to modify neurocircuits and change subsequent thoughts, feelings, and behavior.
  • Synaptic plasticity is a change that occurs at synapses and controls how effectively two neurons communicate with each other. It specifically Referenceers to the activity-dependent modification of the strength or efficacy of synaptic transmission at pre-existing synapses.
  • They play a central role in the capacity of the brain to incorporate transient experiences into persistent memory traces.
  • It may either decrease the efficacy of the synapse, called depression, or increase the efficacy, called potentiation. Synaptic plasticity can be either long-term or short-term.
  • The transmission of information in the central nervous system is mainly through nerve action potentials called nerve impulses. There are two major synapses: the chemical synapse and the electrical synapse.
  • In chemical synapses, the neuron secretes a chemical substance called a neurotransmitter at its nerve ending. This transmitter acts on receptor proteins of the next neuron to excite the neuron and inhibit or modify its sensitivity.
  • Electrical synapses are distinguished by open fluid channels that conduct electricity directly from one cell to the next. Most of these synapses consist of small protein tubular structures called gap junctions that allow the movement of ions freely from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next.

Option A: Narrow time domain

  • The events at the electrical synapses occur in a narrow timeframe. The conduction is faster because the gap junctions enable immediate ion passage.
  • It is a cell association between two nerve cells where ions are used to transmit nerve impulses rapidly.
  • They are smaller, and the information is transmitted at a high rate.

Option B: Bidirectionality

  • Chemical synapses have a characteristic that makes them quite desirable for transmitting most nervous system signals.
  • The transmission of signals is always in one direction, from the presynaptic neuron to the postsynaptic neuron.
  • In contrast, conduction through electrical synapses often transmits signals in either or both directions.

Option D: No latency

  • Latency is the delay in the transmission of nerve impulses along a synapse.
  • In electrical synapses, there is no latency or synaptic delay. The conduction is faster. The gap junctions enable immediate ion passage compared to chemical synapses, where information is transmitted slowly.

questions.text: Inhibition of pain signals by tactile stimulation of the skin is mediated by which type of afferent neurons from mechanoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aβ

  • Stimulation of Aβ fibers from peripheral tactile receptors can decrease transmission of pain signals by lateral inhibition. This is known as Gate control mechanism of pain.

Option A: Aα

  • Aα neurons project to skeletal muscles, causing them to contract.

Option C: Aδ

  • Aδ fibers and type C fibers conduct pain signals to the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

Option D: Type C

  • The C fibers conduct pain signals to the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

Learning Objective

Gate Control Theory

  • Psychologist Ronald Melzack and the anatomist Patrick Wall proposed the gate control theory for pain in 1965 to explain the pain suppression. According to them, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by a gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.
  • Significance of Gate Control: Gating of pain at the spinal level is similar to presynaptic inhibition. It forms the basis for relief of pain through rubbing, massage techniques, application of ice packs, acupuncture, and electrical analgesia. All these techniques relieve pain by stimulating the release of endogenous pain relievers (opioid peptides), which close the gate and block the pain signals.
  • Stimulation of Aβ fibers from peripheral tactile receptors can decrease transmission of pain signals by lateral inhibition- This is known as the Gate control mechanism of pain.

  • This process is mediated by inhibitory interneurons in the dorsal column of the spinal cord.
  • Aα neurons project to skeletal muscles, causing them to contract.
  • Aδ fibers and type C fibers conduct pain signals to the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic for a wellness checkup. He has a medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypertriglyceridemia and obstructive sleep apnea. Along with continuing his medications, the physician advises him to lose weight by exercising daily for 30 minutes. During exercise, oxygen delivery to the muscles increases because all except?

choices.text: Oxygen dissociation curve shifts to left
Increased extraction of oxygen from the blood

questions.solution:
Option A: Oxygen dissociation curve shifts to the left:

  • The heart and the lungs are the two most important organs that come into action during exercise.
  • Exercise increases oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production due to an increase in gas exchange.
  • Pulmonary ventilation increases in direct proportion to the metabolic needs of exercise via two mechanisms:
    • An increase in tidal volume (quantity of air inhaled and exhaled each minute).
    • Increase in respiratory rate per minute.
  • Cardiac changes increase heart rate and stroke volume, which leads to an increase in cardiac output. It increases blood flow to the muscles, which also increases due to increased sympathetic activity.
  • As the intensity of exercise increases, oxygen consumption (Vo2) increases until it reaches a maximum point where oxygen consumption will not increase any further. This point is known as Vo2 max.
  • In the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve, exercise causes a right shift due to increased body temperature, carbon dioxide and decreased pH due to a rise in lactic acid production.
  • Exercise causes 2, 3 BPG to increase in 60 minutes, although that increase may not occur in trained athletes.
  • P50 (haemoglobin at 50% saturation) also rises during exercise as the temperature in the active tissue increases, and CO2 and metabolites accumulate, causing the pH to drop.
  • At low PO2 levels, the dissociation curve of haemoglobin from oxygen is steep and large amounts of O2 are released per unit of PO2.

Option B: Increased stroke volume

  • Stroke volume increases due to increased contractility of the heart so that more oxygen is delivered to the muscles.

Option C: Increased extraction of oxygen from the blood

  • There is an increase in oxygen extraction from the blood to meet the metabolic needs of the muscle tissue.

Option D: Increased blood flow to muscles

  • During exercise, sympathetic activity is increased, which increases cardiac output. It also redistributes blood flow to the muscles.

questions.text: A study reveals that the cell junction is the cellular structure that consists of multiprotein complexes. These complexes provide adhesion to the cells and extracellular matrix. Some junctions act as paracellular barriers and control paracellular transport. A tight junction is formed between adjacent epithelial cells and acts as a barrier. Which of the following is the other name for a tight junction?
questions.solution:
Option A: Zona occludens

  • Zona occludens is the other name for the tight junction.
  • Zona occludens are present at the border between the apical and lateral membranes.
  • Tight junctions, also known as occluding junctions or zonulae occludens, are multiprotein junctional complexes whose general function is to prevent leakage of transported solutes and water and seal the paracellular pathway.
  • The intercalated discs are composed of fascia adherens that are responsible for end-to-end cell anchoring of actin filaments to one another, and no tight junctions (Zona occludens) are present.
  • Zona occludens = tight junction, Macula adherens = desmosome.
  • Between the myofibres, the macula adherens (or desmosomes) bind the cells and are responsible for anchoring the intermediate filament cytoskeletal proteins, vimentin, and desmin.

Intercalated disk

  • The intercalated disk is a tough double membranous structure situated at the junction between the branches of neighboring cardiac muscle fibres.
  • It is formed by the fusion of the membrane of the cardiac muscle branches.
  • Intercalated disks form adherens junctions, which play an important role in the contraction of cardiac muscle as a single unit.

Option B: Macula adherens

  • Desmosomes are cell structures that act as binders during the contraction of cardiac muscles. It is also known as macula adherens. Desmosomes create tighter and smaller junctions compared to fascia adherens.

Option C: Fascia adherens

  • The intercalated discs are composed of fascia adherens that are responsible for end-to-end cell anchoring of actin filaments to one another.

Option D: Gap junctions 

  • Three types of special structures: Fascia adherens, desmosomes, and gap junctions, are found in the intercalated discs to help in the connection of the cardiac muscle cells.

questions.text: A group of students gives a presentation on the transport of molecules and ions across cellular membranes. They describe various modes of transport, including passive transport, active transport, simple diffusion, secondary active transport, etc. Which of the following is the method of transport of glucose in the intestine?
questions.solution:
Option B: Secondary Active Transport

  • Secondary active transport is the transport of a molecule/ion against its concentration gradient across a membrane utilizing the energy of another ion/molecule, which is moving down the concentration gradient.
  • The electrochemical gradients set up by primary active transport store energy, which is used to move other substances against their concentration gradients.
  • The method of glucose transport in the intestine is called secondary active transport.
  • Both glucose and Na+ enter inside the cell (in the same direction) via sodium-glucose cotransporter 1 (SGLT-1). This is called symport.
  • No energy is used when glucose and Na+ enter the cell.
  • However, energy is used indirectly for glucose transport via Na+- K+ ATPase pump at the basolateral membrane.
  • Sodium-glucose symporter carries 2Na+ for each glucose.

  • On the intestinal luminal surface, there is SGLT-1 (secondary active transport), while on the basal surface is GLUT-2 (facilitative transport)

Option A: Primary active transport

  • When the energy is directly used to transport a molecule across the membrane, it is known as primary active transport.
  • A lot of minerals and ions, such as Na+, K+, Mg2+, and Ca2+, are transported by this method using an ion channel.
  • Usually, the enzyme involved is an ATPase, such as Na+- K+ ATPase.

Option C: Simple Diffusion

  • It is a type of passive transport where no energy is required as molecules move from a region of high concentration to a region of low concentration, e.g., the movement of gases O2 and CO2 during respiration.
  • The rate of diffusion depends on the permeability of the membrane.

Option D: Counter transport

  • Also known as antiport.
  • 2 molecules are moved at the same time but in opposite directions, e.g., Na+- H+ antiport and Na+- Ca+ antiport
  • One molecule moves along the concentration gradient in one direction, and the other moves in the opposite direction with the help of carrier protein.

questions.text: In a 3-month-old infant displaying symptoms of respiratory distress, feeding difficulty, and severe muscle weakness, further examination reveals generalized hypotonia and cardiomegaly. Notably, there is an absence of hypoglycemia. Subsequent muscle biopsy indicates the presence of glycogen in lysosomes. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acid maltase

Pompe’s disease:

  • It is the only GSD which is a Lysosomal Storage Disease (LSD).
  • Occur due to deficiency of acid maltase enzyme also known as acid α (1→4) Glucosidase.
  • This enzyme is present in lysosomes, catalyzes the minor pathway of glycogen breakdown.
  • Patient has:
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Progressive skeletal myopathy
    • Death occurs within 2 years due to cardiac failure
  • The muscle biopsy shows vacuoles.
  • The treatment for Pompe’s disease is enzyme replacement therapy using recombinant enzyme alglucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

Option B: Muscle phosphorylase

  • Deficiency of muscle phosphorylase (McArdle’s disease) cause poor mobilization of muscle glycogen leading to exercise intolerance and myoglobinuria with characteristic feature of relatively low blood lactate levels after exercise.

Option C: Branching enzyme

  • Deficiency of branching enzyme (Anderson’s disease ) causes abnormal structure of stored glycogen that resembles long polysaccharide chains having only few branch points giving amylopectin like appearance.
  • Clinical features of are hepatosplenomegaly and death from heart or liver failure before age 5

Option D: Debranching enzyme

  • The main clinical feature associated with deficiency of debranching enzyme (Cori’s disease) is accumulation of limit dextrins (glycogen remains having shorter linear chains with very short branch point) in liver under fasting.

questions.text: To inhibit the formation of foam cells and fatty streaks in the vascular sub-endothelium resulting from uncontrolled phagocytosis of oxidized LDL particles, which substance's increased dietary intake may be beneficial?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin E

  • Oxidation of lipid and protein portion of LDL is deleterious.
  • Oxidized LDL is taken up by scavenger receptors of the macrophages and leads to foam cell formation. It promotes atherosclerosis. Thus, it is important to prevent the oxidation of LDL.
  • Vitamin E is the chain-breaking antioxidant that acts on the lipid phase of LDL and prevents lipid peroxidation.

Option B: Vitamin B6

  • It is used as a cofactor in:
  • Transamination reaction
  • Decarboxylation reactions
  • Has a role in the synthesis of heme, serotonin, norepinephrine, and glutathione.
  • However, no role has been documented as an antioxidant agent.

Option C: Vitamin D

  • It has a role in:
    • Increased intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate.
    • Increased bone resorption at high serum levels.
    • However, no antioxidant role is associated with it.

Option D: Vitamin B12

  • It plays a vital role as a cofactor for methionine synthesis.
  • As a major contributor to DNA synthesis.
  • However, no role has been documented as an antioxidant agent.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient presented to the clinic complaining of diarrhea and disoriented memory. Physical examination revealed a rash on the exposed parts of her body, as shown in the exhibit below. Medical history reveals isoniazid therapy for tuberculosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Niacin deficiency

  • This patient has the classic triad of Dermatitis, Dementia, and Diarrhea, showing Casal's necklace, and is most likely suffering from pellagra caused by niacin deficiency.
  • Prolonged treatment with isoniazid can lead to pyridoxine deficiency, which is required for the endogenous synthesis of niacin.
  • Pellagra is caused by:
    • Dietary deficiency of nicotinic acid or its precursor tryptophan.
    • People with a staple diet of maize and Jowar. Maize is a poor source of both nicotinic acid and tryptophan, and a part of nicotinic acid is in a bound form that is not assimilated in the gastrointestinal tract. Jowar has a high content of leucine. The imbalance between leucine and other related amino acids interferes with the conversion of tryptophan to nicotinic acid.
    • Malabsorption 
    • Drugs like isoniazid (INH), 5-Fluorouracil (5FU), and 6-mercaptopurine.
    • Carcinoid syndrome

Treatment: Niacinamide 300-500mg/day orally in divided doses.

Option A: Tuberculosis skin lesions

  • Lesions of cutaneous tuberculosis appear as painful, friable, yellowish-to-erythematous nodules and papules, 1 to 3 cm in diameter.
  • They can result in painful ulcers in the skin with fibrinous bases near body orifices.
  • Edema and inflammation are also evident in perilesional tissue.
  • They do not form the typical appearance of a Casal's necklace.

Option C: Isoniazid neuropathy

  • Prolonged use of isoniazid can cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency which can cause decreased sensation in extremities or peripheral neuropathy, but this patient does not have neuropathy symptoms; instead, she complaints of diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

Option D: Pyridoxine deficiency

  • Although this patient has a history of isoniazid use and isoniazid can cause pyridoxine deficiency, it would result in peripheral neuropathy.
  • Pyridoxine deficiency in itself does not cause diarrhea, dementia, or dermatitis. However, pyridoxine deficiency causes a secondary deficiency of niacin which causes all these symptoms.

questions.text: A researcher is studying some procedures of epigenetics. He is exploring chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP), which is antibody-procedure, based on combination of techniques of molecular biology and proteomic analysis. Which of the following is most likely used for ChIP?

choices.text: Protein DNA interactions and histone modifications

questions.solution:
ChIP (Chromatin Immuno Precipitation)

  • It detects interactions between DNA & proteins and can provide information on histone modifications.
  • ChIP assays are combined with sequencing. It can be used to map global binding sites precisely for any protein of interest like transcription factors.

Applications include genotyping, clinical genetic testing, forensic analysis, cancer mutations and genetic linkage analysis.

It is not used for detection of aneuploidy (monosomy/trisomy)- FISH is the method of choice for detecting aneuploidy.

ChIP and Chip are both different

  • Chip is known as Microarray/Bioarray/Gene Array. It is a slide like device on which known DNA is attached whereas ChIP is a technique based in protein DNA interaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is equivalent to the Pribnow box in eukaryotes for initiating transcription?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hogness box

  • The Hogness box is also known as the TATA box.
  • It is a DNA sequence found in the promoter region of the eukaryotic gene.
  • RNA polymerase binds here to initiate transcription.
  • In prokaryotic genes, a similar DNA sequence in the promoter region is known as the Pribnow box.
  • So, the eukaryotic Hogness box is equivalent to the prokaryotic Pribnow box.
  • The Hogness box is a DNA sequence that indicates where a genetic sequence can be read and decoded.
  • TATA-binding protein (TBP) binds the TATA region and initiates transcription.
  • Mutation in the Hogness box affects the binding of TBP, resulting in various genetic diseases, such as neurodegenerative disorder (spinocerebellar ataxia and Huntington's disease).
  • Deletion of a TATA box results in loss of corresponding cap sites.
  • TATA box is highly conserved in evolution.
  • It is found about 25-30 base pairs upstream of the transcription initiation site.

[Pribnow and Hogness box]

Option B: GC box

  • The GC box is approximately 110 base pairs upstream of the transcription initiation site.
  • It has a consensus sequence GGGCGG.
  • It binds transcription factors and act as transcription enhancer elements.
  • Also, this is not equivalent to the Pribnow box as it does not bind RNA pol.

Option C: CAAT box

  • The CAAT box is approximately 75-80 base pairs upstream of the transcription initiation site.
  • It has a consensus sequence GGNCAATCT.
  • It binds to general transcriptional factors and works as enhancer element in eukaryotic genes.
  • Also, this is not equivalent to the Pribnow box as it does not bind RNA polymerase directly.

Option D: Refer to above explanations

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic presented in an unconscious state and recovered by injection of thiamine followed by overnight parenteral glucose. The next morning, he had normal serum thiamine with blood glucose = 73 mg/dL. Which of the following enzymes/proteins would have low significant physiologic activity in this patient soon after discharge?
questions.solution:
• After an overnight fast (plasma glucose 73 mg/dL), the glucose concentration will be low.
  • At low glucose levels, hexokinase with its higher afﬁnity for glucose can convert all the glucose to glucose 6-phosphate without triggering the release of its isozyme for glucokinase hence glucokinase concentration remains low.
  • Glucokinase has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than hexokinase, so, it is mostly active in post prandial state when glucose levels are high in the liver.
  • So, in this patient, the activity of glucokinase would be insignificant as it requires high glucose concentration to be effective.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is involved in the activation of fatty acids during beta-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Thiokinase

Fatty acid activation for beta-oxidation:

  • Beta-oxidation oxidizes the fatty acids and releases acetyl-CoA as end products.
  • In order to start this cycle of beta-oxidation, fatty acids need to enter the mitochondria by activation by acyl CoA synthetase/thiokinase.
  • This is the only step in the oxidation of fatty acid that uses energy from ATP. The reaction is shown below

  • The PPi is further hydrolyzed by inorganic pyrophosphatase to make the reaction highly spontaneous.
  • Acyl-CoA synthetases are present in the endoplasmic reticulum, peroxisomes, and the outer membrane of mitochondria.

Option A: Thiophorase

  • Thiophorase does not help to solve the permeation problem of fatty acids.
  • It uses succinyl-CoA to activate acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA.

Option C: Thiolase

  • It’s a wrong answer.
  • It does not help to solve the permeation problem of fatty acids.
  • It’s also known as acetyl-CoA acetyltransferases.
  • It converts two units of acetyl-CoA to acetoacetyl-CoA.

Option D: Thioesterase

  • ​​​​​​​It catalysis the cleavage of thioester bonds which are present in a diverse array of cellular substrates.

questions.text: All of the following disorders are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except:
questions.solution:
Option D: Fabry’s disease

  • Fabry’s disease is a X-linked recessive disorder characterized by deficiency of alpha galatoceramidase enzyme resulting in accumulation of CeramideTrihexoside or Globotriosyl Ceramide.
  • Patient presents with symptoms such as Triad of peripheral neuropathy, Angiokeratoma and Hypohidrosis

Option A: Sandhoff’s disease

  • Enzyme deficient –Hexosaminidase A and B
  • Substrate accumulated: Globoside
  • C/F
    • Macrocephaly
    • Hyperacusis
    • Cherry-red spot

Option B: Niemann-Pick disease

  • Enzyme deficient – Sphingomyelinase
  • Substrate accumulated: Sphingomyelin
  • C/F:
    • Mental retardation
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • present
    • Cherry red spots present
    • Lymphadenopathy

Option C: Gaucher’s disease

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disease
  • Enzyme deficient – Gluco-cerebrosidase
  • Substrate accumulated: Glucosyl Ceramide
  • C/F
    • No cherry red spots
    • Bony pain, pathological fractures
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • No Mental Retardation

ERT (Enzyme Replacement Therapy) is available.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents to the clinic with the problem of severe sunburn after a trip to the beach during the summer vacation. On examination, she is found to have fair hair, fair skin, and red eyes, as shown in the figure below:



Which of the following is the most likely disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Albinism

  • Albinism Is the absence of pigment Melanin from the skin, hair, and eyes (milky white skin, white hair, red eye color)
  • Enzyme deficient is Tyrosinase (an Oxidase that requires Cu).
  • Oculo Cutaneous Albinism is associated with defects in Vision and Photophobia.
  • With ocular albinism, the color of the eye's iris may vary from blue to green.
  • However, when an ophthalmologist examines the eye by shining a light from the side of the eye, the light shines back through the iris since minimal pigment is present.
  • Since there is no cure for albinism, lifestyle adjustments can manage patients with albinism.
  • People with albinism need to take care not to get sunburn because of a lack of Melanin and should have regular healthy skin checks by a dermatologist.
  • Albinism can affect people of all ethnic backgrounds, and its frequency is estimated to be approximately one in 17,000.
  • The prevalence of the different forms of albinism varies by population and is highest in people of Sub-Saharan African descent.

Option A: Phenylketonuria (PKU)

  • Phenylketonuria is due to defects in the enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase.
  • Albinism is not seen.
  • There is a musty odor from the body.

Option C: Alkaptonuria

  • Alkaptonuria is associated with defects in Catabolism of Tyrosine and Phenylalanine.
  • Causes pigmentation of the cartilages.
  • May cause arthropathy.

Option D: Vitiligo

  • In vitiligo, the enzyme Tyrosinase is normal, but there is a lack of Melano-blasts in regional areas.
  • This is an autoimmune disease.
  • Maybe segmental or non-segmental.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to a sudden episode of unconsciousness while playing basketball. His past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. He does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. Family history is significant for sudden death in maternal uncle at a young age. Appropriate measures are taken, but the patient fails to survive. An autopsy report revealed left ventricular hypertrophy, especially in the septal area. Which of the following is not associated with hypertrophy?

choices.text: Occurs due to the synthesis and assembly of additional intracellular components.
There is an increase in the size of the cells.
Cells incapable of division respond to stress by hypertrophy.
There is an increase in the number of cells.

questions.solution:
Option D: There is an increase in the number of cells.

  • Hypertrophy is a condition in which cells grow in size, increasing the size of the affected organ..

  • Hyperplasia is a condition in which there is an increase in the number of cells

  • Stress can cause hypertrophy in cells with limited ability to divide, while it causes hyperplasia in cells that can divide.

  • Hypertrophy and hyperplasia can occur together, leading to an enlarged organ.

  • A limit is reached beyond which the muscle mass cannot enlarge to compensate for the increased burden.

  • The hypertrophy then changes to regressive/degenerative changes leading to ventricular dilation and heart failure in the heart.

Option A: Occurs due to the synthesis and assembly of additional intracellular components.

  • Hypertrophy involves the synthesis of new proteins and cell components

  • The synthesis and assembly of proteins increase the size of the cells and extra structural components within the cell.

Option B: There is an increase in the size of the cells.

  • In hypertrophy, cell size increases in response to stress

  •  Hypertrophy is a condition in which cells grow in size, resulting in an increase in the size of the affected organ.

  • Hypertrophy can progress to significant functional cell injury if the stress is not relieved.

Option C: Cells incapable of division respond to stress by hypertrophy.

  • Cells respond to stress by either hypertrophy (increase in cell size) and/or hyperplasia (increase in cell number).

  • Cells incapable of division respond by hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 90-year-old woman dies peacefully in her sleep, despite having minor diabetes and Alzheimer's disease. Hepatocytes with golden granules in their cytoplasm that do not stain with Prussian blue are found at autopsy. Which of the following best describes the pigment buildup in this patient's liver?
questions.solution:
Option A: Advanced age

Lipofuscin:

  • Lipofuscin is a yellow-brown “wear and tear” pigment associated with normal ageing. Composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids complexed with protein.

  • It may be derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes.

  • Autopsy of an older person will reveal deposits in the heart, colon, liver, kidney, eye, and other organs.

  • Substances that cannot be metabolized accumulate in cells. Examples include:-

    • Endogenous substrates that are not processed because a key enzyme is missing (lysosomal storage diseases)

    • Insoluble endogenous pigments like lipofuscin and melanin

    • Exogenous particulates like carbon and silica.

Option B: Alzheimer's disease

  • Alzheimer's is a chronic neurodegenerative disorder and the most common cause of dementia.

  • Characterized by progressive behavioural and cognitive dysfunction (e.g., short-term memory loss, impaired attention control and reasoning).

  • Associated with deposition of β-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles composed of phosphorylated tau (p-tau) protein.

  • Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

  • Accumulating amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease.

  • Intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein (neurofibrillary tangles) are visible in multiple neurons (examples indicated by green overlay).

  • Neurofibrillary tangles are a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease but are also found in other conditions.

Option C: Congestive heart failure

  • Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a clinical condition in which the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's metabolic needs because of pathological changes in the myocardium.

  • The three main Causes of CHF are coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension.

  • These conditions cause ventricular dysfunction with low cardiac output which results in blood congestion and poor systemic perfusion.

  • CHF is classified as either left heart failure (LHF) or right heart failure (RHF), while a combination of both is called biventricular or global CHF. 

  • LHF leads to pulmonary oedema and consequent dyspnea, while RHF leads to systemic venous congestion that causes symptoms such as pitting oedema, jugular venous distension, and hepatomegaly.

Heart failure cells in decompensated heart failure

  • An accumulation of brown macrophages can be seen in the centre of the image. Their colour is most likely due to hemosiderin from ingested erythrocytes. On the right side, an alveolus filled with erythrocytes is visible.

  • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (heart failure cells) in pulmonary tissue suggest decompensated heart failure.

Option D: Diabetic ketoacidosis

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis is a condition that is primarily seen in patients with type I diabetes and is caused by insufficient insulin levels (often secondary to acute infection).

  • Manifests with hyperglycaemia (usually 300-600 mg/dL), polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, vomiting, volume depletion (e.g., dry oral mucosa, decreased skin turgor), and eventually mental status changes and coma.

  • Unlike in HHS, no insulin is available to suppress fat breakdown; ketogenesis results.

  • Treatment consists of IV insulin, electrolyte, and fluid replacement

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is 42 weeks pregnant is admitted to the labor and delivery ward for labor induction. A fetal heart monitor shows that the fetus is in no acute distress. Sterile examination shows the patient to be minimally dilated without significant effacement. She is given carboprost to induce uterine contraction. Which of the following eicosanoid will the medication represent?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prostaglandin F2a

  • Most tissues of the body produce prostaglandin F2a.
  • It is responsible for vasoconstriction and bronchoconstriction.
  • It helps to stimulate uterine contraction to induce labour.
  • PGF2a acts to cause the contraction of smooth muscles.

Option A: Prostaglandin I2

  • Prostaglandin I2 (prostacyclin) is produced in the endothelium of vessels from arachidonic acid under the action of the cyclooxygenase-2 enzyme.
  • It has the following functions:
  • Vasodilation
  • Inhibits platelet aggregation

Option B: Lipoxins

  • Lipoxins are generated from arachidonic acid by the lipoxygenase pathway, but they suppress inflammation by inhibiting the recruitment of leukocytes.
  • They inhibit the chemotaxis of neutrophils and adhesion to endothelium.
  • Leukocytes produce intermediates during the synthesis of lipoxins, which are converted to lipoxins by platelet interacting with leukocytes.

 

Option C: Leukotriene C4

  • Leukotriene C4 and its metabolites, LTD4 and LTE4, are produced mainly in mast cells.
  • It has the following functions that promote inflammation:
  • Contraction of smooth muscles
  • Bronchoconstriction
  • Intense Vasoconstriction
  • Increased permeability of venules
  • Cysteinyl leukotrienes make up a slow-reacting substance of anaphylaxis.
  • Involved in the pathophysiology of asthma and seasonal allergies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the clinic complaining of fever, lethargy and facial swelling. Complete blood count shows pancytopenia, and renal function tests show creatinine 5mg/dl. The anti-double-stranded antibody is ordered, which comes out positive. A diagnosis of lupus nephritis is made. Which of the following hypersensitivity reactions with corresponding diseases?

choices.text: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura is an example of Hypersensitivity type 1
Reactive Arthritis Hypersensitivity is an example of Hypersensitivity type 3
Rheumatoid Arthritis is an example of Hypersensitivity type 2
Anaphylaxis is an example of Hypersensitivity type 4

questions.solution:
Option B: Reactive Arthritis Hypersensitivity is an example of Hypersensitivity type III

  • Deposition of circulating immune complexes occurs in type III hypersensitivity. 
  • The immune complex of antigen-antibody (mostly IgG) complexes activates complement, which attracts neutrophils; neutrophils release lysosomal enzymes. 
  • It can be associated with vasculitis and systemic manifestations.
  • Examples are SLE, serum sickness, Arthus reaction, and reactive arthritis.

Option A: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura is an example of Hypersensitivity type I

  • Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura is a classic example of Hypersensitivity type II.
  • IgG hypersensitivity reaction is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.  
  • Antibodies bind to cell-surface antigens or extracellular matrix cellular destruction, inflammation, and cellular dysfunction.  
  • Cellular destruction occurs by a cell is opsonized (coated) by antibodies, leading to either phagocytosis and/or activation of the complement system & natural cell killing (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).  
  • Examples are autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (including drug-induced form), immune thrombocytopenia, transfusion reactions & hemolytic disease of the newborn.  
  • Inflammation is mediated by the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces, activation of the complement system, and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation.  
  • Examples are Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever & hyperacute transplant rejection.  
  • Cellular dysfunction by antibodies binds to cell-surface receptors, abnormal blockade or activation of the downstream process.  
  • Examples are myasthenia gravis, Graves disease & pemphigus Vulgaris.

Option C: Rheumatoid Arthritis is an example of Hypersensitivity type II

  • Rheumatoid Arthritis is an example of Hypersensitivity type IV.
  • Two mechanisms, each involving T cells: 
    • 1. Direct cell cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T cells kill targeted cells. 
    • 2. Inflammatory reaction: effector CD4+ 
  • T cells recognize antigens and release inflammation-inducing cytokines. 
  • The response does not involve antibodies (vs types I, II, and III). 
  • Examples are contact dermatitis (e.g., poison ivy, nickel allergy) & graft-versus-host disease. 
  • This principle is used in clinical tests such as purified protein derivatives for tuberculosis infection, patch tests for contact dermatitis & candida skin test for T cell immune function.

Option D: Anaphylaxis is an example of Hypersensitivity type IV

  • Anaphylaxis is a classic example of Hypersensitivity type I
  • The IgE-mediated reaction is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.  
  • Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing.  
  • It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (e.g., the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g., peanuts, shell) or insect toxins (e.g., those in bee venom).  
  • The symptoms of the patient are due to hypersensitivity type I reaction.  
  • Type I is mediated by IgE, and it flares up within minutes.  
  • The symptoms range from rashes to anaphylactic shock with vasodilation hypotension and bronchiolar spasm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 18 weeks gestation, comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Ultrasonography at a previous visit when she was 12 weeks gestation showed a hypoplastic nasal bone. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with an 18-week gestation. Maternal serum studies show low α-fetoprotein and free estriol concentrations and increased inhibin A and β-hCG concentrations. A diagnosis of Down syndrome is made. Which of the following is associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trisomy Chromosome 21

  • Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21

Down syndrome:

  • Down syndrome, also called trisomy 21, is the most common autosomal chromosomal irregularity, occurring in approximately 1:700 live births.
  • The risk of a trisomy 21 pregnancy increases with maternal age.
  • Most individuals with Down syndrome have full trisomy 21, which occurs due to meiotic nondisjunction and results in a genotype with three complete copies of chromosome 21 and a total of 47 chromosomes.
  • Other less common forms of Down syndrome are translocation trisomy 21 and mosaic trisomy 21.
  • Clinically, trisomy 21 manifests as a syndrome involving a characteristic appearance (e.g., upward-slanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, protruding tongue, short stature, transverse palmar crease, sandal gap), organ malformations (e.g., heart defects, duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease), and endocrine disorders (e.g., obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism).
  • Trisomy 21 is associated with an increased risk of malignancy (e.g., high risk of leukaemia) and intellectual disability.
  • Down syndrome is primarily detected in prenatal tests, including ultrasound measurement of nuchal translucency and maternal blood tests for certain hormones (e.g., increased inhibin A and β-hCG; decreased estriol, alpha-fetoprotein, and pregnancy-associated protein A).
  • Fetal karyotyping via chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis confirm the diagnosis, but these procedures are associated with an increased risk of fetal injury or loss.
  • Management of trisomy 21 involves evaluation, monitoring, and treatment of the symptom complex and malformations as necessary.

Option B: Trisomy chromosome 18

  • Edwards syndrome, also known as trisomy 18, is a severe genetic condition affecting how your child's body develops and grows.
  • Children diagnosed with trisomy 18 have a low birth weight, multiple congenital disabilities and defining physical characteristics.

 

Option C: Trisomy chromosome 13

  • Trisomy 13 syndrome is a severe chromosomal disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 13.
  • The three etiologies of trisomy 13 (also called Patau syndrome)
  • Severe, multiple congenital anomalies characterize trisomy 13 syndromes.
  • The classic triad is micro/anophthalmia, cleft lip and/or palate, and postaxial polydactyly, but the clinical presentation in patients with trisomy 13 can be quite variable

Option D: Loss of X chromosome

  • This is seen in turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, shield chest, streak ovaries, widely spaced nipples and cubitus valgus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes to the physician for his annual physical exam. He reports no complaints other than occasional fatigue. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. The laboratory test results are pending. His peripheral blood smear picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Microcytic hypochromic anemia due to iron deficiency

questions.solution:
Option B: Macrocytic Anaemia

  • This patient has the signs and symptoms suggesting anaemia.
  • The peripheral smear findings of hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes → macrocytic anaemia.
  • Macrocytic anaemia or megaloblastic anaemia is characterised by impairment of DNA synthesis leading to ineffective hematopoiesis.
  • This abnormal hematopoiesis results in characteristic morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red blood cells and the hypersegmented neutrophils as seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear.
  • Megaloblastic anaemia is caused by folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 and folic acid are required as coenzymes for thymidylate synthesis, which is an essential component for DNA synthesis.
  • Defective DNA synthesis → delayed nuclear maturation → macro polymorphonuclear cells with nuclear hypersegmentation (five or more lobules instead of the normal three or four lobules).

Option A: Microcytic hypochromic anaemia due to iron deficiency

  • Iron deficiency initially causes normocytic, normochromic anaemia and, if severe, causes microcytic hypochromic anaemia.
