  • The peripheral blood smear shows small red blood cells with central pallor and a thin peripheral rim of haemoglobin (hypochromia).

Option C: Thalassemia

  • This elderly patient is less likely to have thalassemia as it is usually diagnosed early.
  • The peripheral blood smear may show microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with occasional target cells.

Option D: Spherocytosis

  • Spherocytosis is an inherited disorder characterised by defective red cell membranes resulting in fragile red blood cells prone to hemolysis.
  • It is characterised by jaundice and hepatomegaly, which are not seen in this patient.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes, which are small, hyperchromic cells without central pallor.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with an 8-week history of increased tiredness and worsening leg pain. On examination, his temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination shows conjunctival pallor and diffuse petechiae. Posterior cervical lymph nodes and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged and non-tender. His haemoglobin concentration is 8.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 45,750/mm3, and platelet count is 25,000/mm3. A bone marrow aspiration shows numerous immature cells that stain positive for CD10, CD19, and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT). A diagnosis of ALL is made. Which of the following translocations is most commonly seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: t(12;21)

  • Translocation t(12;21) is the most common chromosomal rearrangement in childhood B-ALL and is associated with a favourable prognosis.
  • Further positive prognostic factors are a leukocyte count < 50,000/mm3, no central nervous system involvement, and hyperdiploid.
  • Factors associated with a poor prognosis include a Philadelphia translocation t(9;22) and age < 1 year or > 10 years. 85% of children with ALL achieve complete remission with chemotherapy.

Acute Leukemias

  • Acute leukaemias are malignant neoplastic diseases that arise from lymphoid or myeloid cell lines.
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy, whereas acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) primarily affects adults.
  • The underlying cause of acute leukaemia is rarely identifiable, but risk factors include prior chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hereditary syndromes such as Down syndrome.
  • AML is also associated with preexisting hematologic disorders (e.g., myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative disorders).
  • Acute leukaemias are characterized by the proliferation of immature, nonfunctional WBCs (blasts) in the bone marrow, impairs normal hematopoiesis.
  • This leads to pancytopenia, which manifests with symptoms and signs of anaemia (decreased RBCs), clotting disorders (decreased platelets), and immunocompromise (decreased fully functional, mature WBCs).
  • Patients with acute leukaemia, especially those with AML, may develop extremely high WBC counts, increasing the risk of leukostasis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • Leukemic cells can also infiltrate extramedullary organs, resulting in hepatosplenomegaly, renal impairment, meningeal leukaemia, and, less commonly, involvement of the skin and/or testicles.
  • The first diagnostic steps include a complete blood count and peripheral blood smear to determine the patient's WBC count and assess for the presence of blasts.
  • Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy are typically used to confirm the diagnosis, and subsequent cytogenetic analysis and immunophenotyping are used to identify subtypes and specific mutations.
  • A chemotherapy regimen consisting of high-dose (induction) and low-dose (consolidation and maintenance) cycles is the mainstay of treatment. Additional measures, such as allogeneic stem cell transplantation, may be indicated in patients with poor prognostic factors (e.g., unfavourable cytogenetics) or if initial chemotherapy fails.

Option A: t (15; 17)

  • Translocation t(15;17) is associated with acute myeloid leukaemia (particularly acute promyelocytic leukaemia, or APL), the most common kind of acute leukaemia in adults
  • This translocation alters the retinoic acid receptor, preventing myeloblast differentiation from occurring under physiologic levels of retinoic acid.
  • High doses of all-trans retinoic acid may induce remission, causing malignant cells to mature.

Option B: t (8;14)

  • Translocation t(8;14) is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, an aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma typically manifesting in children and young adults as a rapidly expanding jaw mass.

Option C: t(14;18)

  • Translocation t(14;18) is associated with follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults.
  • This patient has B-ALL, which is not typically associated with this translocation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to backache for 2 weeks. It is associated with fatigue, weight loss, polyuria, and polydipsia. He also reports episodes of confusion. Recent laboratory investigations show hypoalbuminemia, mild anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Plain radiographs of the lumbar spine show numerous lytic lesions. Serum electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal IgG peak. Bone marrow biopsy shows monoclonal plasma cell foci constituting 18% of all hematopoietic cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Multiple myeloma

  • The patient presents with the clinical features of multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is one of the plasma cell dyscrasias.
  • It presents the following:
    • Bone pains/ pathologic fractures
    • Confusion
    • Weakness and lethargy
    • Recurrent bacterial infections
    • Renal insufficiency/dysfunction
  • Laboratory investigations reveal:
    • Anaemia (rouleaux formation)
    • Leukocytopenia
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Increased immunoglobulins on serum protein electrophoresis (IgG followed by IgA, rarely IgM, D or E)
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Increased beta-2-microglobulin (tumour marker for multiple myeloma- a level below 3.5mg/L indicates better prognosis)
    • Bence-jones protein in the urine
    • Lytic lesions on x-rays
    • More than 10% of plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

  • ALL are usually present in children with anaemia, leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia.
  • Hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, and monoclonal antibodies are not seen at ALL.
  • Bone marrow biopsy in ALL reveals blast cells.

Option B: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL)

  • CLL presents in adults with lymphocytosis.
  • Hypercalcemia and monoclonal antibodies are not seen in CLL.

Option C: Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia

  • Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is one of the plasma cell dyscrasias which present as hyperviscosity syndrome.
  • IgM is the immunoglobulin which is raised in Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

questions.text: A sixty-two-year-old male presents to your clinic with complaints of fever and fatigue. Examination findings for the patient are positive for hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Blood smear findings are shown below. These findings are characteristic for which of the following lymphomas are associated with HTLV virus infection?
questions.solution:
Option C: Adult T-cell leukaemia and lymphoma

  • Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma is a neoplasm of CD4+ T cells.
  • It is found in adults infected with the human T-cell leukaemia retrovirus type.
  • HTLV 1 causes adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma
  • Common findings include:
    • Skin lesions
    • Generalized lymphadenopathy
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Peripheral blood lymphocytosis
    • Hypercalcemia
  • Tumour cells vary in appearance, but cells with multilobulated nuclei ("cloverleaf" or "flower" cells) are characteristic findings.

Option A: Burkitt’s lymphoma

  • Burkitt lymphoma is cancer involving B lymphocytes found in the germinal centre of lymph tissue.
  • It is not caused by HTLV 1.

Option B: B-Cell lymphoma

  • B cell lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in B cells.
  • It is not caused by HTLV 1.

Option D: Hodgkin’s disease

  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a lymphoma characterized by Reed Sternberg cells.
  • It is not caused by HTLV 1.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anaemia. She is vitally stable and afebrile. A duodenal histopathological biopsy was performed, which revealed complete villous atrophy. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-endomysial antibodies

  • From the given case scenario suggesting features of malabsorption, iron deficiency anaemia and complete villous atrophy, a diagnosis of celiac disease can be made.
  • Serologic studies of celiac disease include:
    • Anti-endomysial antibodies
    • Tissue transglutaminase [tTG] antibodies: most specific
    • Antigliadin antibodies
  • Complications of celiac disease include:
    • Increased risk for enteropathic-associated T- cell lymphoma
    • IDA
    • malabsorption and skin complications
  • Treatment:
    • Cereal substitution with maise and rice
    • Dapsone for dermatitis herpetiformis
    • Corticosteroids

Option B: Anti-goblet cell antibodies

  • Autoimmune enteropathy, which is most common in children, is caused by anti-enterocyte antibodies, also known as anti-goblet cell antibodies and culminates in persistent diarrhoea with small intestinal villous atrophy.

Option C: Anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies

  • Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are immune proteins often found in persons with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), a set of chronic illnesses caused by an autoimmune process and characterised by swollen and damaged intestinal lining tissues.

Option D: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

  • Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are autoantibodies directed against antigens identified in neutrophil and monocyte cytoplasmic granules. ANCA testing is often used to diagnose or exclude Wegener's granulomatosis and microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with low-grade fever, weight loss, fatigue, crampy abdominal pain, episodic diarrhoea and postprandial bloating for the last few months. Right lower quadrant tenderness is elicited on palpation of the abdomen. A capsule endoscopy reveals thickening of the terminal ileum, oedema, marked luminal narrowing, and a cobblestone appearance of the mucosa. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Additional typical findings include crypt abscesses and Pseudopolyps
Inflammation and ulceration are limited to mucosa and submucosa with sparing of deeper layers
It can affect any portion of the gastrointestinal tract, but the proximal jejunum is the most common site of involvement
It can cause fistula formation between loops of the affected bowel

questions.solution:
Option D: It can cause fistula formation between loops of the affected bowel

  • This patient with low-grade fever, weight loss, fatigue, crampy abdominal pain, episodic diarrhoea, postprandial bloating, and endoscopy findings of thickening of the terminal ileum, oedema, marked luminal narrowing, and a cobblestone appearance of the mucosa, most likely has Crohn's disease.
  • Fistula formation between loops of the affected bowel is a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease.

Option A: Additional typical findings include crypt abscesses and Pseudopolyps

  • Crypt abscesses & Pseudopolyps are seen in ulcerative colitis, not in Crohn's disease.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B: Inflammation and ulceration limited to mucosa and submucosa with sparing of deeper layers

  • Transmural involvement of the intestine is seen in Crohn's disease
  •  Mucosal and submucosal inflammation is a feature of ulcerative colitis.

Option C: It can affect any portion of the gastrointestinal tract, but the proximal jejunum is the most common site of involvement

  • Crohn's disease can involve any part of GIT, but the most commonly involved site is the ileum.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 29-year-old non-smoker man has presented to your clinic with complaints of primary infertility for the last three years. He married five years ago, and his wife's fertility reports are clear. He has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. He is vitally stable. Physical examination has revealed grade 2 clubbing and apex beat on the right side in the fifth intercostal space. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze and right basal crackles are audible, with heart sounds best heard on the right side of the chest. The scrotal examination is unremarkable. His semen analysis has shown abnormal results. Upon further investigation, he is found to have classic symptoms of bronchiectasis and situs inversus. What is the most likely cause of infertility in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Asthenozoospermia

 

  • Asthenozoospermia is a common cause of human male infertility characterized by reduced sperm motility, less than 40%.
  • It is a case of Kartagener Syndrome.
  • In Kartagener Syndrome, a defective dynein arm results in defective ciliary motility.
  • The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.
  • It presents with a triad of:
    • Situs inversus
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Sinusitis
  • Reduced ciliary motility leads to asthenozoospermia due to missing dynein arms (slow-moving sperms)

Option A: Oligospermia 

  • Oligospermia is a decrease in sperm concentration in semen below 15 million sperm per milliliter (WHO, 2010).
  • Oligospermia is a defect in sperm production and may be due to surgically correctable causes like varicocele, exposure to thermal or chemical environmental factors suppressing spermatogenesis, hormonal factors, intrinsic testicular defect, or idiopathic.
  • Oligospermia is not associated with bronchiectasis and situs inversus.

Option B: Blockage of the epididymis

  • The epididymis becomes blocked, preventing sperm from entering the vas deferens and getting into the ejaculate.
  • A blockage can occur on one side or both sides.
  • The most important cause for this is infections, any prior scrotal surgery or trauma
  • There is no such history in this scenario.
  • During the examination of the ductal structures, the epididymis may feel as though it is dilated and hardened.
  • Generally, it is flat in the middle and cannot be felt.
  • If there is a dilated and hardened epididymis, it may indicate a blockage.

Option D: Undescended Testis

  • The testicles develop in the abdomen while a male baby is still in the uterus.
  • Before birth, the testicles typically drop from inside the abdomen to the scrotum.
  • Undescended testicles fail to drop into the scrotum before birth or in the first few months of life.
  • The condition is also called cryptorchidism.
  • If the testicles are non-palpable on examination, they may be undescended.
  • In this case, the scrotal examination is normal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to an outpatient clinic with a complaint of a lump lump in her right breast. Her previous medical history does not warrant any special attention. Physical examination revealed a 0.5 cm rubbery mass in the right upper quadrant. The mass is painless and can move in horizontal and vertical planes. Mammography is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fibroadenoma 

  • It is a common benign breast tumour in women.
  • Although the pathogenesis of fibroadenoma is unknown, two-thirds of patients have MED12 mutations.
  • These tumours are most common in young females. 
  • Because fibroadenoma responds to oestrogen levels, it can grow during the period of high oestrogen (pregnancy) and regress after menopause. 
  • Characteristics of fibroadenoma are 
    • Well circumscribed 
    • Rubbery 
    • Greyish 
    • Mobile 
  • Because of the rapid growth and infarction of tumours during pregnancy may resemble carcinoma.
  • Fibroadenoma can increase the risk of carcinoma when complex features are present 
    • Cyst > 0.3 cm 
    • Sclerosing adenosis
    • Epithelial calcifications 
    • Papillary apocrine change
  • The majority of patients who receive cyclosporin after a kidney transplant are at an increased risk of developing multiple fibroadenomas.
  • Histopathology 
    • Pericanalicular pattern - epithelium is surrounded by stroma 
    • Intracanalicular pattern - compressed and distorted lumen by stroma 

Option A: Fibrocystic disease

  • It is a benign breast condition palpated as "lumpy bumpy." 
  • It causes multiple cysts to form and stromal fibrosis. 
  • Smaller cysts combine to form larger ones. 
  • Fibrosis is caused by material leakage caused by cyst rupture.  

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • The majority of medullary carcinomas are caused by hypermethylation of the BRCA 1 promoter, which results in decreased gene expression in approximately 67% of patients.
  • It is not associated with the familial BRCA1 mutation. 
  • The infiltration of T lymphocytes is the most common feature of these tumours. As a result, the outcome is determined by the host's immune response and antigen burden. 
  • It has a better prognosis. 

Option D: Colloid carcinoma

  • It has a soft or rubbery consistency and the appearance of pale grey-blue gelatin. 
  • Tumours appear as small islands of cells surrounded by mucin.

questions.text: MRI done in a 28yrs old male suffering from neurofibromatosis 2 showed an ice cream cone appearance. On asking, he further revealed that it began with a ringing sensation in the ears, which progressed to balance problems and hearing loss. Which of the following microscopic finding is seen in a given disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Antoni A and B pattern

  • These benign tumours exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves. They are a component of neurofibromatosis -2 (NF2).
  • Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B, as shown.
  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is common, and “nuclear-free zones” lie between the regions of nuclear palisading and is termed Verocay bodies.

  • NF2 is associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas and hearing loss
  • Benign tumours usually originate from perineural fibroblasts.
  • Intracranial schwannomas originate from the vestibular branch of the eighth cranial nerve.
  • Malignant schwannomas, although rare, are treated with radiation therapy if curative resection is not possible.

Option A: Spindle cells

  • Spindle cells are not associated with vestibular schwannomas.
  • Spindle cells are present in meningiomas.

Option B: Storiform pattern

  • An intracranial malignant fibrous histiocytoma is a tumour composed of collagen-forming spindle cell proliferation arranged in a storiform pattern.

Option C: Target cells

  • Target cells are not a feature of vestibular schwannomas.
  • Target cells are a feature of thalassemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented in OPD with right flank pain and blood in urine from 2 weeks. On examination, a flank mass is palpable on the right side. CECT reveals a heterogeneous group for which nephrectomy is done. Histopathology of the specimen showed a renal cell tumour infiltrating as a complex papillary structure, covered by a single layer of tumour cells and with low-grade nuclei. This tumour type is characterized cytogenetically by?
questions.solution:
Option C: Trisomy 7/17

  • The patient complained of right lumbar pain and hematuria and was diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. Nephrectomy is done, and histopathology reveals type 1Papillary carcinoma.
  • The cytogenetics of papillary renal cell carcinoma is characterized by trisomy 7/17.
  • In papillary carcinoma, papillae are present; it arises from distal tubular cells, is multifocal & bilateral, and results due to trisomy 7 / 16 / 17
  • Trisomy 7 is associated with sporadic & familial variants of papillary carcinoma and is more frequently associated with dialysis associated with cystic disease. Foamy macrophages are present.
  • Psammoma bodies are also present.

 

 

Option A: Mutant VHL gene

  • Mutations in the VHL gene cause von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.
  • It is a rare, inherited disorder that causes tumours and cysts to grow in the brain, spinal cord, eyes, inner ear, adrenal glands, pancreas, kidney, and reproductive tract.
  • The tumours are usually benign, but some may be malignant.

 

Option B: Loss of 3p

  • The loss of DNA sequences on chromosome 3p is one of the primary and most common events in the pathogenesis of the clear cell variant of renal cell carcinoma.

 

Option D: FH genes

  • Mutations in the FH gene cause hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer.
  • The FH gene makes a protein called fumarase.

questions.text: A 26 years male presents to opd with complaints of pain abdomen, nausea and vomiting for 5 hours. He says that the pain is intolerable and radiating to the umbilicus. There is a history of 2 episodes of hematuria. USG revealed multiple renal stones. Urinalysis is done, and the following urine crystals are seen. These stones are made of which of the following substance?
questions.solution:
Option A: Calcium oxalate

  • Etiologies:
    • Hypercalciuria
    • Hyperoxaluria
    • Hypocitraturia
    • Can result from increased intake of Ethylene glycol (antifreeze)
    • Vitamin C
    • Associated with inflammatory bowel disease, i.e., ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease due to malabsorption
  • Crystals are Biconcave dumbbells or bipyramidal envelopes.
  • Urine pH is low
  • Stone is radio-opaque
  • Urine alkalinization is chosen for prophylaxis.

Option B: Uric acid

  • The stones are rounded rhomboids, rosettes, or needle-shaped.

Option C: Calcium phosphate

  • Calcium phosphate stones are Wedge-shaped prisms.

Option D: Cysteine

  • Cysteine stones are hexagonal.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl arrived at the ER after ingesting 15 tablets of an unknown drug, causing altered mental status, rapid breathing, and vomiting. To treat drug toxicity, various methods can remove the drug from the body, such as dialysis. Which drug, when toxic, is eliminated through urine acidification?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amphetamine

  • In this case, the patient presented in a semi-conscious state with tachypnea and vomiting due to drug overdose toxicity.
  • Most drugs are metabolized in the liver and excreted by the kidneys.
  • During the poisoning of drugs, multiple mechanisms work to remove the drug from the body.
  • Changes in urinary pH affect tubular reabsorption of partially ionized drugs. Weak bases ionize more and are less reabsorbed in acidic urine. Weak acids ionize more and are less reabsorbed in alkaline urine.
  • Urine is acidified in case of amphetamine poisoning, as amphetamine is basic. It ionizes more and absorbs less in acidic urine.

Option A: Salicylates

  • Urinary pH has a great impact on the reabsorption of a drug.
  • Weak acids ionize more and reabsorb less in alkaline urine.
  • Urine is alkalinized in salicylate poisoning, as salicylate is a weak acid, so it ionizes more and reabsorbs less in alkaline urine.

Option B: Barbiturates

  • Urinary pH has a great impact on the reabsorption of a drug.
  • Weak acids ionize more and reabsorb less in alkaline urine
  • Urine is alkalinized in barbiturate poisoning, as it is a weak acid, so it ionizes more and reabsorbs less in alkaline urine.

Option D: Methotrexate

  • Urinary pH has a great impact on the reabsorption of a drug.
  • Weak acids ionize more and reabsorb less in alkaline urine
  • Urine is alkalinized in methotrexate poisoning, as it is a weak acid, so it ionizes more and reabsorbs less in alkaline urine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes a dose-response curve?

choices.text: Dose Response Curve(DRC) has a sigmoid shape
Area under time and plasma concentration curve signifies the extent of absorption of the drug
Drug dose is plotted on Y-axis
Quantal DRC tells about the effect of drugs on an individual

questions.solution:
Option B: Area under time and plasma concentration curve signifies the extent of absorption of the drug

Dose-response curves:

  • The relationship between the dose of a drug or substance and the measured response. Typically plotted on a graph, the X axis is the drug dose, and the Y axis is the measured response.
  • Plots of dose (or log dose) versus response for drugs (agonists) that activate receptors can reveal information about these agonists' affinity, potency, and efficacy.
  • The following terms are used to describe dose-response relationships:
    • Potency (EC50): The potency of a drug is measured as the concentration required to produce a pharmacological response of a specified intensity. 
    • Not related to efficacy (drugs with a high potency can have a low efficacy) but dependent on affinity.
    • EC50 = the effective concentration required to produce 50% of the maximum possible response (Emax).
    • A left shift of the curve is a sign of decreased EC50 and increased potency, meaning a lower concentration of the drug is needed.
    • EC50 is not to be confused with ED50; ED50 is the median effective dose that produces a desired beneficial effect in 50% of the population.
    • ED50 = 5 mg implies that the administration of 5 mg of the drug achieves the desired effect in 50% of the studied population.
    • The same drug may have different ED50 values based on the indication (e.g., aspirin has different ED50 values for headache and for thromboembolism prophylaxis).

  • Drug efficacy:
    • In pharmacology, “drug efficacy” refers to the maximum effect (Emax) a drug is capable of producing (where increases in dose will not increase effect).
    • The relative efficacy graph illustrates the difference in efficacy between drugs A and B at high drug concentrations.
  • Therapeutic index (TI): a measurement of the safety of a drug 
    • TI = median toxic dose (TD50)/median effective dose (ED50)

  • The greater the therapeutic index, the safer the drug 
  • High therapeutic index: e.g., glucocorticoids, penicillin.
  • Narrow therapeutic index: Drugs with a narrow TI require monitoring (e.g., lithium, theophylline, warfarin, digoxin, and antiepileptic drugs).
  • Therapeutic window: the range of doses that is effective for treating a condition with a minimum of adverse effects
  • The lethal dose (LD50): The dose that is lethal for 50% of the test population in animal experiments

Plasma concentration-time curve:

  • The area under the curve (AUC) tells the extent of absorption.
  • When compared with the AUC of the intravenous route, we get bioavailability.
  • Oral Bioavailability = AUC (oral)/AUC (IV)

The area under the curve of bioavailability graphs

  • The blue line shows the concentration of a substance administered intravenously (IV) over a while, and the red line shows the concentration of a substance taken orally.
  • The ratio of the area under the curve (AUC) of the orally administered substance to the AUC of the IV substance yields a substance's bioavailability (F).
  • Tmax is the time required to attain the maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), which tells the absorption rate. The lower the Tmax, the faster the rate of absorption.
  • Cmax tells the maximum concentration that is obtained by a particular dose.

Option A: Dose Response Curve(DRC) has a sigmoid shape

  • Dose-Response Curve(DRC) has a Hyperbola shape.
  • However, the log Dose Response Curve (log DRC) is a Sigmoid shape.

Option C: Drug dose is plotted on Y-axis

  • While plotting dose-response curves X axis is the drug dose, and the Y axis is the measured response.
  • Slope tells the drug's safety; the more the slope, the less the safety.

Option D: Quantal DRC tells about the effect of a drug on an individual

  • Quantal DRC tells about the effect of a drug on the population.
  • Quantal D-R curves plot the percentage of a population responding to a specified drug effect versus dose or log dose.
  • They permit estimations of the median effective or effective dose in 50% of a population—ED50.
  • They can reveal the range of intersubject variability in drug response
  • A steep D-R curve reflects little variability
  • A flat D-R curve indicates great variability in patient sensitivity to the effects of a drug.

questions.text: Which drug, not inducing mydriasis, might the physician prescribe for a 50-year-old female experiencing severe right eye pain, blurred vision, nausea, and conjunctival injection with corneal edema, along with a fixed and dilated right pupil, without any other remarkable findings on examination?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pilocarpine

  • All these symptoms of the patient suggest angle closure glaucoma.
  • Pilocarpine is a drug which can be used for this condition.
  • Pilocarpine cause miosis, not mydriasis
  • Pilocarpinc causes marked sweating, salivation and increase in other secretions. The cardiovascular effects are complex. Small doses generally cause fall in BP (muscarinic), but higher doses elicit rise in BP and tachycardia which is probably due to ganglionic stimulation
  • Applied to the eye, it penetrates cornea and promptly causes miosis, ciliary muscle contraction and fall in intraocular tension lasting 4-8 hours.
  • Sympathomimetic drugs cause the contraction of dilator pupillae and thus result in active mydriasis, whereas parasympathomimetic drugs contract sphincter pupillae leading to active miosis.

Option A: Atropine

  • Parasympatholytic drugs like atropine stop the action of Ach on sphincter pupillae resulting in passive mydriasis.

Option B: Phenylephrine

  • Phenylephrine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist.
  • It can be used for:
    • Nasal decongestion
    • Dilation of the pupils

Option C: Tropicamide

  • Tropicamide is an anticholinergic drug.
  • It is also used for the dilation of the pupils.
  • It is usually used during the examination of the eyes.

questions.text: What condition makes it unsafe to prescribe an ACE inhibitor to a 36-year-old female with acute severe headache, dizziness, and hypertension, who is also a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Renal artery stenosis

  • ACE inhibitors are the drug of choice for controlling blood pressure in patients with diabetes mellitus type 2.
  • However, ACE inhibitors are contraindicated when the patient has renal artery stenosis due to azotaemia risk. Renal artery stenosis is the narrowing of arteries that carry blood to the kidneys.
  • Narrowing of the arteries prevents sufficient oxygen-rich blood from reaching the kidneys.
  • Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors are a medication used primarily for treating high blood pressure and heart failure.
  • ACE inhibitors relax the blood vessels and decrease blood volume, leading to lower blood pressure and decreased oxygen demand from the heart.
  • Types of blood pressure-lowering drugs are:
    • ACE inhibitors and ARBs. ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) inhibitors and ARBs (angiotensin receptor blockers) work by widening your blood vessels
    • Calcium channel blockers
    • Beta-blockers
    • Diuretics
  • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in:
    • Pregnancy
    • Hyperkalaemia
    • Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis
    • There is a risk of azotaemia resulting from preferential efferent arteriolar vasodilation in the renal glomerulus due to the inhibition of angiotensin II.
  • Indications of ACE inhibitors:
    • Hypertension
    • Coronary artery disease
    • Heart failure
    • Diabetes
    • Certain chronic kidney diseases
    • Heart attacks
    • A disease involves hardening the skin and connective tissues (scleroderma)
    • Migraines

Option A: Hypertension

  • ACE inhibitor belongs to one of the classes of anti-hypertensive drugs.
  • It is indicated for treating high blood pressure in patients with diabetes.

Option B: Myocardial infarction

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors increase the contractile function of the myocardium.
  • ACE inhibitors reduce myocardial infarction size and improve ventricular remodelling.
  • A decrease in the size of infarction and ventricular remodelling both benefit morbidity and mortality in post-infarction patients with left ventricular dysfunction.

Option D: Left ventricular dysfunction

  • ACE inhibitors decrease after-load and preload and increase cardiac output.
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors have several hemodynamic effects, beneficial in the presence of left ventricular (LV) dysfunction.
  • ACE inhibitors increase cardiac output and stroke volume and reduce systemic vascular resistance and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.

questions.text: A 66-year-old female comes in with complaints of difficulty breathing at rest and heaviness in the left chest region for the past few months. ECG and echocardiography were done, revealing significant left ventricular dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 40%, and a diagnosis of congestive heart failure is made. You feel that a diuretic is mandatory in the treatment of this case. Which diuretic would you prescribe with zero fear of excessive K+ excretion?
questions.solution:
Option C: Triamterene

  • Amiloride and triamterene are K+-sparing diuretics that act by inhibiting epithelial Na+ channels. 
  • In the distal tubules and collecting ducts, three separate channels are present (one for Na+, K+ and H+ each). Aldosterone acts on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD) to cause reabsorption of Na+. 
  • This generates a lumen negative potential difference across the membrane of this part of the nephron. To maintain electric neutrality, K+ and H+ are secreted in the lumen. 
  • When amiloride and triamterene inhibit epithelial Na+ channels, the transepithelial potential difference is not generated, and therefore, K+ and H+ are not secreted in the lumen. 
  • Thus due to more retention of K+, amiloride may result in hyperkalemia.

Option A: Acetazolamide

  • Acetazolamide decreases the secretion of H+ in the distal tubules and collecting ducts.
  • Due to less reabsorption of sodium in the proximal convulated tubules (PCT), more is delivered to the distal tubules (DT).
  • Na+ is exchanged with K+ and H+.
  • At equally natriuretic doses, K+ excretion is maximum with CA inhibitors because Na+ delivered to the distal tubules is exchanged only with K+ (excretion of H+ is inhibited by these drugs).

Option B: Furosemide

  • Furosemide inhibits the cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl-) of the thick ascending loop of Henle.
  • Therefore, it enhances the secretion of sodium, potassium and chloride and causes hypokalemia.

Option D: Thiazide

  • Inhibit NaCl reabsorption in early distal convoluted tubules.
  • Thiazide diuretics deliver a high luminal sodium load with a resulting physiological secretion of potassium, thus causing hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with persistent upper abdominal pain, worsened by food intake, but without radiation or other symptoms, has a medical history of controlled hypertension, hemorrhoids, and chronic low back pain treated with diclofenac. Given this scenario, what is the optimal management approach for him?
questions.solution:
Option D: Omeprazole

  • The patient has NSAID-related peptic ulcer disease, with his symptoms, i.e. postprandial pain, suggestive of a gastric ulcer. NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenases which result in decreased production of prostaglandins E1. This causes reduced mucous and bicarbonate secretion and decreased mucosal blood flow.
  • Proton pump inhibitors are the most effective agents for reducing NSAID-associated gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  • To prevent ulcers in patients at risk, discontinue NSAID if possible, combine NSAIDs with a PPI or misoprostol or use a COX 2 selective inhibitor, e.g. celecoxib.

Option A: Sucralfate

  • Sucralfate adheres to the ulcer and forms a protective covering that allows the ulcer to heal.
  • It can be used for the symptomatic relief of duodenal ulcers, prevention of stress ulcers and treatment of oral ulcers. It is not indicated for NSAID-induced PUD.

Option B: Pirenzepine

  • Pirenzepine is a selective M1 receptor antagonist available for treating PUD in Europe. It acts by decreasing gastric acid secretion; however, effective doses for ulcer healing produce intolerable side effects.
  • Its use for PUD is now obsolete, replaced with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and H2 receptor blockers.

Option C: Aluminum hydroxide

  • It is an antacid that binds to the protons in gastric acid and neutralizes it. Less effective than PPI and H2 receptor antagonists.
  • Aluminium hydroxide causes constipation, which would worsen the haemorrhoids in this patient, so it is not recommended in this case.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, who is G2P1 presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, palpitation, increased sweating and tremors for 2 weeks. On examination, her blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and pulse is 100 beats/min. The thyroid gland is mildly enlarged and non-tender with no audible bruit. What is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism during 2nd trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option B: Methimazole

  • This patient has symptoms of hyperthyroidism presenting with fatigue, increased sweating, palpitations, tremors and tachycardia.
  • Overt hyperthyroidism, i.e. low thyroid stimulating hormone, elevated free thyroxine T4 or triiodothyronine, is uncommon during pregnancy.
  • The most common cause of hyperthyroidism during pregnancy is Grave’s disease, an autoimmune disorder.
  • Hyperthyroidism can complicate pregnancy. It can lead to:
    • Miscarriage
    • Premature labour
    • Stillbirth
    • Neonatal death
    • Hypertension
    • Preeclampsia
    • Thyroid storm
  • Severe hyperthyroidism is treated with anti-thyroid medication.
  • Propylthiouracil is used during the first trimester since it is hepatotoxic and can cause agranulocytosis.
  • Methimazole is used during the second and third trimesters since methimazole is associated with aplasia cutis, choanal atresia, and tracheoesophageal fistula.
  • It is very important to treat thyroid disorders during pregnancy because thyroid hormone is very important for the fetus, especially during the first trimester. The thyroid hormone plays an essential role in normal brain development.

Option A: Propylthiouracil

  • Propylthiouracil is the drug of choice during the first trimester.

Option C: Sodium iodide

  • Sodium iodide is contraindicated in women who may become pregnant or who are pregnant.
  • It is considered a pregnancy category X drug.

Option D: Radioactive iodine

  • Radioactive iodine is contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to fetal hypothyroidism, mental retardation and increased malignancy risk in the infant.

questions.text: A 29-year-old schizophrenic male, currently under the treatment of Haloperidol, presented with Parkinsonism-like symptoms. Which of the following would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Option C: Benzhexol

  • Benzhexol is used to reduce tremors, muscle stiffness and movement problems that are associated with Parkinson's disease
  • It is also used to lessen side effects that are caused by some medications used to treat mental conditions

Option A: Levodopa

  • Parkinson's can be treated with Levodopa, which boosts dopamine levels; schizophrenia is often treated with drugs that block the activity of dopamine
  • So Levodopa should not be used to treat Parkinsonism-like symptoms in patients who are diagnosed cases of schizophrenia

Option B: Benserazide

  • Benserazide allows more of the Levodopa you take to get into your brain before it is changed into dopamine
  • This medication block the dopamine receptors in nerve cells
  • The resulting reduction in dopamine levels causes Parkinsonism
  • Typically, when someone stops taking these medications, the symptoms of parkinsonism decrease over time

Option D: Selegiline

  • Selegiline is used in combination with levodopa or levodopa and carbidopa combination to treat Parkinson's disease
  • This medicine works to increase and extend the effects of Levodopa
  • It may help to slow the progress of Parkinson's disease

questions.text: A 24-year-old final-year medical student complains of joint pains, intermittent lower back pain, difficulty sleeping, and exam-related anxiety. She worries about her studies, her mother's health (recently diagnosed with locally advanced colon cancer), and her younger brother's studies. The psychiatrist reassures her and prescribes a dual-function 5HT1 agonist and anxiolytic. What is the drug?
questions.solution:
Option D: Buspirone

  • The scenario mentioned above is a classical case of a generalized anxiety disorder(GAD), and buspirone is the drug of choice for generalized anxiety disorder due to its anxiolytic as well as 5HT1 agonist properties.
  • Buspirone has a high affinity for serotonin 5HT1 and 5HT2 receptors and moderate affinity for dopamine D2 receptors but no affinity for benzodiazepine-GABA receptors.
    • Therefore, by elevating the levels of serotonin and dopamine, it acts as an anxiolytic. However, due to a lack of affinity with benzodiazepine-GABA receptors, it has no sedative, anticonvulsant or muscle relaxant properties.
    • This makes it the drug of choice in this case - relieving anxiety without eliciting sedation and enabling the patient to study for her upcoming exams.

Option A: Diazepam

  • Diazepam is an antiseizure medication belonging to the benzodiazepines category.
    • It binds to stereospecific benzodiazepine receptors on the postsynaptic GABA neuron at several sites within the central nervous system, including the limbic system and reticular formation.
    • It has no affinity for 5HT1 receptors.

Option B: Zolpidem

  • Zolpidem, an imidazopyridine hypnotic structurally dissimilar to benzodiazepines, enhances the activity of GABA receptors via selective agonism at the benzodiazepine-1 (BZ1) receptor; the result is a decrease in neuronal excitability leading to sedative and hypnotic effects.
    • Because of its selectivity for the BZ1 receptor site over the BZ2 receptor site, zolpidem exhibits minimal anxiolytic, myorelaxant, and antiseizure properties (largely attributed to agonism at the BZ2 receptor site)

Option C: Cinnarizine

  • Cinnarizine is a calcium channel blocker used as an antiemetic agent. It has no anxiolytic or 5HT1 activity.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a complaint of fever and productive cough for the last 5 days. On examination, right-sided bronchial breaths are appreciated. A chest X-ray was ordered, which revealed right-sided consolidation. A diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia is made, and an antibiotic is prescribed. Which of the following antimicrobials stops protein synthesis by inhibition of translocation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Macrolides

  • Inhibition of protein synthesis occurs via binding to the 50S ribosomal RNA.
  • The binding site is near the peptidyltransferase centre, and peptide chain elongation (i.e., transpeptidation) is prevented by blocking the polypeptide exit tunnel.
  • Thereby, they inhibit translocation.

Option A: Aminoglycosides

  • Aminoglycosides bind to the 23S fraction of the 30S ribosomes and inhibit protein synthesis in at least three ways:  
  • Interference with the initiation complex of peptide formation  
  • Misreading of mRNA, which causes the incorporation of incorrect amino acids into the peptide and results in a nonfunctional protein  
  • The break-up of polysomes into nonfunctional monosomes.  
  • These activities occur more or less simultaneously, and the overall effect is irreversible and leads to cell death.

Option B: Tetracyclines

  • Tetracyclines bind reversibly to the 23S fraction of the 30S ribosome at the A site, blocking the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the acceptor site on the mRNA-ribosome complex. 
  • This prevents the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide.

Option D: Chloramphenicol

  • Chloramphenicol selectively inhibits protein synthesis in bacterial cells by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunits in the region of the A site involving the 23S ribosomal RNA.
  • Also inhibit peptide bond formation by blocking peptidyl tranferase.

questions.text: Which anti tuberculosis treatment drug can cause gout?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pyrazinamide

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an acid-fast bacillus that causes Tuberculosis (TB).
  • TB is an infectious disease that usually affects the lungs but can also affect other body parts.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Chronic cough
    • Fever
    • Bloody sputum
    • Weight loss
  • Diagnosis is based on Chest X-ray findings and sputum cultures.
  • Treatment of TB involves multidrug therapy using the following drugs:
    • Isoniazid
    • Ethambutol
    • Rifampicin
    • Pyrazinamide
    • Streptomycin
  • Pyrazinamide causes hyperuricemia and thus predisposes to gout.

Option A: Streptomycin

  • Adverse effects of streptomycin include:
    • Tinnitus
    • Vertigo
    • Ataxia
    • Nephrotoxicity
  • Streptomycin is not associated with gout.

Option B: Ethambutol

  • Adverse effects of ethambutol include:
    • Optic neuropathy
  • Ethambutol is not associated with gout.

Option C: Rifampicin

  • Adverse effects of rifampicin include:
    • Hepatotoxicity
    • Orange body fluids
  • Rifampicin is not associated with gout.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with multiple joint pains and morning stiffness lasting for an hour. He has been prescribed aspirin for pain alleviation. Which of the following statements is true about aspirin?

choices.text: In an afebrile patient acute overdose of aspirin produces hypothermia
Aspirin suppresses flushing associated with a large dose of nicotinic acid
Aspirin therapy prevents granulomatous lesions and cardiac complications of acute rheumatic fever
Long-term aspirin therapy increases the risk of developing colon cancer

questions.solution:
Option B: Aspirin suppresses flushing associated with a large dose of nicotinic acid

  • Roles of aspirin:
    • Niacin induces flushing through dermal Langerhans cells, where the activation of G protein-coupled receptors increases arachidonic acid and prostaglandins, such as prostaglandin D2, prostaglandin E2 leading to activation of prostaglandin D2, E2, and E4 receptors in the capillaries resulting in vasodilatation.
    • This is by preventing the prostaglandin formation, blocking the PG receptors or regulating the rate of niacin absorption.
    • Nicotinic acid can cause flushing due to the release of Prostaglandins. This premedication with aspirin decreases this complication.
    • Therefore, aspirin is used to prevent flushing due to nicotinic ingestion
    • Aspirin can cause hyperthermia in overdose. It decreases the risk of developing colon cancer.

Option A: In an afebrile patient, an acute overdose of aspirin produces hypothermia

  • Aspirin's direct results affect the respiratory centre causing hyperventilation. As a result, higher anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs due to the body's reaction to hyperventilation (due to kidneys producing more bicarbonate and eliminating more potassium). The acidosis and inhibition of the Krebs cycle build up lactate and pyruvate, causing the suppression and decoupling of oxidative phosphorylation. This will result in more heat being produced and hyperthermia.

Option C: Aspirin therapy prevents granulomatous lesions and cardiac complications of acute rheumatic fever

  • It does not prevent or alter disease duration in granulomatous lesions, nodules, cardiac complications, valvular defects or chorea.

Option D: Long-term aspirin therapy increases the risk of developing colon cancer

  • It is used in patients with familial colonic polyposis to suppress polyp formation and afford symptomatic relief.
  • It prevents colon cancer. This is because the incidence of colon cancer among regular aspirin users is much lower.
  • COX-2 overexpression is associated with cancer progression. Aspirin causes inhibition of the COX-2 enzyme and thus provides anti-cancer effects.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient with complaints of sore throat, cough, and fever from the last 3 days presents to the OPD. On examination, his throat is swollen red, and pus around the tonsils. The doctor sent his swab to the microbiology laboratory. Hemolytic colonies of Streptococcus pyogenes are obtained from the swab. Which toxin of streptococcus causes hemolysis around colonies?
questions.solution:
Option B: Streptolysin S

  • The patient is suffering from sore throat, cough, and fever. On examination, his throat is swollen red, and pus around the tonsils. Based on this history, this patient is most likely suffering from diphtheria.
  • Streptolysin S causes hemolysis around colonies.
Streptolysin ‘O’ Streptolysin ‘S’
Oxygen labile Oxygen stable
Hemolysis in reduced state only Hemolysis around Streptococcal colonies.
It cannot cause hemolysis on the surface of blood agar.  
  • DNA se/ Deoxyribonuclease/ Streptodornase :
  • Diagnostic use: Anti-DNase B > 300–350 units/ml is useful for the retrospective diagnosis of skin infections (pyoderma) and acute glomerulonephritis where ASO titre is low.
  • Hyaluronidase (spreading factor): Expressed by non-capsulated strains, such as M type 4 and 22.

Option A: Streptolysin O

  • It cannot cause hemolysis on the surface of blood agar.
  • Streptolysin O is a type of toxin produced by group A Streptococcus (GAS) bacteria.

Option C: Streptodornase

  • Diagnostic use: Anti-DNase B > 300–350 units/ml is useful for the retrospective diagnosis of skin infections (pyoderma) and acute glomerulonephritis where ASO titer is low.

Option D: Hyaluronidase

  • Hyaluronidase (spreading factor): Expressed by non-capsulated strains, such as M type 4 and 22.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother with complaints of failure to thrive, progressive muscular weakness, and poor head control. The mother states that she feeds the baby soy-based formula sweetened with honey. The baby is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Clostridium botulinum

  • This is a case of Floppy baby syndrome in which the patient presents with complaints of failure to thrive, poor head control and progressive muscular weakness.
  • It is caused due to C. botulinum.

Infant botulism/Floppy child syndrome

  • By ingesting contaminated food (usually honey) with spores of C. botulinum in children ≤ 1 year of age.
  • Spores germinate in the intestine, releasing the toxin.
  • Manifestations include:
    • Inability to suck and swallow.
    • Weakened voice.
    • Ptosis.
    • Floppy neck.
  • The botulinum toxin is the most potent toxin causing disease in humans.
  • Blocks the release of acetylcholine from motor nerve endings at the neuromuscular junctions leading to descending flaccid paralysis.
  • Other species that can cause botulism- are C. baratii, C. butyricum, and C. argentinense.

Other Options

Option B: Clostridium difficile

  • It causes pseudomembranous colitis, an advanced form of Clostridium difficile-associated disease (CDAD).

Option C: Clostridium perfringens

  • In clostridium perfringens, 13 major & minor toxins are present.
  • Toxins: Type A - E
  • Most infections are caused by Type A/α toxin.

Option D: Clostridium tetani

  • It produces the following toxins:
    • Tetanolysin
    • Tetanospasmin: presynaptic inhibition of glycine / GABA.

questions.text: A 23-years-old male comes to his family physician with complaints of a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans that exuded clear fluid under pressure for 5 days. He gives a history of having unprotected sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 2 weeks ago. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal enlarged and nontender inguinal lymph nodes in both groins. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

choices.text: Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge
Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option B: Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge

  • This is a case of syphilis in which the patient presents with complaints of painless, indurated ulcer on the glans that exuded clear fluid on pressure for 5 days.

  • The patient, in this case, had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 2 weeks ago.

  • On examination of the patient, there are enlarged and nontender inguinal lymph nodes in both groins.

  • Syphilis is caused by treponema pallidum.

  • T. pallidum can be seen from ulcer discharge by using Dark field microscopy.

  • Dark-field microscopy:-helpful for diagnosis early in the disease before the appearance of serum antibodies. T. pallidum is identified by its slender spiral structure and corkscrew motility

  • Direct fluorescent antibody staining for T. pallidum (DFA-TP-Sensitivity is 100%)

  • Silver impregnation method: Levaditi stain (for tissue section), Fontana stain (smear)

Other Options

Option A: Gram's stain of ulcer discharge

  • T. pallidum cannot be stained by Gram stain.

  • T. pallidum can be seen from ulcer discharge by using Dark field microscopy.

Option C: Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

  • Giemsa stain is also known as G-banding.

  • It is used to stain chromosomes and is often used to create a chromosome map.

  • It can identify chromosomal aberrations.

Option D: ELISA for HIV infection

  • The diagnosis of the above-mentioned case is syphilis which is caused by treponema pallidum.

  • So, there is no need to perform ELISA for HIV infection.

questions.text: A 40 year old patient was admitted to ICU. His condition deteriorated 5 days after putting on ventilator. X ray showed signs of pneumonia. On sample culture, growth of Acinetobacter was obtained. Which of the following is not true about Acinetobacter?
questions.solution:
Acinetobacter is an Obligate aerobe.

Features of Acinetobacter:

  • Gram negative coccobacilli
  • Obligate aerobe
  • Saprophytic (present in soil and water in environment)
  • Oxidase negative
  • ICU isolate
  • Recently identified as an important nosocomial pathogen causing several hospital outbreaks.
  • Multi drug resistant.

Leads to nosocomial infections like:

  • VAP (ventilator associated pneumonia)
  • CRBSI (Catheter related blood stream infections)
  • CAUTI (catheter associated urinary tract infection)

Causes of VAP:

Early onset VAP (within 4 days of mechanical ventilation) Late onset VAP (≥ 5 days after mechanical ventilation starts)
Pneumococcus Pseudomonas aeruginosa
H. influenzae Acinetobacter
MSSA (Methicillin sensitive S.aureus) E. coli
Klebsiella
MRSA (Methiciliin resistant S. aureus)

Clinical Pulmonary Infection Score (CPIS) used for ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP) :

Parameter (s) Score 0 Score 1 Score 2
Temperature (°C) 36.5°C & 38.4°C 38.5°C & 38.9°C 39°C & 36.4°C
Leukocytosis 4000 & 11,000 < 4000 & > 12,000
Tracheal aspirate None Non-purulent Purulent
Oxygenation (PaO2/FIO2 mmHg) > 250 or ARDS 250 & no ARDS
Chest radiograph No opacity Diffuse (patchy) opacity Localized opacity
Progressive radiological progression No radiological progression Radiological progression
Culture of tracheal aspirate Pathogenic bacteria light or no growth Pathogenic bacteria moderate of heavy growth
Culture – Gram stain Different morphology Same morphology as Gram stain

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presented to the hospital with complaints of headaches, nausea, and vomiting for 3 days. The patient is a known case of HIV-AIDS and has been on treatment for 2 years. The CD-4 count of the patient is 150/ μl. The patient was admitted, and after a complete evaluation, acute meningitis was suspected. Which of the following is the most probable/common pathogen that can be expected as a causative organism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cryptococcus neoformans

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans is a soil saprophyte commonly found in the faeces of pigeons and birds.
  • The fungus is the most common cause of meningitis in HIV-positive patients with a CD-4 count of less than 200/μl.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an oval, broad-budding yeast.
  • It has a thick polysaccharide capsule around it.
  • Indian ink staining of the CSF sample shows the presence of a thick capsule around the fungi.
  • Indian Ink staining: Image below

Option A: Staphylococcus saprophyticus

  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a gram-positive coccus.
  • It is coagulase-negative bacteria.
  • It is a common cause of urinary tract infections in sexually active young females.
  • It is not a cause of meningitis in HIV-positive patients.
  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a novobiocin-resistant pathogen.

Option B: Streptococcus agalactiae

  • Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive, catalase-negative, and facultative anaerobe.
  • This pathogen is the causative agent for neonatal meningitis and sepsis.
  • Infants can acquire infection from the maternal vagina during birth or from the environment.
  • The vertically transmitted infection causes neonatal meningitis and sepsis during the first week of life.
  • Infection contracted from the environment causes sepsis during the second to twelfth week of life.

Option D: Listeria monocytogenes

  • Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus.
  • Listeria monocytogenes show slow tumbling motility when grown at 25 degrees Celsius.
  • It causes meningitis and sepsis in neonates of infected mothers. The neonates may acquire the infection in utero or through the birth canal.
  • Individuals are infected with this pathogen by ingesting contaminated cheese and dairy products.
  • It can cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals but is a less common causative pathogen than Cryptococcus neoformans.

questions.text: A patient made a self-diagnosis of an athlete's foot and began using a product advertised on TV. The condition improved but did not clear, and the patient showed himself to a Dermatologist. A skin scraping was sent for culture, including culture for fungi. The fungal culture yielded a slow-growing colony, which produces abundant microconidia. Which of the following dermatophyte is the causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trichophyton  

  • Trichophyton causes superficial mycoses.
  • It mainly affects cutaneous tissues.
  • Humans and animals are natural reservoirs for this fungus.
  • Macroscopic examination of the trichophyton colonies shows powdery, waxy or velvety growths, with pigmentation characteristic of different species of this fungus.
  • Microscopic examination of trichophyton colonies shows microconidia and macroconidia.
  • Microconidia are abundant. They are arranged in clusters along the hyphae or borne on conidiophores.
  • Macroconidia are relatively scant. They are generally thin, elongated with blunt ends and have distinctive shapes in different species.
  •  Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of chronic, treatment-resistant lesions in humans.

Microconidia Trichophyton :

 

 

Macroconidia Trichophyton

 

 

 

Option B: Microsporum

  • Microsporum is a superficial dermatophyte.
  • The Microsporum genus has different anthropophilic, zoophilic and geophilic species.
  • Macroscopic examination of Microsporum colonies shows cotton-like, powdery, or velvety growths. Colonies show brown to white pigmentation.
  • Microconidia and macroconidia are seen on microscopic examination of Microsporum growths in a culture media.
  • Microconidia are relatively scanty.
  • Macroconidia of Microsporum fungus are large, multicellular, spindle-shaped structures. They are present singly on the ends of hyphae.

 

Macroconidia Microsporum:

 

Option C: Epidermophyton

  • Epidermophyton causes superficial mycoses of the skin and hair.
  • They are mainly anthropophilic fungi.
  • Epidermophyton colonies are powdery and produce greenish-yellow pigments.
  • This fungus does not produce microconidia.
  • Macroconidia seen on microscopic examination of the cultures are multicellular, pear-shaped, and typically arranged in clusters.

 

Macroconidia Epidermophyton:

Option D: Trichosporon

  • Trichosporon is a genus of anamorphic fungi.
  • This fungus is typically found in the soil.
  • White piedra is a condition caused by the proliferation of trichophyton fungus in the hair.
  • This genus has no sexual states.
  • Microscopically, trichosporon species have characteristic yeast cells germinating to produce hyaline hyphae.
  • Hyaline hyphae disarticulate at the septa. Hyphal compartments act as arthroconidia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with fever, chills, nausea, diarrhea, and muscle aches. The patient was admitted and blood samples were sent to the lab for examination. On blood smear examination, the finding shown in the image was seen.



Which of the following statement is true about the finding shown in the image?

choices.text: Multiple ring forms of P. falciparum are seen
All stages of parasitemia are seen in this peripheral blood showing P. vivax
Schizonts of P. vivax are seen in the picture
The above image shows P. malariae infection

questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple ring forms of P. falciparum are seen

  • In the above-given case, the presence of fever with chills, fatigue, muscle ache, jaundice, splenomegaly, and smear shows infected RBCs (ring form) with multiple rings are suggestive of the diagnosis of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Features of Plasmodium falciparum:

  • Normal size RBC

  • All RBCs affected

  • Schizont stage absent

  • Accole forms present

  • Multiple rings are seen.

P. malariae and vivax infected RBC shows single ring in RBC.

Option B: All stages of parasitemia are seen in this peripheral blood showing P. vivax

  • All stages of parasitemia are seen in this peripheral blood showing P.falciparum.

  • The crescent-shaped gametocytes can be seen on blood smear examination.

Option C: Schizonts of P. vivax are seen in the picture

  • Schizonts of P. vivax cannot be seen in the picture.

  • Schizonts of P. vivax are large in size containing 12-24 merozoites, coalesced pigment, yellowish-brown in colour, and may fill RBC.

Option D: The above image shows P. malariae infection

  • The above image shows the P. falciparum infection.

  • The image shows the ring from RBCs which indicates the P. falciparum infection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the OPD with abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 110/70mmHg with a regular pulse rate of 70 beats per minute. A stool analysis is requested for examination in the microbiology laboratory, revealing the egg floats on a saturated salt solution. Identify the organism present in the patient whose egg is shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Option C: H.Nana

  • The egg of Hymenolepis nana is shown in the image above, and Hymenolepis diminuta infections are most often asymptomatic.
  • Heavy infections with H. nana cause weakness, headaches, anorexia, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. Polar filaments with central hooklets feature the non-Bile stained egg of hymenolepis nana.
  • Praziquantel and niclosamide are the mainstays of treatment. Infective form: Eggs are ingested with contaminated food and water.                                                                                  

Option A: Ascaris

  • Eggs with rugosity.
  • Fertilised egg of Ascaris

  • Unfertilised egg of Ascaris

Option B: Enterobius vermicularis

  • Planoconvex egg having tadpole-like larvae.

Option D: Ancylostoma duodenale

  • Eggs with a thin transparent shell having 4-8 blastomeres, non-bile stained

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with complaints of fever, cough, back pain, runny nose, loss of taste, and shortness of breath. He was a suspected case of COVID -19. There is no sign of clubbing or oedema on physical examination. There is no history of smoking. The resident doctor recommended antibody testing for the patient. Antibody-secreting plasma cells are derived from which cells?
questions.solution:
Option B : B cells

Plasma cells are derived from B cells.

Plasma cells:

  • Plasma cells originate from terminally differentiated B cells.

  • Plasma cells are oval or egg-shaped structures characterized by a stellate (star-like pattern) nucleus, non-staining golgi, and basophilic cytoplasm.

  • Plasma cells produce and secrete all the classes of immunoglobulins into the fluids around the cells.

Option A: T cells

  • T cells are derived from stem cells in the bone marrow and differentiate into helper cytotoxic or regulatory T cells.
  • T cells are part of the immune system and attack specific antigens to protect the body from infections.

Option C: Macrophages

  • Macrophages are derived from monocytes
  • Macrophages are important for the detection and phagocytosis of microorganisms.
  • It also presents antigens to T cells to initiate inflammation.

Option D: Neutrophils

  • Neutrophils are the most abundant type of granulocytes.
  • These cells lead the immune system response.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl was admitted to the infectious disease hospital with a provisional diagnosis of rabies. What is the shape of this virus?
questions.solution:
The shape of this virus is bullet shaped.

Structure of Rabies Virus:

    • Rabies virus is bullet-shaped 180 x 75 nm, with one end rounded or conical and the other planar or concave.
    • Rabies is a RNA virus.

Shapes of various Viruses:

    • Rabies - Bullet. Refer to the image below.

  • Ebola virus - Filamentous. Refer to the image below.

  • Poxvirus - Brick
  • Tobacco mosaic virus - Rod shaped
  • Adeno & Picorna, Reo, Retrovirus - Icosahedral
  • Orthomyxovirus- Spherical or Elongated
  • Paramyxovirus - Pleomorphic
  • Coronavirus - Pleomorphic. Refer to the image below.

questions.text: What is it called when a victim was strangled with an elbow around the neck?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mugging

  • Strangulation is caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow or knee of the assailant.

Option A: Garroting

  • Garroting: Strangulation is caused by compression of the neck by a ligature which is quickly tightened by twisting it with a lever (rod, stick or ruler) known as Spanish windlass, which results in a sudden loss of consciousness and collapse.

Option C: Bansdola

  • Bansdola: A bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. Both ends are tied with a rope due to which the victim is squeezed to death.

Option D: Burking

  • It is a combination of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
  • One man does smothering while another seating over his chest causing traumatic asphyxia.

questions.text: This " knockdown gas", responsible for numerous cases of toxic exposure in the petroleum industry is fatal in concentrations over 500-1000 ppm, revealing a bluish-green stain on post-mortem examination. Prolonged exposure in lower concentrations causes rhinitis to acute respiratory failure. Which among the following is being described?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hydrogen sulphide

  • It is a colorless, heavy, flammable gas, which on Post mortem staining will reveal a Bluish-green discoloration.
  • Hydrogen sulphide in combination with CO2 and methane formed in sewers is known as SEWER GAS.
  • It is also referred to as the “knockdown gas” because inhalation of high concentrations can cause immediate loss of consciousness and death.

Option B: Carbon monoxide

  • Carbon monoxide: Cherry red discoloration

Option C: Cyanide

  • Cyanide: Bright Red/ Brick red; Pink

Option D: Phosphorus

  • Phosphorus: Dark brown/yellow discoloration

questions.text: Identify the image given below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Nigella sattiva

  • Nigella sativa is a small black seed that has been used for centuries in herbal medicine.

Option A: Opium

  • Opium (afim) is the dried juice of the poppy (Papaver somniferum).
  • Classification:
    • Natural: Morphine, codeine.
    • Semi-synthetic: Heroin, hydromorphone, oxymorphone, oxycodone.
    • Synthetic: Meperidine, methadone, levarphanol tartrate, paregoric, diphenoxylate, fentanyl, propoxyphene.
  • The contact of morphine with the skin of sensitive persons may cause erythema, urticaria and itching dermatitis.
  • When opium is taken by mouth, symptoms begin within half hour. If the drug is injected, its action is noted within 3 or 4 minutes. It first stimulates, then depresses and finally paralyses the nerve centres.

Option C: Datura

  • Dhatura, a member of the Solanaceae family, the fruits are spherical and have sharp spines known as thorn-apple.
  • All parts of these plants are poisonous - Fruit, Flowers and Seeds (highest concentrations of alkaloids are found in roots and seeds).
  • Active Principles: The plant contains belladonna alkaloids whose primary actions are anticholinergic.
    • Hyoscine (scopolamine). The major active principle is hyoscine.
    • Hyoscyamine
    • Atropine

Option D: Tropican Black Cana

  • Botanical Name: Canna ‘Tropicanna Black’
  • An extraordinary variety with foliage that is a magnificent combination of dark purple and black shades; crowned with dazzling scarlet-orange blooms from spring to fall; excellent display when massed along borders, or as a garden accent.

Learning Objective

  • Nigella sativa is a small black seed that has been used for centuries in herbal medicine.
  • Nigella sativa also known as black caraway, black cumin, nigella or kalonji.

Nigella sativa seed

Elwendia persica

questions.text: A person was admitted to the emergency ward with injuries sustained at a protest site. The person was one among the crowd that was dispersed by the police using lathi charge. Which among the following is least likely to be seen secondary to being hit by a lathi?
questions.solution:
Option D: Incised wound

  • Lathi is a blunt weapon. It cannot produce an incised wound, which is a sharp force injury.

Option A: Fissured fracture

  • A blow with a blunt weapon or fist often fractures the nasal bones, and also ethmoid bone with radiating fractures into the supra-orbital plates, if the force is severe. A blow with a blunt weapon may cause fracture of the maxilla and malar bones. Pulping of the face may result from striking with a heavy stone. The mandible is fractured by a blow from a fist, stick or by a fall from a height. A heavy blow on the jaw drives the condyles against the base of the skull, producing a fissured fracture.

Option B: Contusion

  • Blunt force injuries: Abrasion, contusion, laceration & fracture.
  • Bruise/Contusion is the extravasation of blood in the subcutaneous/sub-epithelial tissues due to rupture of blood vessels, usually capillaries, as a result of blunt force injury or pressure.

Option C: Incised - looking lacerated wound

  • Lacerations produced without excessive skin crushing may have relatively sharp margins. Blunt force on areas where the skin is close to bone, and the subcutaneous tissues are scanty, may produce a wound which by linear splitting of the tissues (as the skin is easily stretched during impact), may look like incised wound.
  • The sites are the scalp, eyebrows, cheek bones, lower jaw, iliac crest, perineum, and shin. A wound produced by a fall on the knee or elbow with the limb flexed, and by a broken glass or sharp stone also simulates incised wound.

questions.text: Which of the following is Nysten’s law?

choices.text: Cadaveric rigidity does not appear in living people
Cadaveric rigidity appears faster in older and the young than in the middle age
Cadaveric rigidity occurs in men earlier than in the women
Cadaveric rigidity affect successively the masticatory muscles, those of the face and the neck, those of the trunk and arms and finally those of the lower limbs

questions.solution:
Option D: Cadaveric rigidity affects successively the masticatory muscles, those of the face and the neck, those of the trunk and arms, and finally those of the lower limbs

  • Nysten’s law: Rigor mortis affects first the muscles of the jaw, followed by those of the face and neck, then muscles of the trunk and arms, and lastly the legs and feet.

Option A: Cadaveric rigidity does not appear in living people

  • Though Cadaveric rigidity does not appear in living people, it is not Nystein's rule.

Option B: Cadaveric rigidity appears faster in older and the young than in the middle age

  • Cadaveric rigidity absent in fetuses < 2 months of gestation [IUL]
  • Cadaveric rigidity is not seen in the fetus as the muscle/ protein development is absent [it occurs after 2 months]

Option C: Cadaveric rigidity occurs in men earlier than in the women

  • Cadaveric rigidity occurs in women earlier than in men because of the muscle bulk.

questions.text: In cases of examination of victims of sexual offence, spray of toluidine blue is used for

choices.text: Identification of clotted blood on injuries

questions.solution:
Option D: Recent micro injuries

  • TBD (Toluidine Blue Dye) was used to identify micro-tears or abrasions, especially in the posterior fourchette, that is a common site of trauma from intercourse.

questions.text: All of the following are investigator bias except?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Hawthorne bias

  • The Hawthorne effect refers to people's tendency to behave differently when they become aware that they are being observed. As a result, what is observed may not represent “normal” behavior, threatening the internal and external validity of your research.
  • Subject bias: Where error is done by study subjects for example.
    • Recall bias- Due to faulty recall of information by study subjects
    • Hawthorne bias- Study subjects may alter their behavior upon observation
    • Apprehension bias- Systemic alterations in the parameter of interest due to apprehension

Other options

Option A: Interviewer bias 

  • Interviewer bias happens in case-control studies where the interviewer knows about the disease status of the person and probes more for exposure amongst cases as compared to controls.
  • Allowing equal time for interviews can take care of interviewer bias to some extent.

Option B: Misclassification bias

  • The subjects are misclassified with respect to their status, risk factor, and outcome.
  • Investigatory bias: Interviewer bias, selection bias, misclassification bias.
  • The misclassification bias is a type of investigator bias.

Option D: Pygmalion bias

  • Pygmalion bias: Increase motivation by teachers results in increased marks of students.
  • It is a type of Investigator bias: Selection bias.

questions.text: Clinical trials are research studies performed on people that are aimed at evaluating a medical, surgical, or behavioral intervention. Maximum tolerated dose of a new drug is evaluated in which of the following phase?
questions.solution:
Option A: Phase 1

  • Phase 1 clinical trial:
    • Used to evaluate the Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of a new drug.
    • Healthy human volunteers are used.
    • It is done for safety and non-toxicity.

Option B: Phase 2

  • Maximum drug failure in the drug is seen in Phase 2.
  • Phase 2 is done on patients to know the efficacy of the drug.

Option C: Phase 3

  • Phase 3 is RCT because it has a controlled or comparison group.
  • Phase 3 is the most important phase of the trial.
  • A comparison with an existing drug in the market is done.
  • The new drug is launched in the market after phase 3.

Option D: Phase 4

  • Post-marketing surveillance is done under phase 4 of the trial.
  • Phase 4 is the longest trial.
  • Long-term & rare side effects can be identified. 
  • Suppose there is a fatal disease like cancer in the end stage and someone discovered a new drug anti-cancer for that and that drug has shown toxicity in animals.

questions.text: Immunity is defined as the body's ability to protect itself from an infectious disease. Active and passive immunity should be given together in all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Measles

  • The measles vaccine (provides active immunity) efficacy is reduced by concurrent administration of measles immunoglobulin (gives passive immunity).
  • The measles vaccine alone gives quite a good (immunity) level of protection.
  • Hence, we avoid giving Measles Immunoglobulin along with the measles vaccine.

Option A: Tetanus

  • Tetanus vaccination can be given together with Ig.
  • Vaccine: TT (Tetanus toxoid) given as DPT
    o 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks
    o 1st Booster: 16-24 months
    o 2nd Booster: 5 years of age
    o TT at 10 yrs of age
    o TT at 16 yrs of age
    o Pregnant females

Option B: Rabies

  • For rabies, vaccination & Ig can be given together.
  •  For immediate protection
    1. HRIg (Human rabies Ig)
    2. ERIg (Equine rabies Ig)
  • Vaccines approved:
  • 1. PCECV (purified chick embryo cell vaccine)
    2. PV (purified Vero cell rabies vaccine)

Option D: Hepatitis B

  • Hep B vaccination can be given together with Ig.
  • Side effects of the Hep B vaccine include hypersensitivity, and shock.
  • 3 doses: (6, 10, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at home or (0, 6, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at an institute.

questions.text: A vaccination drive was organized by the PHC in rural India for the village children. All of the following are contraindications to Pertussis containing vaccine except?

choices.text: Anaphylactic reaction to the previous dose

questions.solution:
Option C: Egg allergy

  • Yellow fever vaccine is contraindicated in Egg allergy, not Pertussis.
  • Epilepsy, anaphylactic shock on the previous dose, and progressive encephalopathy are CI to pertussis. HHE (Hypotensive Hyporesponsive Episode) & persistent inconsolable crying are adverse effects of the pertussis vaccine.

Option A: Uncontrolled epilepsy

  • Evolving neurological condition (e.g. uncontrolled epilepsy or progressive encephalopathy). Children with this condition shouldn't receive the whole-cell pertussis component of the vaccine.

Option B: Anaphylactic reaction to the previous dose

  • A further dosage of a specific vaccination should not be administered if the patient has an anaphylactic reaction to a previous dose, which is a real contraindication to further immunization with the relevant antigen.

Option D: Progressive encephalopathy

  • The development of neurological illnesses, such as uncontrolled epilepsy or progressive encephalopathy, are contraindications for receiving the pertussis vaccine.

questions.text: All the following are examples of Health promotion, except?
questions.solution:
Answer
