Option C: Chemoprophylaxis

  • Primary prevention can be defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur".
  • It includes Health Promotion & Specific protection.
  • Chemoprophylaxis/vaccines fall under Specific protection.

Other options

Option A: Stop smoking

  • Decreased salt intake, stopping smoking, and installation of sanitary latrine comes under Health promotion.

Option B: Installation of sanitary latrine

  • Installation of sanitary latrines comes under Health promotion.

Option D: Decreased salt intake

  • Decreased salt intake also comes under Health promotion.

questions.text: If two screening tests are applied together, which of the following will be there?
questions.solution:
Option A: Increased sensitivity and decreased specificity

  • A population/person is subjected to two screening tests at the same time (applied together) it is called screening tests in parallel.
  • In this, combined values of:
    • Sensitivity increases
    • Specificity decreases
    • Positive predictive value (PPV) decreases
    • Negative predictive value (NPV) increases

Other options

Option B: Increased specificity and decreased sensitivity

  • The specificity is increased and sensitivity is decreased in screening tests in series.
  • A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test; 2nd screening test is applied only in those in which the 1st screening test is positive.

Option C: Increased sensitivity and increased specificity

  • Increased sensitivity and increased specificity are not accurate to screening tests in parallel.
  • The sensitivity is increased and the specificity is decreased in screening tests in parallel.

Option D: Decreased sensitivity and decreased specificity

  • Decreased sensitivity and decreased specificity are not accurate to screening tests in parallel.
  • The sensitivity is increased and the specificity is decreased in screening tests in parallel.

questions.text: A rural village PHC reported many cases of perinatal mortality. All of the following are the Intranatal causes of Perinatal mortality, except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Antepartum hemorrhage

  • Antepartum hemorrhage is an antenatal cause of Perinatal mortality.
  • The common causes of antepartum hemorrhage are placenta previa and placenta abruption.
  • Antenatal causes of perinatal mortality
    • Maternal disease
    • Pelvic disease
    • Antepartum Hemorrhage

Option A: Birth injuries

  • Birth injuries usually occur as a result of poorly managed delivery.
  • It is an intranatal cause of Perinatal mortality.

Option B: Birth asphyxia

  • A poorly managed labour and delivery may lead to birth asphyxia.
  • It is an intranatal cause of Perinatal mortality.

Option D: Obstructed labor

  • Obstructed labor is an intranatal cause of Perinatal mortality.
  • Obstructed labor is the result of around 8% of maternal death.
  • Obstructed labor: No progress of labor in spite of good Uterine contractions (i.e. there is no descent of the Presenting Part).

questions.text: In a study, every fourth student is selected in a class while sampling. Interpret the type of sampling.
questions.solution:
Option B: Systematic Random Sampling

  • Based on sampling fraction: Every K unit is chosen in the population list, where K is chosen by sampling interval.
  • Sampling interval (K): Total number of units in population / Total Number of units in the sample.

Option A: Simple random sampling

  • Every unit of the population has an equal chance of being selected.
  • Applicable for small, homogenous, and readily available populations.

Option C: Stratified random sampling

  • The division of a population into smaller subgroups known as strata is a key component of the sampling technique known as stratified random sampling.
  • In stratified random sampling, also known as stratification, the strata are created based on the shared traits or features of the members, such as wealth or level of education.

Option D: Cluster random sampling

  • Applicable when units of the population are natural groups or clusters.
  • Use of CRS in India: Evaluation of immunization coverage.
  • Limitation: Clusters cannot be compared with each other.

questions.text:
Match the following health committees with their proposed social health concepts:




Health committee

Social health concept


A – Bhore committee
I – Comprehensive health care


B – Balwant Rai committee
II – Multipurpose Worker concept


C – Jungalwalla committee
III – Integration of health services


D – Kartar singh committee
IV – Panchayati Raj institutions
questions.solution:
Option B: A-I, B-IV, C-III, D-II

A. Bhore committee: Comprehensive healthcare concept

  • Bhore Committee: Health Survey & Development Committee.

B. Balwant Rai committee: Panchayati Raj institutions

  • Balwant Rai Mehta Committee: Recommended 3-tier rural Health infrastructure "Panchayat - Panchayat samiti - Zilla Parishad".

C. Jungalwalla Committee: Integration of Health Services

  • Jungalwalla Committee (1967): Also known as ‘Committee on Integration of Health Services.

D. Kartar Singh Committee: Multipurpose Worker Concept

  • Kartar Singh Committee (1973): Also known as ‘Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning’.

questions.text: The National TB Programme (NTP) was launched by the Government of India in 1962 in the form of a District TB Centre model involved with BCG vaccination and TB treatment. Which among the following is the new RNTCP software online to monitor the TB control program?
questions.solution:
Option A: NIKSHAY

  • NIKSHAY (Ni= End, Kshay= TB) is the web-enabled patient management system for TB control under the Revised National Tuberculosis Programme (RNTCP).
  • It is developed and maintained by the Central TB Division (CTD), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India, in collaboration with the National Informatics Centre (NIC), and the World Health Organization Country Office for India.
  • Nikshay is used by health functionaries at various levels across the country both in the public and private sector, to register cases under their care, order various types of tests from Labs across the country, record treatment details, monitor treatment adherence, and transfer cases between care providers.
  • It also functions as the National TB Surveillance System and enables reporting of various surveillance data to the Government of India.

Option B: NISCHAY

  • The Government of India has made the pregnancy test kit "Nischay" available across the country. 
  •  There are additional test kits on the market. ASHA or other link workers are given the kit, and the women should get appropriate advice regarding the test's outcome.

Option C: e-DOTS

  • A case-based web application called Nikshay is being developed by the Central TB Division in association with the National Informatics Center.
  • Countries, particularly those with a high TB burden, created the fundamentals necessary for offering high-quality TB diagnosis and treatment through the implementation of the DOTS strategy (1994–2005) and the Stop TB Strategy (2006–2015). 

Option D: None of the above

  • This is not the appropriate answer to the above-given question.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to draw some study designs. Identify the study design given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option D - Nested case-control study

  • The given image depicts a Nested case-control study.
  • Nested case-control study:
  • - Type of cohort Study
  • Temporality → forward-looking study
  • Only done in
    • New & Rare diseases
    • If Diagnostic tests are very Expensive.
  • It is a small case-control study that is nested in a big cohort study.

Other options

Option A - Cross-sectional study

  • Cross-sectional study:
    • Aka Snapshot study/ Prevalence study (as prevalence is calculated).
    • Done at point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
    • Based on primary data.
    • Can't calculate the strength of association.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study

  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of a prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.

Option C - Case-control, study

  • Case-control study is better for rare diseases.
  • Case-control study has 2 groups
    1. Cases: Having the disease
    2. Controls: They are comparison groups not having the disease
  • We ask about the history of the same exposure in both groups & then compare both groups.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to prepare charts on various programmes and services to create awareness among the village population. Which of the following is true about the Services shown in the Photograph given below?

choices.text: ‘Heart’ of the system is ASHA worker
1 Anganwadi centre is established per 400-800 population in Plains

questions.solution:
Option B: 1 Anganwadi centre is established per 400-800 population in Plains

  • Given image depicts ICDS: Integrated child development services (1975).
  • 1 Anganwadi centre is established per 400-800 population in Plains, 300-800 in hills.

Option A: Heart’ of the system is ASHA worker

  • Heart of ICDS are Anganwadi workers.

Option C: Functional unit is ‘District’

  • Functional unit is Community development block.

Option D: Free OPD care is given

  • ICDS provides an integrated package of services: Supplementary nutrition, Immunization, Health check-up, Medical referral services, Nutrition and health education for women, Non-formal education for children aged 3-6 years, and pregnant and nursing mothers in rural, urban and tribal areas.

Learning Objective

Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Scheme:

  • Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS), 1975.
  • ICDS aims at providing services to preschool children in an integrated manner so as to ensure the proper growth and development of children in rural, tribal, and slum areas.
  • ICDS is one of the world’s largest programmes for early childhood development.

Beneficiaries

Services
  • Children (0-6 year)
  • Pregnant & lactating female
  • 15-49 years female
  • 11-48 years females
  • Non formal pre-school education
  • Health education
  • Immunization
  • Family planning services
  • Referral services
  • Free food supplementation
    • Calories - 1/3rd of daily requirement
    • Proteins - 1/2of daily requirement

questions.text: Subject bias is the tendency of the subject or participant in a study to react, either consciously or unconsciously which impacts the results. All of the following are Subject biases except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Selection bias

  • Selection bias is a type of Investigator bias.
  • Selection bias- Groups compared are differentially susceptible to the outcome of interest

Other options

Option A: Recall bias

  • Recall bias is a subject bias.
  • Recall bias- Due to faulty recall of information by study subjects.

Option C: Hawthorne bias

  • Hawthorne effect (Cohort study) and Recall bias (Case-control study) are types of Subject bias.
  • Hawthorne bias- Study subjects may alter their behavior upon observation

Option D: None of the above

  • Subject bias: Where error is done by study subjects for example.
    • Recall bias- Due to faulty recall of information by study subjects
    • Hawthorne bias- Study subjects may alter their behavior upon observation
    • Apprehension bias- Systemic alterations in the parameter of interest due to apprehension.

questions.text: A patient from a rural village presented to the PHC with nausea, vomiting, a blue line on gums, wrist/foot drops, pallor, and colic. Which of the following poison can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Inorganic Lead

  • Nausea, vomiting, the blue line on gums, wrist/foot drops, pallor, and colic are the features of inorganic lead poisoning.
  • A: Anaemia
  • B: Burtonian line/Basophilic stippling, Bone lines
  • C: Colic, Constipation (dry bellyache)
  • D: Drop (wrist/Foot drop) - Lead palsy
  • E: Encephalopathy
  • F: Facial pallor (earliest sign)
  • G: Gout (saturnine gout)
  • H: Hypertension
  • I: Impotence

Option A: Mercury

  • Acute exposure to elemental mercury vapor may produce corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea. It may progress to pulmonary edema and fibrosis. Sometimes, manifestations similar to Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) are seen especially in children.
  • Fatal dose: 1-4 g of mercuric chloride; 10–60 mg/kg of methyl mercury and 10 mg/m³ of mercury vapor.
  • Fatal period: 3-5 days.
  • Chronic Mercury Poisoning (Hydrargyrism): This may result from (1) continuous accidental absorption b) the workers, (2) excessive therapeutic use, (3) recovery from a large dose, and (4) if the ointment is used as an external application for a long time.

Option B: Arsenic

  • Skin symptoms: Usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation).

Option C: Organic lead

  • Insomnia, Mental confusion, Headache, Delirium, and Encephalopathy are clinical manifestations due to Organic lead poisoning.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was explaining SAFE strategy to the village population on village health day. The SAFE strategy has been developed for the control of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Trachoma

  • WHO has recommended the ‘SAFE strategy’ for the global elimination of trachoma:
    • Surgery
    • Antibiotic use
    • Facial cleanliness
    • Environmental improvement

Option A: Onchocerciasis

  • Ocular disease not seen in India: Onchocerciasis
  • Black Fly (Simulium) is a vector for Onchocerciasis (River blindness). Simulium is also known as ‘White socks’.

Option C: Refractive error

  • The major causes of Low Vision in India are
    • Cataract (77%) is the MCC of Low Vision in India.
    • Refractive Error (19%).

Option D: Ocular trauma

  • Ocular trauma can be minor or severe, even resulting in loss of vision. Injury to the eye is caused by blunt, sharp, or chemical trauma.
  • General symptoms of ocular trauma include eye hemorrhage, progressive loss of vision, pain, diplopia (double vision), eye flashers or floaters (flashes of light or small dots or circles in the field of vision), misshapen pupil or iris, non-reactive pupil, or proptosis (bulging eyes).

questions.text: Polyunsaturated fatty acids are fatty acids that contain more than one double bond in their backbone. The highest percentage of polyunsaturated fatty acids is present in?
questions.solution:
Option B: Soya bean oil

Polyunsaturated fatty acids:

  • Fatty acids that contain more than one double bond in their backbone are called polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA).
  • The richest source of PUFA is Safflower oil > Sunflower oil > Soya bean oil.
  • Hence, among the given options, a high amount of PUFA is found in soya bean oil.

Extra points:

  • Coconut oil is the richest source of saturated fatty acid.
  • Coconut oil is also the richest source of Medium chain fatty acids.

Option A: Groundnut oil

  • The PUFA content present in groundnut oil is 32.
  • The richest source of PUFA is Safflower oil > Sunflower oil > Soya bean oil.

Option C: Margarine

  • Margarine is not the richest source of polyunsaturated fatty acids.

Option D: Palm oil

  • The PUFA content present in palm oil is 11.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital emergency with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and dizziness on exertion while working in the backyard. He had a history of palpitations. On physical examination, there is an added sound after the second heart sound, crackles in the lungs, blood pressure of 80/60 mm Hg and pulse of 150 beats per minute. An ECG tracing of this patient is shown in the image below. Which of the following would be the best management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: DC shock 25-50 J

  • An atrial flutter is a form of supraventricular tachycardia. It results due to a re-entry circuit within the right atrium. The atrial rate ranges around 300 per minute (200-400).
  • The AV conduction ratio governs the ventricular rate. The most common ratio is 2:1, with higher degree blocks causing 3:1 or 4:1 blocks.
  • ECG shows atrial flutter with a 2:1 block. It occurs as an anticlockwise flutter. The inverted flutter waves in II, III and aVF occur at 300 beats per minute.
  • The upright flutter waves in V1 simulate the P waves
  • This results in a ventricular rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • The PR interval is 200 msec (5 small squares) and is constant throughout the strip.
  • Since the patient is in acute LVF, beta blockers are contraindicated.
  • Since the patient's circulation is compromised, Cardioversion ( DC shock 25-50 J) is indicated.

other options

Option A: Esmolol

  • Esmolol is a cardioselective beta blocker that is used for nodal arrhythmias. However, the use of beta-blockers is contraindicated in patients with acute left ventricular failure (such as this patient) due to further loss of cardiac output.

Option B: Ibutilide

  • Ibutilide is used for rhythm control, but at the moment, prompt treatment is warranted using cardioversion to stabilise the patient hemodynamically.

Option C: Digoxin

  • Digoxin is not an answer because it is a pro-arrhythmogenic drug and takes time to achieve therapeutic levels.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents with severe chest pain and breathlessness after coming back from cremation grounds due to the death of her husband. ECG shows S.T. elevation in the precordial leads, most noticeably in V2-V3. Troponin T and Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are mildly elevated. Invasive coronary angiography shows completely normal coronary arteries. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrates apical akinesis and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy most commonly affects elderly women.
  • The condition is caused by an extremely stressful physical or emotional event.
  • Angiography is normal despite all findings of Myocardial Infarction (MI)
  • Apical Akinesia and low ejection fraction both pointing towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • It can cause cardiogenic shock, and death can occur
  • Treatment is an Intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP)

Option A: Anxiety

  • In the given cause, apical Akinesia and low ejection fraction point towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, so anxiety could not be the cause.

Option B: Septal myocardial infarction

  • In the above scenario, there is no obstruction of the coronary arteries, and the echocardiogram demonstrates findings significantly associated with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Coronary artery spasm

  • Coronary artery spasms would be self-resolving, and the echocardiographic findings are not seen in the cases of artery spasms.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought with short stature, a short-webbed neck and widely spaced nipples suggestive of a chromosomal abnormality, and is subsequently confirmed by karyotyping. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the cardiovascular anomaly that is most likely present in this child?
questions.solution:
Option C: Coarctation of Aorta

  • This child has the typical clinical presentation of Turner’s syndrome: short stature, short webbed neck and broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • The associated cardiac anomaly in such patients is coarctation of the aorta (COA) and a bicuspid aortic valve.
  • MC CHD in turner syndrome: Bicuspid aortic valve (50%) > Coarctation of the aorta (30%)
  • Physical findings of COA include upper extremity hypertension and a delay in the radio-femoral pulse.

Option A: Atrial septal defect

  • Atrial Septal Defect is not associated with Turner syndrome
  • Syndromes Associated With ASD
    1. Pierre Robin Sequence
    2. TAR [Thrombocytopenia Absent Radius] Syndrome
    3. Fetal Alcohol syndrome
    4. Ehler Danlos Syndrome
    5. Down Syndrome
    6. Holt-Oram syndrome
    7. Ellisvan Creveld Syndrome
    8. Rubinstein Taybi syndrome

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • It is not associated with Turner syndrome
  • Most common congenital cyanotic heart disease in children
  • 4 components
    • Large, nonrestricted VSD 
    • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOT) or pulmonary stenosis(infundibular>valvular)
    • Overriding of the aorta
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus

  • Ductus arteriosus connects the aorta to the pulmonary artery
  • Hypoxia and prematurity predispose to PDA

questions.text: A 34 year old female comes with complaints of diarrhoea for a past few months. She says her stools are occasionally bloody. Which among the following extra-intestinal manifestations of IBD correlate with bowel disease activity?
questions.solution:
Option C: Peripheral arthritis

Non-intestinal manifestations are similar for both CD and UC.

Dermatologic manifestations

  • Erythema nodosum seen with acute flares.
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum (UC > CD)

Joint manifestations

  • Peripheral arthritis correlates with exacerbations of bowel disease
  • central arthritis (ankylosing spondylitis or sacroiliitis)

Ocular complications

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Episcleritis
  • Uveitis

Hepatobiliary complications

  • Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones (CD > UC)
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (UC >> CD)

Renal complications

  • Kidney stones (CD > UC)
  • Uric acid stones also occur with increased frequency in CD


Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum

  • It is one of the findings in IBD, especially UC.
  • However, it does not correlate with disease activity

Option B: Erythema Nodosum

  • Erythema nodosum does not correlate with disease activity.
     

Option D: Primary sclerosing cholangitis

  • PSC is associated with UC.
  • However, it does not correlate with disease activity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents in the emergency department with complaints of palpitation and tremors. Symptoms occurred when he took an uncontrolled dose of iodine accidentally. He has been diagnosed with iodine deficiency hypothyroidism for 10 years. The patient's heart rate is 105 beats/min, and her blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. On examination, he is sweating profusely. After administration of supplemental iodine to subjects in an endemic area of iodine deficiency, hyperthyroidism occurs through which of the following phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Option B: Jod-Basedow effect

  • The Job-Basedow effect is hyperthyroidism following administration of iodine or iodide, either as a dietary supplement or as a contrast medium.
  • This phenomenon is iodine-induced hyperthyroidism due to an increase in the process of iodine trapping due to the increased availability of daily iodine in micro-dosages over many years.
  • In contrast, the Wolf Chaikoff effect is hypothyroidism due to a decrease in iodine trapping due to exposure to mega dosages of iodine in blood circulation.

Option A: Wolf-Chaikoff effect

  • It is an auto-regulatory phenomenon that transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification and the release of thyroid hormones due to excess iodine.
  • It is an effective means of rejecting larger quantities of iodine and preventing thyroid hormone production.
  • The Wolff-chaikoff effect causes hypothyroidism in a patient with hyperthyroidism (Grave's disease) after the excess iodine infusion.
  • There is a decrease in T3 and T4 synthesis in the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.
  • It is specially used as a treatment plan against thyroid storm.
  • The normal patient can escape from this phenomenon.
  • But hyperthyroid patient persists in this phenomenon.

Option C: Cork effect

  • In the Pemberton manoeuvre, both arms are raised and touch the sides of the head for some time.
  • It causes an increase in pressure in the thoracic inlet and narrows the aperture, resulting in obstruction of the thoracic inlet by the thyroid.
  • Increased pressure in the venous system results in facial plethora.
  • It is used for retrosternal goitre examination.
  • It has been known as the cork effect.

Option D: Thyrotoxicosis factitia

  • Ingestion of excess thyroid hormone or thyroid tissue is known as Thyrotoxicosis factitia.
  • It is not due to the infusion of iodine intake, but in thyrotoxicosis factitia is due to the ingestion of hormones.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency in a drowsy state. He becomes unconscious on the emergency floor. An ABG sample is immediately taken. His ABGs are pH=7.25, PCO2=60 mmHg, PO2=65 mmHg and HCO3=26 mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Respiratory acidosis uncompensated

  • The ABGs of the patient show pH=7.25 (acidosis), PCO2=60 mmHg (raised), pO2=65 mmHg (low) and HCO3=26 mmHg (normal).
  • The patient has a low pH, high pCO2, normal HCO3- and a low pO2.
  • The patient has respiratory acidosis, which leads to a low pO2.
  • HCO3- is normal, so compensation has not yet occurred.
  • So, this patient has uncompensated respiratory acidosis.

Option B: Respiratory alkalosis compensated

  • This patient has a low pH and a high pCO2.
  • He has respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis.

Option C: Metabolic acidosis uncompensated

  • The patient has a normal HCO3- level.
  • His acid-base picture is not secondary to a metabolic abnormality.

Option D: Metabolic alkalosis compensated

  • The patient has a low pH and a normal HCO3- level.
  • He has respiratory acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of milk coming out of her nipples for the past 5 months. She is a nulligravida, and she is experiencing galactorrhea on a physical exam. She is diagnosed with prolactinoma. The characteristic physical finding of prolactinoma after galactorrhea is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bitemporal hemianopia

  • The patient has prolactinoma, which is a secretory pituitary adenoma that happens due to over secretion of the prolactin hormone
  • Galactorrhea is the first symptom that most women get as a result of prolactinoma
  • The second one is bitemporal hemianopia due to the pressure of adenoma on the optic chiasm
  • Bitemporal hemianopia is loss of vision of the lateral side of both eyes, and you have only the medial side of vision
  • Rx-
    • Bromocriptine (MOA – DA agonist)
    • Cabergoline lowers prolactin level

Option B: Anovulatory cycles

  • Anovulatory cycles happen due to the prolactins negative effect on the L.H. and FSH, so anovulatory cycles happen as there will be no progesterone production for the shedding of the uterine wall
  • But bitemporal hemianopia is more common than anovulatory cycles

Option C: Amenorrhea

  • Prolactinoma – ↑ Prolaction
  • Negative to L.H. – Anovulatory cycles
  • Negative to FSH – Amenorrhea
  • leads to Infertility and amenorrhea
  • But bitemomporal hemanopia is more common than Ammenohrea

Option D:Infertility

  • Infertility happens due to amenorrhea, as stated above, but it is not as common as bitemporal hemianopia

questions.text: A 26-year-old HIV-positive male patient presents to the OPD with a 2-week history of fever associated with weight loss and dry cough. Bronchoalveolar lavage staining shows the following finding. What is the drug of choice for the given infection?
questions.solution:
Option B: Co-trimoxazole

  • The image shows exudates in the lung's alveoli stained with silver.
  • The black organisms are the opportunistic fungus Pneumocystis jirovecii (PCP), infecting AIDS patients.
  • The drug used for Pneumocystis Jiroveci is co-trimoxazole.
  • Co-trimoxazole, known as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), is the preferred treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii (PCP).
  • It is administered intravenously (IV) or orally (PO) for 14 days to non-HIV-infected individuals with moderate illness and 21 days to all other patients.
  • TMP-SMX, which disrupts the organism's folate metabolism, is more tolerable and at least as effective as substitute medications.
  • TMP-SMX can produce anaphylactic and anaphylactoid responses as well as leukopenia, hepatitis, rash, and fever, and individuals with HIV infection have an exceptionally high frequency of TMP-SMX hypersensitivity.

Option A: Isoniazid and rifampicin

  • The antibiotic isoniazid, called isonicotinic acid hydrazide (INH), is used to treat tuberculosis (TB). It is frequently used with rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and either streptomycin or ethambutol to treat active TB. It is frequently used alone to treat latent TB. Additionally, it may be treated with atypical mycobacteria, including M. avium, M. kansasii, and M. xenopi.
  • They are not used in the treatment of PCP.

Option C: Doxycycline

  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic of the tetracycline class called doxycycline is used to treat illnesses caused by bacteria and certain parasites.
  • Acne, chlamydia infections, Lyme disease, cholera, typhus, and syphilis are among the conditions it is used to treat.
  • When used with quinine, it is also used to prevent malaria.
  • It is not used in the treatment of PCP.

Option D: Azithromycin

  • A multitude of bacterial illnesses can be treated with azithromycin, an antibiotic.
  • It covers pneumonia, traveller's diarrhoea. It could be used for malaria together with other drugs.
  • It is not used in the treatment of PCP.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the hospital by ambulance immediately after a car accident. The patient receives three emergency blood transfusions due to active bleeding and persistent hypotension. After 4 hours, the patient developed sudden respiratory distress. SpO2 is reduced to 80%, and PCWP is 16 mm Hg. Which of the following can be the reason behind this symptom in this patient that can lead to death?
questions.solution:
Option C: TRALI

  • The typical presentation of Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia ( O2 saturation <90% in room air), and hypotension within 6 hours of transfusion.
  • PCWP in TRALI is ≤ 18 mm Hg.
  • TRALI results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.
  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release inflammatory mediators that increase capillary permeability.

              Cytokine released due to antigenic difference

                                     ↓

              Damage to the microvasculature of the lungs

                                     ↓

                                   TRALI

                                     ↓

                                    Death

  • The most common complication of blood transfusion leading to death is TRALI.

Option A: Hypokalemia

  • Massive blood transfusion usually causes hyperkalemia but rarely leads a patient to death.

Option B: Citrate toxicity

  • Citrate intoxication → Hypocalcemia, manifested by circumoral numbness and tingling sensation of the fingers and toes.
  • It is a complication of a massive blood transfusion, but it usually doesn't lead to death.

Option D: Hypothermia

  • Hypothermia is a complication that occurs due to a massive blood transfusion. But it doesn't lead to death.

questions.text: Hyponatremia is a condition of decreased serum concentration of sodium ions. This would lead to various neurologic signs depending on the severity. The hyponatremia can be euvolemic, hyper or hypovolemic. Which of the following conditions does not present as euvolemic hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cirrhosis

  • Cirrhosis is a state of volume overload.
  • The is persistent activation of RAAS in the cirrhosis.
  • This leads to volume gain.
  • However, this also results in dilutional hyponatremia due to more water than sodium.
  • Thus cirrhosis leads to Hypervolemic hyponatremia.
  • Other causes of hypervolemic hyponatremia are CHF and nephrosis.

Hypervolumic hyponatremia:

  • Patients with hypervolemic hyponatremia develop an increase in total body Na+-Cl– that is accompanied by a proportionaely greater increase in total body water, leaading to a reduced plasma Na+ concentration. As in hypovolemic hyponatremia, the causative disorders can be separated by the effect on urine Na+ concentration, with acute or chronic renal failure uniquely associated with increased urine Na+ concentration.
  • The pathophysiology of hyponatremia in the sodium-avid edematous disorders (congestive heart failure [CHF], cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome) is similar to that in hypovolemic hyponatremia, except that arterial filling and circulatory integrity is decreased due to the specific etiologic factors (e.g., cardiac dysfunction in CHF, peripheral vasodilation in cirrhosis).
  • Urine Na+ concentration is typically very low, i.e., <10 mM, even after hydration with normal saline; this Na+-avid state may be obscured by diuretic therapy.
  • The degree of hyponatremia provides an indirect index of the associated neurohumoral activation and is an important prognostic indicator in hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Option B: Hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism results in free water clearance.
  • This results in euvolemic hyponatremia.

Option C: Glucocorticoid deficiency

  • Severe hyponatremia can result from secondary adrenal insufficiency due to pituitary disease.
  • In contrast, the deficit in circulating aldosterone in primary adrenal insufficiency causes hypovolemic hyponatremia, and the predominant glucocorticoid deficiency in secondary adrenal failure is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia.
  • Glucocorticoids exert negative feedback on AVP release by the posterior pituitary such that hydrocortisone replacement in these patients can rapidly normalize the AVP response to osmolality, reducing circulating AVP

Option D: SIADH

  • A condition which activates the V2 Receptor in the collecting duct of the kidneys and increases ADH will lead to a gain of water in the body.
  • This leads to an increase in total body water. The total salts are normal.
  • This results in Relative hyponatremia i.e. euvolemic hyponatremia

questions.text: An 8-month-old female baby presents to the pediatric emergency with a history of lethargy for 1 day. She has had many episodes of vomiting. Her mother is a known case of drug addiction. The baby is obtunded but has normal muscle tone and pupillary reflexes on examination. Labs show Na+= 135 mEq/L, K+ = 4.2 mEq/L, glucose 5.9 mmol/l, Cl- = 116 mEq/L. Urine is negative for glucose & ketones but positive for calcium oxalate crystals. Her ABGs reveal pH=7.19, pCO2=20 mmHg, pO2=100 mmHg, and HCO3=6.2 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Metabolic acidosis partially compensated

  • The ABGs show acidic pH, low PCO2 and low HCO3.
  • Anion gap: Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-) = 135 - (116+6) = 135-122 = 13 (elevated).
  • The patient has a high anion gap and partially compensated metabolic acidosis.
  • Urine is positive for calcium oxalate crystals which are diagnostic of ethylene glycol poisoning.
  • Mother has a history of drug addiction. Normal pupillary reflexes of the baby indicate no CNS depression.

Option A: Metabolic acidosis compensated

  • The pH is highly acidic. So, full compensation has not yet occurred.

Option C: Metabolic alkalosis compensated

  • The patient has an acidic pH and low HCO3.
  • She has metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

Option D: Metabolic alkalosis partially compensated

  • The patient has an acidic pH and low HCO3.
  • She has metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the clinic for consultation. She has been recently diagnosed with classic Migraine and wants to know its features. Which statements are correct regarding patients with a classical migraine?

choices.text: A unilateral headache with unilateral visual loss and muscle aches
Left a retro-orbital headache with rhinorrhoea and red eye
Visual deficit that persists after cessation of a unilateral headache
Pulsating unilateral headache worsened with the movements of the head

questions.solution:
Option D: Pulsating unilateral headache worsened with the movements of the head

  • A migraine is a unilateral pulsating headache that can worsen with movement and is associated with photophobia
  • A migraine headache starts with an aura(the patient experiences a noise or a particular smell before the headache)
  • The diagnostic criteria for migraine headaches are as follows:
DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA FOR MIGRAINE
Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 hr in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache,
At least 2 of the following features: Plus, at least 1 of the following features:
Unilateral pain Nausea/ vomiting
  • Throbbing pain
  • Photophobia
  • Phonophobia
Aggravation by movement
Moderate or severe intensity

Option A: A unilateral headache with unilateral visual loss and muscle aches

  • This Statement describes GIANT CELL ARTERITIS - Typical presenting symptoms include headache, Polymyalgia, Rheumatica, jaw claudication, fever, and Weight loss.

Option B: Left a retro-orbital headache with rhinorrhoea and red eye

  • This Statement describes the cluster headache
  • Cluster headache:
    • The pain is deep, usually retroorbital, excruciating in intensity, nonfluctuating,
    • special features:
      • Periodicity -A core feature of cluster headaches is periodicity. At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs same hour each day for the duration of a cluster bout
      • Parasympathetic autonomic activation -Cluster headache is associated with ipsilateral symptoms of cranial parasympathetic autonomic activation leading to conjunctival injection or lacrimation, rhinorrhea or nasal congestion, or cranial sympathetic dysfunction, such as ptosis.

Option C: Visual deficit that persists after cessation of a unilateral headache

  • This Statement describes Ophthalmoplegic Migraine. In ophthalmoplegia, there is a visual deficit which can trigger Migraine, and even after cessation of the Migraine, the visual deficit remains

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of hypertension. His blood pressure has been high on various occasions. On examination, his pulse is 95 beats per minute, his temperature is 99°F and his blood pressure is 155/100 mmHg. On further laboratory evaluation, he is found to have high serum sodium and hypokalaemia. A CT abdomen is performed on the patient, and its findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Conn Syndrome

  • The image shows a mass on top of the kidney, indicative of adrenal pathology.
  •  Since hypertension is present with hypokalemia, it is due to high levels of aldosterone in the blood.
  • Increased aldosterone from adrenal adenoma is diagnostic of Conn syndrome.
  • PAC/PRA (plasma aldosterone concentration/plasma renin activity) is often used as a screening test for adrenal adenoma. A high PAC/PRA ratio indicates primary hyperaldosteronism, whereas a low ratio indicates a secondary cause.
  • The abnormal electrolyte levels often seen with too much aldosterone lead to signs and symptoms such as:
    • Lack of muscle strength
    • Frequent voiding
    • Night-time voiding
    • Headache
    • Increased thirst
    • Pins and needles feeling
    • Eyesight problems
    • Paralysis that comes and goes
    • Muscle twitching and cramps

 

Option A: Pheochromocytoma

  • Pheochromocytoma is also an adrenal tumour and is often seen as a mass on top of a kidney. It also presents with hypertension, but hypokalemia is not seen.

Option C: Liddle Syndrome

  • Liddle syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder which causes the overactivity of the epithelial sodium channels but does not present as an adrenal mass.

Option D: Secondary Hyperaldosteronism

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism (conn syndrome) is due to a problem of the adrenal glands themselves, which causes them to release too much aldosterone. Whereas secondary hyperaldosteronism is the excessive production of aldosterone due to increased production of renin or high activity of the RAAS system.

questions.text: A 46-year-old patient presents to the clinic with severe pain in the finger joints. Her medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis. Besides joint pain, she complains of excessive tiredness and breathlessness. On general physical examination, pallor is noted in the conjunctiva. A panel of complete blood count and iron studies is ordered. Regarding anaemia of chronic diseases, all of the following are true, except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Decreased ferritin

  • In anaemia of chronic inflammation, ferritin is normal or high, reflecting the fact that iron is sequestered within cells and ferritin is produced as an acute phase reactant.
  • Chronic disease results in the production of acute phase reactants from the liver, including hepcidin.
  • Hepcidin sequesters iron in storage sites by limiting iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid precursors and decreasing erythropoietin production. Thus, making serum iron unavailable to use. 
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option A: Decreased serum iron

  • In anaemia of chronic disease, serum iron is decreased because iron is sequestered in macrophages by acute phase reactants.

Option C: Decreased total iron binding capacity

  • In anaemia of chronic disease, serum ferritin increases; therefore, total iron binding capacity decreases.

Option D: Increased bone marrow iron

  • In anaemia of chronic disease, serum ferritin increases because iron is trapped in the bone marrow.

questions.text: A 34-year-old black female presents to the physician with symptoms of cough, dyspnea, and lymphadenopathy for 3 months. She has lost 2 pounds in the last month despite eating junk food. She is vitally stable. She does a job in a paper factory. Her younger brother died of sudden cardiac death 6 years back. Physical exam shows cervical adenopathy and hepatomegaly. Her chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Bronchoscopy and transbronchial lung biopsy

  • The above-mentioned case is of Sarcoidosis involving the lungs.
  • In this case, a black female presents to the physician with symptoms of cough, dyspnea, and lymphadenopathy for 3 months.
  • Hilar and peripheral lymphadenopathy are common, and 20 to 30% of patients have hepatomegaly.
  • Chest x-ray shows symmetrical hilar lymphadenopathy.
  • The diagnostic method of choice - transbronchial biopsy: mononuclear cell granulomatous inflammatory process.
  • While liver and scalene node biopsies are often positive, noncaseating granulomas are so frequent in these sites that they are not considered acceptable for primary diagnosis.

Option A: Open lung biopsy

  • For open lung biopsy, an incision is made in the skin on the chest and surgically removes a piece of lung tissue.
  • An open lung biopsy can sometimes be used for a definite diagnosis of Sarcoidosis.
  • Biopsy reveals noncaseating granulomas.

Option B: Liver biopsy

  • Liver biopsy is used it is to differentiate hepatic Sarcoidosis from other autoimmune and granulomatous liver diseases.
  • All cases of hepatic Sarcoidosis do not require treatment.
  • Liver biopsy reveals noncaseating granuloma of Sarcoidosis.

Option D: Scalene node biopsy

  • Scalene lymph nodes are important because they are a common location for metastasis of several cancers, the most common of which is lung cancer.
  • They are located posteriorly by scalene muscles and anteriorly by the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • It is usually not performed in Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is seen in the emergency with vomiting and lethargy for 1 day. On general physical examination, the boy appears dehydrated; temperature is 99°F, blood pressure 100/70mmHg, pulse 110 beats/minute and respiratory rate 25 breaths/minute. The arterial blood gas sample shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following conditions is not associated with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ureterosigmoidostomy.

  • When the pH of plasma is decreased (pH<7.35), it is called acidosis, while elevated plasma pH (pH>7.35) is called alkalosis.
  • Acidosis can be respiratory or metabolic, depending upon the initiating event. It is characterized by headaches, loss of consciousness, hyperkalemia, warm flushed skin, nausea, vomiting and rapid, deep breathing.
  • If the primary event is due to a respiratory system defect, it is known as respiratory acidosis. Important causes of respiratory acidosis are airway obstruction, chronic lung diseases, acute lung diseases, opioids, sedatives and weakening of respiratory muscles. It is corrected by a renal compensatory increase in bicarbonate reabsorption, but it is a delayed response.
  • If a metabolic event causes acidosis, it is known as metabolic acidosis. It is corrected by hyperventilation which is an immediate response. Metabolic acidosis is divided into normal anion gap metabolic acidosis and high anion-gap metabolic acidosis. These can be differentiated based on the anion gap, calculated as:

The normal anion gap is around 8-12mEq/L.

  • The anion gap is increased by conditions that produce extra acid in our body. These conditions cause a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis (anion gap >12mEq/L)and include:
    • Uremia
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis
    • Propylene glycol
    • Iron tablets or isoniazid
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Ethylene glycol
    • Salicylates (aspirin)
  • Conditions that cause a normal anion gap
    • Hyperchloremia
    • Hyperalimentation
    • Addison’s disease
    • Ureterosigmoidostomy
    • Renal tubular acidosis
    • Diarrhoea
    • Acetazolamide
    • Spironolactone
    • Saline infusion

 

Option A: Diabetic ketoacidosis.

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis causes a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis because acidic ketone bodies are formed.

 

Option B: Uremia.

  • Uremia is when there is excess urea in our body due to defective renal excretion of urea.
  • It causes an elevated anion-gap metabolic acidosis

 

Option C: Lactic acidosis.

  • Excessive lactic acid production or defective excretion causes elevated anion-gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of fatigue that increases with work. The patient says she gets tired quite early without completing her tasks and takes long breaks to complete them. She has a history of breathing and eating difficulty. There is no accident or fall history. She is a non-smoker with no drug abuse history. Her blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, and her pulse is 80 beats/min. Physical examination reveals that there is a dropping in eyelids and blurry vision. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. A test is performed on the patient's eye, as given in the image below. This test is helpful in the evaluation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
CORRECT OPTIONS:

Option A: Myasthenia Gravis

  • The patient with complaints of fatigable muscle weakness, diplopia, ptosis, dyspnea and dysphagia suffers from Myasthenia gravis.
  • In myasthenia gravis, antibodies are present against the postsynaptic Acetylcholine receptors. It decreases postsynaptic receptor activation.
  • The image given above is of the ice pack test.
  • Ice pack test: In this test, an ice pack is applied to the ptosis eye, and the length of the eyelid is measured before and after applying the ice.
  • Usually, a rise of 2 cm is measured in a positive test.
  • It is used in patients suspected of palpebral ptosis and ophthalmoparesis due to myasthenia gravis.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

Option B: Multiple system atrophy

  • It is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects both the autonomic system and movements.
  • It occurs due to the progressive death of the different brain and spinal cord cell functions.
  • It occurs due to the accumulation of alpha-synuclein in oligodendroglia.
  • It mostly resembles Parkinson's disease; initially, it is difficult to differentiate the two.
  • It shows the following characteristics:
  • Slowness of movements
  • Tremors
  • Speaking difficulty
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Fainting
  • Bladder incontinence
  • It is diagnosed by MRI showing hot cross buns sign and putaminal atrophy.

Option C: Trigeminal neuralgia

  • It is a unilateral, intermittent, shock-like pain on one side of the face.
  • It occurs due to trigeminal nerve compression (CN V) at the level of the pons, which leads to demyelination and atrophy of the nerve.
  • Mainly it involves the second and third branches of the nerve (CN V₂ and V₃).
  • Triggers include chewing, brushing or any light touch (like a towel stroke after bathing).
  • It may last from a few seconds to minutes.
  • Compression can occur due to an abnormal vascular loop, tumour or multiple sclerotic plaques.
  • It is treated with carbamazepine (first-line treatment)

Option D: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis

  • It is an episode of extreme muscle weakness triggered by a high carbohydrate diet and strenuous exercise that occurs mostly in adolescence and childhood.
  • It is mainly associated with hypokalemia. Potassium deficiency impairs nerve conduction and muscle contraction.
  • It occurs due to the mutation in calcium or sodium channels that affects the skeletal muscles.
  • The most common symptoms are:
  • Heart palpitations
  • Muscle cramps
  • Paralysis
  • CMAP compound muscle action potential shows a low amplitude and no exercise improvement.

questions.text: A 2-year-old Prim gravid female patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of a rash on her face, Joint pain associated with the rash, and itching on exposure to sunlight. On examination, you find a rash over her face sparing nasolabial folds. On lab investigation, antinuclear antibodies (+). Mark the correct statement with respect to antibodies and their pattern in the given condition.

choices.text: Anti-Nuclear antibody - least sensitive antibody for SLE
Anti-Smith antibody - least specific antibody for SLE
Homogeneous pattern of nuclear antibody is seen in SLE
Anti- Ribosomal P antibody causes Psychosis in SLE

questions.solution:
Option D: Anti- Ribosomal P antibody causes psychosis in SLE

The above symptoms and clinical findings resemble SLE.

SLE: -

1. Autoimmune

2. Kidney defect (proteinemia)

3. AIHA: Normocytic Normochromic anaemia

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder with CNS manifestations on occasion.
  • This disorder presents with psychiatric complaints in a few cases, but the psychotic features are uncommon.
  • A peripheral pattern indicates that fluorescence occurs at the nucleus's edges in a shaggy pattern; this pattern is almost exclusively associated with systemic lupus.
  • Lupus also has a speckled pattern.

Test: -

  1. Antinuclear antibody – sensitive to SLE
  2. Anti-Smith antibody – specific for SLE
  3. Anti-ribosomal P antibody - cause psychosis in SLE
  4. Anti- topoisomerase antibody – scleroderma
The pattern of nuclear antibody Disease
RIM pattern SLE (anti dsDNA)
Homogeneous pattern Drug-induced SLE (anti-histone)
Speckled pattern Connective tissue disorder
Nucleolar pattern Scleroderma
Centromere pattern CREST

Option A: Antinuclear antibody - least sensitive antibody for SLE

  • The antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is the most sensitive test for SLE and, thus, the best screening assay for excluding it.
  • Anti-native (N)-DNA and anti-Sm (Smith antigen) tests are highly specific for SLE and have strong confirmatory powers, even in patients who do not appear to be infected.

Option B: Anti-Smith antibody - least specific antibody for SLE

  • Anti-Smith (Sm) antibody is a highly specific anti-systemic lupus erythematosus antibody (SLE).
  • Despite anti-Sm antibody specificity for SLE, the relationship between anti-Sm antibody level and clinical manifestation of SLE remains unknown.

Option C: Homogeneous pattern of nuclear antibody is seen in SLE

  • Total nuclear fluorescence has a homogenous (diffuse) pattern, which is common in people with systemic lupus.
  • Several ANA subtypes can be found in SLE patients.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department with clinical features of CKD. She has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension. She has been recently diagnosed with Stage 5 CKD and has been undergoing hemodialysis for a few months now. Which of the following is the feed for such patients with CKD?
questions.solution:
Option C: High-calorie, low volume

  • A condition known as chronic kidney disease (CKD) is one in which the kidneys get damaged and are unable to filter blood as effectively as they should.
  • As a result of this, extra fluid and waste products from the blood linger in the body, which can lead to a variety of severe health issues, including coronary heart disease and stroke.
  • The severity of CKD can range from mild to severe. Although medication has been demonstrated to halt the growth of the condition, it often gets worse with time. If the condition is not addressed, chronic kidney disease (CKD) can lead to renal failure and an earlier stage of cardiovascular disease.
  • Dialysis or a kidney transplant are both necessary for survival in the event that kidney function has been lost.
  • CKD patients have catabolic metabolism, so they will require higher calories.
  • Since the disease CKD has affected the kidney, we prefer to give low volume due to decreased capacity of the kidney to excrete.

Option A: Low-calorie, low volume

  • Catabolic metabolism in CKD requires high calories and low volume.

Option B: Low-calorie, high volume

  • Catabolic metabolism in CKD requires high calories and low volume.

Option D: High-calorie, high volume

  • Catabolic metabolism in CKD requires high calories and low volume.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents to the office with complaints of blood in her urine, nausea, weakness and swelling of both legs, and puffiness of her face. Her blood pressure is 150/110 mmHg, and her pulse is 80 beats/min. Her examination reveals bilateral moderate pedal oedema. Urine analysis shows nonselective proteinuria and red cell casts. Renal biopsy is done, which shows glomerular crescents. Diagnosis of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis is made. Which of the following is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Methylprednisolone

  • This patient, with rapidly deteriorating kidney function and the presence of glomerular crescents, is most likely suffering from rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
  • RPGN is a rapidly progressive disease and can lead to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) if not treated early.
  • Early initiation of therapy has been known to lead to full recovery of kidney function in 50% of the patients.
  • The mainstay treatment of RPGN is glucocorticoids. Cyclophosphamide can be added along with methylprednisolone for better results.
  • In the case of RPGN secondary to ANCA-associated vasculitis, Rituximab is added to methylprednisolone for better results.

Option A: Wait and Watch

  • Wait and watch approach is inappropriate in RPGN.
  • If treatment is not initiated early, the patient’s condition advances to ESRD with high mortality.
  • It is advised to start treatment with 500-1000 mg methylprednisolone while awaiting confirmatory biopsy results if RPGN is suspected.
  • Wait and watch approach is usually adopted in comparatively benign conditions, such as mild cases of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. (PSGN)

Option B: Sirolimus

  • Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant which acts as an mTOR inhibitor.
  • It is usually used as prophylaxis for renal transplant rejection. It is not used in RPGN management.

Option D: Plasma Exchange

  • Plasma exchange is not the first line of management of RPGN.
  • In cases of RPGN secondary to anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody deposition (Goodpasture Syndrome), plasma exchange is employed in addition to immunosuppressive therapy with glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide.
  • Plasma exchange removes the antibodies responsible for the patient’s condition, thus improving the patient's overall outcome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to a plastic surgery clinic with a complaint of yellowish plaques appearing on her face, as shown in the image below. She describes the lesion as non-painful and does not bleed on touch. She has a family history of lipid metabolic disorders, and her father died of myocardial infarction in his 40s. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Xanthelasma

  • The image above shows xanthelasma palpebrarum, yellow plaque-like depositions of cholesterol-rich material. It is made up of lipid-laden histiocytes.
  • Xanthelasma palpebrarum is the most common type of xanthoma. It can involve the upper and lower eyelids bilaterally.
  • The causes of xanthelasma include:
    • Obesity
    • Smoking
    • Hypertension
    • Heavy alcohol intake
    • Idiopathic in normolipidemic patients.
    • Familial hypercholesterolemia.
    • Diabetes mellitus.
    • Biliary cirrhosis.
    • Thyroid hormone abnormalities.
  • Xanthelasmas can increase the risk of atherosclerosis and myocardial infarction in a patient.
  • Most people get xanthelasmas between the ages of 35-55 years.
  • Xanthelasmas indicate high serum cholesterol. Treatments with cholesterol-lowering drugs and lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, quitting smoking and fruit & vegetable diet. Management of underlying conditions is essential.
  • Surgical removal is the treatment of choice.

Option B: Necrobiosis lipoidica.

  • Necrobiosis lipoidica is a rare complication of diabetes mellitus which presents as shiny yellow lesions on the shins that may ulcerate and cause pain.

Option C: Tuberous xanthoma.

  • Tuberous xanthomas are firm, painless red nodules that develop on pressure areas such as extensor surfaces of the knees, elbows and buttocks.

Option D: Orbital lipogranuloma.

  • Orbital lipogranuloma presents as a palpable subcutaneous nodule present around the orbit. It is an inflammatory granulomatous soft tissue reaction associated with injections, trauma or systemic diseases.

questions.text: Excessive sexual desire in males is known as:
questions.solution:
• Satyriasis is the condition of excessive sexual desire in males
  • Excessive sexual desire in females is known as nymphomania.
  • Tribadism/Lesbianism - sexual intercourse between two female partners.
  • Sadism - Type of sexual perversion in which person obtain sexual gratification by beating/assaulting/humiliating other partner. DSM-5 defines sexual sadism as the recurrent & intense sexual arousal from the physical and psychological suffering of another person. Minimum duration required for diagnosis is 6 months (DSM-5).

questions.text: Feeding and Eating disorders are characterized by a persistent disturbance of eating or eating-related behavior that results in the altered consumption or absorption of food and significantly impairs physical health or psychosocial functioning. Which is the most common eating disorder?
questions.solution:
Option D: Binge eating disorder

Most common eating disorder: Binge eating disorder > Bulimia Nervosa > Anorexia Nervosa

Binge eating disorder

  • It is the most common eating disorder
  • Females > Males
  • The person is overweight
  • Binge eating is present, but no compensation
  • Impulsive & extroverted personality styles are linked to this disorder
  • Treatment: CBT + SSRI

Option A: Anorexia Nervosa

  • Most common eating disorder: Binge eating disorder > Bulimia Nervosa > Anorexia Nervosa

Option B: Bulimia nervosa

  • Binge eating disorder  is more common than Bulimia Nervosa and Anorexia Nervosa

Option C: Avoidant restriction of food intake disorder

  • Avoidant restriction of food intake disorder is not as common as binge eating disorder

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife with a complaint of confusion and disorientation. He has a long history of alcoholic intake and has drunk heavily for the last three days. On examination, he is unable to tell his name, there is gross incoordination in his walking, and his eyes deviate to one side. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Wernicke’s encephalopathy

The features of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia associated with a history of alcoholic consumption suggest Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy is an acute and reversible neurological dysfunction that is associated with heavy alcoholic intake.
  • It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency resulting from chronic heavy alcohol use.
  • The diagnosis is usually clinical. However, the labs will show decreased serum thiamine levels and increased serum lactate and pyruvate levels.
  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia.

Option B: Korsakoff’s psychosis

  • Korsakoff psychosis differs from Wernicke’s encephalopathy in two ways:
  1. It is chronic and irreversible.
  2. The symptoms include confabulation (fabricated memories), anterograde and retrograde amnesia, and altered temper.
  • The symptoms described in the case above are inconsistent with Korsakoff’s psychosis.

Option C: Alcoholic hallucinosis

  • Alcohol hallucinosis is characterized by the symptoms of hallucinations that neither occur in Wernicke’s encephalopathy nor have been described in the case above.

Option D: Delirium tremens

  • Delirium tremens is a symptom of alcohol withdrawal. There is no history of withdrawal from alcohol in the above case.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the psychiatric emergency department due to neck spasm for 2 hours. She recently presented in the outpatient department due to hearing voices and changes in behavior 5 days ago. She was diagnosed with a psychotic disorder and was started on medication. On physical examination, the patient's neck is twisted to the extent that the head is turned to the right side at an odd angle. Which of the following drug is least likely to cause the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Thioridazine

  • The patient presents with signs and symptoms of acute dystonia.
  • Acute dystonia is one of the extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).
  • EPS is because of D2 blocking activity.

 

Extrapyramidal Effects

 

 Clinical features

 

 Pharmacotherapy

 

Acute dystonia

Sudden sustained contraction of the neck, mouth, tongue, and eye muscles presenting as:

  • Oculogyric crisis, ocular muscles spasm, and opisthotonos
  • Torticollis
  • Laryngospasm
  • Grimacing

Earliest to develop. Occurs within days of drug usage.

Anticholinergic drugs:

  • Benztropine
  • Diphenhydramine

Acute akathisia
  • Constant purposeless involuntary movement from one place to another.
  • Most common EPS.
  • Occurs within days to weeks
  • Propranolol
  • Lorazepam
  • Benztropine

Tardive dyskinesia

Gradual onset after prolonged therapy (>6 months). Usually presents after years of treatment.

Dyskinesia of the mouth, face trunk, and extremities causing:

  • chewing and sucking movements
  • grimacing
  • choreoathetosis movements
  • Deutetrabenazine
  • Valbenazine

Malignant neuroleptic syndrome

Most serious side effect. Presents as:

  • Hyperthermia
  • Severe muscular rigidity and dystonia
  • Akinesia
  • Mutism
  • Fluctuating level of consciousness
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia
  • High blood pressure

Laboratory findings include:

  • Increased WBC count
  • Increased level of CPK
  • Increased level of liver enzymes
  • Increased levels of plasma myoglobin and myoglobinuria
  • Occasionally renal failure
  • Immediately stop>
  • Medically cool the patient
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Dantrolene (skeletal muscle relaxant)
  • Bromocriptine or Amantadine

Drug-induced parkinsonism

Gradual onset tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Occurs within weeks to months
  • Benztropine
  • Amantadine
  • Typical antipsychotics have potent D2 blocking activity and hence, more EPS.
  • Thioridazine is an exception because it has less D2 blocking activity and more anticholinergic activity.
  • Atypical antipsychotics have less D2 blocking activity than typical antipsychotics and hence, fewer EPS.
  • The exception is risperidone which has potent D2 blocking activity.

Option A: Haloperidol

  • Haloperidol is a potent D2 blocker.
  • It has severe EPS.

Option B: Thiothixene

  • Thiothixene is a potent D2 blocker.
  • It has severe EPS.

Option D: Perphenazine

  • Perphenazine is a typical antipsychotic.
  • It blocks D2 receptors causing EPS.
  • It is more likely to cause EPS than thioridazine.

questions.text: A 61-year-old female presents in OPD with a lump of size 6x3.5cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. FNAC of the lump revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. She subsequently underwent Patey’s modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following statements is true about Patey’s modified radical mastectomy?

choices.text: Internal mammary lymph nodes are removed

questions.solution:
Option C: Pectoralis minor is removed

  • A Patey's modified radical mastectomy involves the complete removal of the breast, which includes the skin, areola, nipple, and the majority of the axillary lymph nodes as well as pectoralis minor muscle. 
  • The pectoralis major muscle is left intact in Patey’s modified radical mastectomy.


Option A: Pectoralis major is removed

  • In a modified radical mastectomy, the pectoralis major muscle is preserved.

Option B:  Axillary lymph nodes are preserved

  • Axillary lymph node dissection is an important component of modified radical mastectomy.
  • They are removed in all types of MRM.

Option D: Internal mammary lymph nodes are removed

  • These lymph nodes are not removed in Patey's modified radical mastectomy.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown below that can be performed for a 40-year-old female with toxic nodular goiter.
questions.solution:
Option C: Total Thyroidectomy

  • The case mentioned above underwent a total thyroidectomy shown in the picture.
  • There are various thyroidectomy indications, including thyroid cancer, multinodular toxic goitre, and hyperthyroidism.
  • Removal of the whole thyroid gland or a part of the thyroid gland depends on the underlying condition.
  • Total Thyroidectomy – Removal of all visible thyroid tissue.

  • Hemi Thyroidectomy – Removal of one lobe with isthmus.

Option A: Near-total Thyroidectomy

  • Complete resection on one side while leaving a remnant of thyroid tissue (< 1g) on the contralateral side adjacent to the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the ligament of the berry.

Option B: Hartley Dunhill Procedure

  • Leaving 4-6 grams of thyroid in one lobe with the removal of the rest of the thyroid gland is done in Hartley Dunhill Procedure.

Option D: Subtotal Thyroidectomy

  • Leaving 3-4 grams of thyroid tissue in each lobe with the removal of the rest of the thyroid gland. The typical reason to leave a remnant at the berry's ligament is to preserve the recurrent laryngeal nerve and blood supply to the parathyroid.

questions.text: A 14-year old boy was involved in a bike accident, receiving blunt trauma to his upper abdomen. After immediate admission to the local hospital, an intraperitoneal hemorrhage was demonstrated by peritoneal lavage. Surgical laparotomy showed a large hepatic rupture 1.5 cm long on the upper surface of the right lobe. Laceration repair was done, and adequate drainage was performed. Hemostasis was completely successful at the end of the operation. On postoperative day 2, asymptomatic clinical jaundice occurred. The total bilirubin level increased very rapidly to 18.7 mg/dl and to 40.7 mg/dl on postoperative day 5. The other laboratory findings showed anemia, a slight decrease in plasma proteins, and leukocytosis. On postoperative day 6, ERCP was done, which showed the following finding: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bilhemia

  • Fig-A, Endoscopic retrograde cholangiogram. Bile ducts injected by catheter (C) positioned in the common bile duct. Opacification of fistula (arrow) and segmental branch of right hepatic vein (RHV).
  • Fig-B, Selective opacification of the segmental branch of the hepatic vein, fistula (arrow), and bile duct
  • BILHEMIA:
    • It is the reverse of haemobilia, with bile entering the bloodstream through communication with the hepatic veins or with branches of the portal vein. 
    • The reversed flow is caused by the inversion of the pressure gradient due to high intraductal biliary pressure, generally resulting from peripheral obstruction or low venous pressure.
    • The symptoms are rapidly increasing jaundice with elevated direct bilirubin without increased liver enzymes.

Option A: Haemobilia

  • An abnormal communication between a blood vessel and the bile duct causes bleeding into the biliary tree.
  • The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, and jaundice.
  • The most common cause of haemobilia is iatrogenic trauma, mostly due to percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage from 2% to 10%
  • The test of choice is arterial angiography.
  • Most bleeds are managed conservatively; however, angiography with transarterial embolization is indicated for major haemobilia requiring blood transfusion.

Option C: Biliary stricture

  • In biliary strictures, hepatic enzymes are deranged with an elevation of direct bilirubin.

Option D: Iatrogenic injury during the procedure

  • Iatrogenic injury during the procedure causes haemobilia.
  • Bilhemia is an abnormal reversed flow between hepatic veins and the bloodstream.

questions.text: What is the congenital anomaly seen in the ultrasound image given below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Phrygian cap

  • The ultrasound image shows the infoldings of the septum between the fundus and body, which is suggestive of the Phrygian cap

  • The Phrygian cap is the most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder.
  • It is present in 5% of cases and may be mistaken for pathological deformity of the organ.

Option A: Moynihan’s hump

  • The hepatic artery may take a tortuous course on the front of the origin of the cystic duct, or the right hepatic artery is tortuous and the cystic artery short. 
  • The tortuosity is known as the 'Caterpillar turn' or 'Moynihan’s hump'.

Option C: Duplication

  • Gallbladder duplication is a rare congenital malformation that occurs in about one in 4000 births.
  • Congenital anomalies of the gallbladder and anatomical variations of their positions are associated with an increased risk of complications after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option D: None of the above

  • The picture shown above is the Phrygian cap.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented to the clinic complaining of abdominal pain, secretory diarrhoea, and reflux. After further investigations, he was diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding his diagnosis?

choices.text: Mostly found in the Hesselbach triangle
Basal acid output >5 mEq/hour is diagnostic
Most common site is the duodenum

questions.solution:
Option C: Most common site is the duodenum

 

  • Gastrinoma is the second most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumour, causing Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES), which is characterised by acid hypersecretion and peptic ulceration.
  • Although the majority of the ulcers are solitary, several ulcers in unusual sites that do not react to antacids should raise the possibility of ZES. The most frequent type of ulcer is a duodenal ulcer.
  • Gastrin levels of more than 1000 pg/mL are indicative of gastrinoma. However, this is not the case because gastrin levels are high in other illnesses such as pernicious anaemia, atrophic gastritis, and so on. A secretin stimulation test is useful in ambiguous instances.
  • SSTR (octreotide) scintigraphy in conjunction with CT is the preferred test. The octreotide scan is more sensitive than CT, identifying tumours as small as 1cm and finding around 85% of gastrinomas.
  • Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is useful in locating tumours in the pancreatic head or duodenum wall, where gastrinomas are typically 1cm in size.
  • The combination of an octreotide scan with a EUS detects more than 90% of gastrinomas.
  • One-fourth of gastrinomas are associated with the MEN1 syndrome. Approximately 50% of gastrinomas spread to lymph nodes or the liver and are thus classified as malignant.

Option A: Mostly found in the Hesselbach triangle

  • Primary gastrinoma is detected in 70% to 90% of patients in Passaro's triangle, a region described by a triangle with points at the junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct, the second and third section of the duodenum, and the neck and body of the pancreas.

Option B: Basal acid output >5 mEq/hour is diagnostic

  • A basal acid output of more than 15 mEq/hour is diagnostic

Option D: Lymphadenectomy improves survival

  • Treatment includes full tumour removal. Lymphadenectomy is unnecessary because there is no benefit in survival.

questions.text: Which of the following does a successful treatment of a Zenker's diverticulum involve?

choices.text: Either diverticulopexy or resection with cricopharyngeal myotomy

questions.solution:
Option C: Either diverticulopexy or resection with cricopharyngeal myotomy 

  • Surgical or endoscopic repair is the gold standard of treatment. 
  • Cricopharyngeal Myotomy and Diverticuloplexy is the preferred treatment modality for this patient. 
  • Open repair involves Diverticulectomy (resection) and Diverticulopexy ( surgical fixation of the diverticulum). 
  • In all cases, a myotomy of the proximal and distal thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscle is performed. 
    • For small diverticula (<2 cm ), a myotomy is sufficient alone.  
    • For a large sac (>5 cm), excision of the sac is indicated. 
  • Endoscopic repair is by Dohlman’s procedure (Diverticulo-esophagostomy). 

 

Option A: Diverticulopexy 

  • Along with Diverticulopexy, resection of the diverticulum with cricopharyngeal myotomy can be performed. 

Option B: Resection of the diverticulum 

  • Along with resectioning of the diverticulum with cricopharyngeal myotomy, Diverticulopexy, can be performed. 

Option D: Observation 

  • The patient needs immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: Bird of prey sign is present in which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sigmoid volvulus

  • Radiological (X-ray) Characteristics of the sigmoid colon
    • Markedly dilated sigmoid colon with a bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance.
    • The dilated loop's inferior convergence points towards the pelvis's left side. Whorl sign CT scan.
    • Contrast enema demonstrates the point of obstruction with the pathognomic 'birds beak' or 'bird of prey' or 'ace of spades' sign.

  • Volvulus:
    • Volvulus is defined as the twisting of a loop of the bowel on its mesentery and is one of the most common causes of intestinal obstruction.
    • The sigmoid colon and, less frequently, the cecum are the common sites of volvulus in adults.
    • Patients typically show features of bowel obstruction (abdominal pain, distension, bilious vomiting) or bowel ischemia and gangrene (tachycardia, hypotension, hematochezia, peritonitis) in severe cases.
    • The whirl sign and a grossly dilated loop of the bowel on an abdominal CT scan establish the diagnosis of volvulus in adults.
    • Sigmoid volvulus without peritonitis is initially managed with endoscopic detorsion, followed by a semi-elective surgery (sigmoid colectomy).
    • Sigmoid volvulus with peritonitis, and all cases of cecal volvulus, require emergency surgery.
    • Endoscopic detorsion should not be attempted in a patient with cecal volvulus because of the high risk of perforation.

 

Option A: Gastric volvulus

  • Plain radiograph of gastric volvulus:
    • Chest radiograph intrathoracic; upside-down stomach mediastinal or retrocardiac air-fluid level
    • Abdominal radiograph; when performed with the patient upright unexpected location of the gastric bubble double air-fluid level large, distended stomach collapsed small bowel

Option B: Intussusception

  • Abdominal x-rays in the cause of intussusception may demonstrate an elongated soft tissue mass (typically in the upper right quadrant in children) with bowel obstruction (and therefore air-fluid levels and bowel dilation) proximal to it.
  • There may be an absence of gas in the distal collapsed bowel.

Option D: Cecal volvulus

  • KIDNEY BEAN sign is a characteristic kidney-shaped air-filled structure in the left upper quadrant ( opposite the site of obstruction) seen in patients with cecal volvulus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea for the last two months. He is afebrile and vitally stable. He looks pale and has oral ulcers. His abdominal examination is unremarkable. On further evaluation, in barium contrast studies, the hose pipe appearance of the intestine is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Crohn’s disease

  • Hose-pipe appearance is a feature of Crohn’s disease.
  • Crohn’s disease:
    • Chronic transmural inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract.
    • Radiologic findings:
      • Deep ulcers
      • Hose-pipe appearance (long stricture extending into I/C valve with thickened wall)
      • Fat halo sign
      • Cobblestone appearance
      • Creeping fat sign

Option B: Malabsorption Syndrome

  • Malabsorption syndrome is a digestive disorder that prevents the body from effectively absorbing nutrients from food.
  • It has many causes, but most commonly involves damage to the small intestine's mucous lining.

Option C: Ulcerative Colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease which involves the colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea and abdominal pain along with iron deficiency anaemia.
  • There is a collar button appearance and loss of haustrations.
  • Signs seen:
    • Target sign / Halo sign
    • Comb sign
    • Rose thorning sign
    • Creeping fat sign
    • String sign of Kantor

Option D: Hirschsprung’s disease

  • Hirschsprung's disease is characterised by the absence of ganglionic cells in the distal colon and rectum.
  • It occurs due to the failure of migration of neural crest cells to distal bowel segments and affects cells in both myenteric and submucosal plexuses.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented to your clinic with complaints of abdominal pain radiating to the back, early satiety, and fullness.
