During his workup, an incidental adrenal mass was found on the abdominal CT scan. Which of the following is an indication for adrenalectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

Indications of surgery in Incidentaloma:

  • Suspicious imaging characteristics (irregular margins)
  • Size >5 cm
  • Bilateral adrenal metastasis
  • Functional tumor
  • Young age
  • Interval tumor growth
  • Patient preference
  • Patients with worsening hypertension, abnormal glucose tolerance, or osteoporosis

Adrenal incidentalomas:

  • Adrenal lesions discovered during imaging performed for unrelated reasons are referred to as incidentalomas
  • The incidence of these lesions identified by CT scans ranges from 0.4 to 4.4%

  • Arrow points towards non-functioning adrenal adenocarcinoma.

Option A: Size >5 cm

  • Incidental adrenal masses with a size > 5 cm have a high risk of being malignant. Therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such masses. 

Option B: Bilateral adrenal metastasis

  • Bilateral adrenal metastasis indicates malignancy; therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such cases.

Option C: Functional tumor

  • Functional incidental adrenal tumors produce troublesome symptoms; therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such cases.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male patient with a rectal abscess, polyuria, abnormal creatinine level, and glomerular filtration rate, and a family history of polycystic kidney disease presents to the surgical outpatient department. The patient's vital signs are normal, and there are no other pertinent symptoms. An intravenous pyelogram image is attached below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Autosomal Dominant Kidney Disease

  • Clinical signs: Polyuria, rectal pain, a rectal abscess, abnormal creatinine, and GFR indicates polycystic kidney disease.
  • The image shows a spider leg/swiss cheese appearance, which is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an autosomal dominant genetic disease with the involvement of chromosome 16. The disease occurs due to an abnormality in the polycystin protein.
  • In ADPKD, both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts. The kidney loses its function of the urine concentration, due to which the patient passes a large amount of diluted urine (polyuria).
  • Multiple cysts in the kidney cause compression of blood vessels that lead to the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, or renin-angiotensin-system, which is a regulator of blood pressure and cardiovascular function.
  • Any compression in the pelvicalyceal system will lead to HIS (Hydronephrosis, Infection, Stone). Dysregulated RAAS in ADPKD patients results in hypertension.
  • Clinical features are usually presented on 3rd to 4th decade of life. Most commonly, patients present with hypertension (75% adults & 25% children), while other presentations include polyuria, nocturia, hematuria and nephrolithiasis.
  • Diagnosis for the detection of ADPKD is made by intravenous pyelography (IVP), and spider leg, bell-shaped and Bubble Swiss- Cheese appearance is observed.

Option A: Urothelial carcinoma

  • The best diagnostic procedures for TCC are ureteroscopic brush cytology for malignant cells, intravenous pyelogram showing radiolucent intraluminal filling defects and CT urography for evaluating the upper urinary tract.
  • Ureteral tumors are often characterized by ureteral dilation below the site of the lesion.

Option B: Urolithiasis

  • Intravenous pyelography can diagnose urinary tract diseases like kidney stones and bladder stones. Imaging tests can detect kidney stones in the urinary tract.
  • High-speed or dual-energy computed tomography (CT) can reveal even tiny stones. A typical abdominal X-ray is less common as it can miss small kidney stones.

Option D: Hydronephrosis

  • Hydronephrosis is usually identified by imaging tests such as a kidney ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI.
  • Imaging reveals the outline of an enlarged kidney which is the hallmark of hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with fever, difficulty in urination, and groin pain for 2 days. He also complained of lower back and perineal pain for the past month. On examination, mild tenderness and swelling of the prostate were noted. CBC and urine examination were done, revealing leukocytosis and findings consistent with bacterial infection. What's the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option B: Acute prostatitis

  • A middle-aged male with complaints of fever, urinary symptoms and groin pain is the typical case of acute prostatitis.
  • It is also associated with low back and perineal pain.
  • The digital rectal examination palpates a mild, tender, swollen prostate due to bacterial infection. The digital rectal examination should be done cautiously to avoid the risk of septicemia.
  • The leukocytosis in blood and urine reports is due to infection and inflammation in the body.
  • The diagnosis is made by:
    • Digital rectal examination
    • CBC and urine reports show leukocytosis.    
  •  The treatment is with the antibiotics such as trimethoprim and ciprofloxacin because of their penetration ability into the prostate.

Other options

Option A: Pyelonephritis

  • It is not associated with pain in the perineum.
  • The swollen and tender prostate negates this disease.  

Option C: Benign prostatic hyperplasia

  • It is usually present above 60 years old male.
  • The fever and the leukocytosis are not associated features of this disease.

Option D: Nephrolithiasis

  • Nephrolithiasis is not associated with perineal pain.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the fertility clinic for evaluation of infertility. He and his wife have been trying to have children for two years. His wife was recently evaluated and found to be normal and healthy. The patient denies any pain in his testicular region. However, he reports occasional feelings of heaviness in his scrotum. On physical exam, his scrotum looks distended. At rest, a "bag of worm"-like finding is visible and palpable in the testicle. What is the grade of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Grade III

  • In the above case, the heaviness and distension of the scrotum with a "bag of worm" finding on palpation is suggestive of varicocele. As it is visible and palpable at rest, it is grade III.
  • Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform plexus of the internal spermatic venous system.
  • They are unusual in boys and typically develop during late childhood and adolescence
  • In some cases, the dilated vessels are cremasteric veins and not part of the pampiniform plexus. The usual cause is the absence or incompetence of valves in the proximal testicular vein.
  • While most varicoceles are idiopathic, obstruction of the left testicular vein by a renal tumour or nephrectomy is a cause of varicocele in later life; characteristically, in such cases, the varicocele does not decompress in the supine position.
  • Varicoceles may be asymptomatic, or patients may experience an annoying dragging discomfort that is worse on standing at the end of the day. This presumably reflects distension of the testicular veins.
  • When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side hangs lower than normal; on standing, the varicose plexus feel like a bag of worms. There may be a cough impulse.
  • Diagnosis can be made by ultrasonography and colour Doppler.
  • When the discomfort is significant, then percutaneous embolisation of the gonadal veins is the usual first-line intervention.
  • If this is impossible or if the varicocele recurs, then surgical ligation of the testicular veins is the appropriate treatment, although recurrence can occur even after surgery.

​​​​​​

Varicocele Grading
Grade 1

 

 Palpable during Valsalva manoeuvre, but not otherwise

 
Grade 2

 

 Palpable at rest but not visible

 
Grade 3

 

 Visible and palpable at rest

 

Option A: Grade I

  • If a varicocele is palpable during the Valsalva manoeuvre, but not otherwise, then it will fall in grade 1.
  • If it is visible and palpable at rest, it is under grade 3.

Option B: Grade II

  • If the varicocele is palpable at rest but not visible, it will fall in grade 2.
  • If it is visible at rest and also palpable, then it will be grade 3.

 

Option D: Grade IV

  • There are usually three grades of varicocele.
  • According to Sarteschi classification of varicocele, grade 4 vessels appear to enlarge in the supine position.
  • Testicular hypotrophy is very common in this stage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a complaint of pain in the right foot with a severe burning sensation. On examination, veins are dilated and tortuous. There is an ulcer that is causing serous discharge on the medial malleolus too. Doppler scan, revealed incompetent perforators. According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, how would you classify the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: C6

  • It is a case of a varicose vein due to dilated and tortuous veins with the presence of an active venous ulcer.
  • CEAP is a classification of chronic venous disease.
  • According to CEAP(Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology), C6 is for active venous ulcer, which is in the above-mentioned case.

Option A: C1

  • According to the classification, C1 is just reticular veins.
  • It is the start of venous disorder.

Option B: C3

  • C3 is varicose veins with mild to moderate edema.

Option C: C4a

  • C4a is for pigmentation and eczema.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp tearing chest pain that started 1 hour ago. The patient had a history of hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history. Family history is also significant for Marfan syndrome. On physical examination, lungs are clear to auscultation, and the heart sounds are normal. Vital signs reveal a temperature of 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg in both arms, pulse is 108/min and regular, and respiration rate 18/min. A chest x-ray reveals widened mediastinum. The CT scan is shown below:



 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aortic dissection

  • This is a case of aortic dissection with sudden onset sharp tearing chest pain, increased blood pressure, and mediastinum widening.
  • Aortic dissection presents with >20 mmHg difference in SBP between the arms and ECG with nonspecific ST and T wave changes.
  • It is associated with hypertension, congenital bicuspid aortic valve, cocaine use, and Marfan syndrome.
  • Diagnosis
    • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)
    • Computed tomography (CT) angiography

 

 

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

 

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option B: Thoracic aorta aneurysm​​​​​​​

  • Involves ascending the aorta and descending the aorta above the diaphragm.
  • It is associated with hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and Ehler-Danlos syndrome (EDS).
  • It causes aortic root dilation, which may lead to aortic valve regurgitation.

Option C: Angina

  • Angina is chest pain due to ischemic myocardium secondary to coronary artery narrowing or spasm.
  • ECG findings are ST depression (stable angina), transient ST elevation (vasospastic angina), and ST depression and T wave inversion (unstable angina).

Option D: Heart failure

  • Heart failure is a failure of the cardiac pump that presents with shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, crackles, S3 heart sound, jugular venous distention, and pitting edema.
  • Left heart failure is caused by hypertension, myocardial infarction, ischemia, and dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • The right heart is caused by chronic lung disease (leads to cor pulmonale).​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented to the clinic with complaints of a submandibular mass for the past 2 months. The mass is soft and nontender. Examination of the oral cavity shows a unilateral translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth, lateral to the midline. Which of the following is true regarding this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland
It is the most common type of minor salivary gland tumor

questions.solution:
Option A: It is a mucous extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland

  • This patient presented with a submandibular swelling that is soft and nontender. Examination showed a translucent swelling on the floor of the mouth. This presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of ranula.
  • Ranula is a translucent cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth that resembles a frog belly (Ranula is derived from 'Rana', the Latin for frog).
  • The term ranula is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.
  • It is mostly caused due to local trauma and duct rupture (i.e. during tongue piercing), followed by mucin spillage into the surrounding soft tissues. It can also rarely be caused by obstruction due to a sialolith or a mucus plug.
  • Histopathological features include mucin accumulation surrounded by granulation and fibrous tissue (mucous extravasation phenomenon) or a cyst filled with mucin and lined by the ductal epithelium (mucus retention cyst)
  • Ranula is a mucocele that is present on the floor of the mouth. It is usually unilateral and lateral to the midline. It is a smooth, dome-shaped, fluctuating and painless swelling.
  • The size of a ranula varies from a few to several centimetres in diameter. Very large lesions may occupy the entire floor of the mouth.
  • Diagnosis is usually made clinically, but MRI can be used in atypical cases. Treatment involves surgical removal of the cyst or marsupialization of the cyst.
  • Removal of the ranula can be tricky as there is a high risk of damaging the submandibular duct during ranula surgery.

Option B: It is treated with chemotherapy

  • Chemotherapy can be used in some cases of carcinomas of the oral cavity. A tumour presents as a hard, fixed mass, unlike this patient, who presented with a soft, nontender mass.

Option C: It is the most common type of minor salivary gland tumour

  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common minor salivary gland tumour and is present most commonly on the palate. This patient's presentation is not consistent with a minor salivary gland tumour.

Option D: It is diagnosed by biopsy

  • A ranula is diagnosed clinically. MRI can be used in patients with atypical presentations. A biopsy is not required.

questions.text: A 39-year old female came to the OPD complaining of pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen for the past 5 days. The patient was further evaluated, and CT abdomen was done. What is your diagnosis based on the sign shown in the CT image?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gallstones

  • The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign; this sign is seen in Gallstones.
    • The center of the gallstone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure; this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on the radiograph suggestive of the Mercedes-Benz sign or Seagull sign.
    • A plain radiograph of the gallbladder will show radiopaque gallstones in 10% of patients.

Option B: Liver abscess

  • In general, they appear as peripherally enhancing, centrally hypoattenuating lesions.
  • Occasionally they appear solid or contain gas in the form of bubbles or air-fluid levels.
  • The “double target sign” is a characteristic imaging feature of hepatic abscess, in which a central low-attenuation lesion (fluid-filled) is surrounded by a high-attenuation inner rim and a low-attenuation outer rim.

Option C: Common bile duct stones

  • The sensitivity of CT to detect stones in the common bile duct is 65%-88%.
  • Target sign: Central round density of the stone and surrounding lower attenuating bile or mucosa.
  • Rim sign: Stone is outlined by a thin shell of density.
  • Crescent sign: Bile eccentrically outlines luminal stone, creating a low attenuation crescent.

Option D: Hydatid cyst

  • Fluid-filled cyst, with frequent peripheral focus areas of calcification, usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • The “water-Lily sign” indicates a cyst with a floating, undulating membrane caused by a detached endocyst.
  • Hyperdense internal septa within a cyst showing a spoke wheel pattern may also be seen.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the hospital after a roadside accident. He has an injury to the front of the head. On examination, white transparent fluid is coming out of the nose. The patient tries to sniff the fluid back but cannot do so. Which of the following bone fractures result in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anterior cranial fossa fracture

  • This patient, with clear fluid coming out of the nose after sustaining a head injury, has CSF rhinorrhea.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid circulates in the subarachnoid space around the brain and the spinal cord.
  • Anterior cranial fossa fracture leads to CSF leakage into the nasal cavity.
  • The patient cannot sniff back this fluid which confirms the diagnosis.

Option B: Middle cranial fossa fracture

  • Middle cranial fossa fracture leads to CSF leakage into the ear.
  • This is known as CSF otorrhea.
  • CSF leakage into the nasal cavity occurs secondary to anterior cranial fossa fracture, not middle cranial fossa fracture.

Option C: Posterior cranial fossa fracture

  • Posterior cranial fossa fracture leads to injury to cranial nerves and cerebellum.
  • CSF rhinorrhea is due to an anterior cranial fossa fracture, not a posterior cranial fossa fracture.

Option D: Occipital bone fracture

  • Fracture of the occipital bone leads to injury to the brain’s visual cortex and occipital lobe.
  • Occipital bone fracture does not lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male mechanical engineer, who was brought by his wife reported that he was fasted for 25 days prior to presentation and that he only ingested water for that period under the influence of a Swamiji. He broke his fast today by eating breakfast after which he became extremely confused and restless. All of the following are true about the condition the patient is suffering from except:

choices.text: Associated with increased risk of arrhythmia
Occur with rapid & excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition

questions.solution:
Option D is the false statement regarding the patient's condition.

REFEEDING SYNDROME:

→ Potentially lethal condition

→ Occurs with rapid & excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa & massive weight loss in obese patients.

Pathophysiology

→ With refeeding, shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate

→ Increased insulin release → Cellular uptake of electrolytes particularly:

− Phosphate → Hypophosphatemia

− Magnesium → Hypomagnesemia

− Potassium→ Hypokalemia

− Calcium→ Hypocalcemia

→ Increased risk of arrhythmia, confusion, respiratory failure, liver dysfunction, seizure, coma & death due to dyselectrolytemia

→ Treatment- matching intakes with requirements and avoiding overfeeding

→ Hypophosphatemia and hypomagnesemia require treatment

Option A: True statement

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition.

Option B: True statement

Refeeding syndrome is associated with an increased risk of arrhythmia.

Option C: True statement

Refeeding syndrome occurs with rapid & excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition.

Option D: False statement

Hypophosphatemia & hypomagnesemia are the signs of refeeding syndrome and it requires treatment. Hyperphosphatemia & hypermagnesemia are not the signs.

Learning objective:

Refeeding is the process of reintroducing food after a prolonged period of malnourishment or starvation. Refeeding syndrome is a serious and potentially lethal condition that can occur during rapid refeeding. It is caused by sudden shifts in the electrolytes which leads to electrolyte imbalances like hypomagnesemia hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypokalemia. It is associated with an increased risk of arrhythmia.

questions.text: A female patient is scheduled for cholecystectomy. The surgeon uses an instrument to hold skin and subcutaneous tissue for retraction. What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Option D: Allis tissue forceps

 

  • Allis tissue forceps have a tip which has alternate teeth or grooves

  • Its uses include

    • Holding skin and subcutaneous tissue flap for retraction

    • Holding tough tissue

    • Holding skin during suturing

    • Hold cut margins of the skin

Option A: Lahey’s forceps

 

Ligature Forceps – Surtex Instruments.com" src="https://surtex-instruments.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Lahey-Dissecting-and-Ligature-Forcep.jpg" />

 

  • Lahey’s forceps are also known as right-angled forceps and mixter artery forceps.

  • The terminal part of the blade has a right angle, and it has transverse serrations.

  • It is used while dissecting the pedicle of solid organs and dissecting and passing ligature to the cystic duct and cystic artery.

Option B: Kocher’s forceps

 

 

  • Kocher’s forceps have teeth and a groove at the tip.

  • They are used to

    • Crush at the base of the appendix

    • Hold perforating vessels in mastectomy

    • Catch the bleeder in surgeries of the palm and sole

Option C: Babcock’s tissue forceps

 

  • Babcock’s tissue forceps have curved tips with fenestrations.

  • They are used in the following

    • Appendectomy

    • Gastrectomy

    • Fallopian tube

    • Ureter

Option D: Allis tissue forceps

 

  • Allis tissue forceps have a tip which has alternate teeth or grooves

  • Its uses include

    • Holding skin and subcutaneous tissue flap for retraction

    • Holding tough tissue

    • Holding skin during suturing

    • Hold cut margins of the skin

questions.text:
True about the suture material shown in the image:

A. Undergoes phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation
B. Synthetic absorbable suture
C. Has the highestaffinity for adherence to E.coli and S. Aureus
D. Absorbed in 180 days
questions.solution:
Statements B&D are true statements about Polydioxanone (PDS) sutures.

Polydioxanone (PDS):

Polydioxanone is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of polyester, poly (p-dioxanone). It is suitable for cases where extended wound support and strength are required. It retains about 70% of the initial strength for 2 weeks, 50% for 4 weeks, and 25% for 6 weeks and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely gets absorbed within 180-210 days. The absorption of this suture is reliable and predictable. It has the lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and S. Aureus. it is resistant to enzymatic degradation and phagocytosis.

Polydioxanone (PDS):

Suture Types Raw material Tensile strength retention in vivo Absorption rate Tissue reaction Contraindications Frequent uses
Polydioxanone (PDS)

Monofilament

Dyed or undyed

 Polyester polymer

Approximately 70% remains at 2 weeks

Approximately 50% remains at 4 weeks

Approximately 14% remains at 8 weeks

Hydrolysis minimal at 90 days

Complete absorption at 180 days

 Mild Not for use in association with heart valves or synthetic grafts or in situations where prolonged tissue approximation under stress is required Used as alternative for other absorbable sutures in a particular place where slightly longer wound support is required

Statement A: False statement

Polydioxanone is resistant to enzymatic degradation and phagocytosis.

Statement B: True statement

Polydioxanone is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture.

Statement C: False statement

Polydioxanone has the lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and S. Aureus.

Statement D: True statement

Polydioxanone is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely gets absorbed within 180-210 days.

Learning objective:

Surgical suture materials are used in the closure of most wounds either traumatic or surgical. The ideal suture should allow the healing tissue to recover sufficiently to keep the wound closed together once the sutures are removed or absorbed. These sutures may be either absorbable or non-absorbable based on the material it is made of. Polydioxanone is a synthetic absorbable suture. It has the lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and S. Aureus. Surgically used suture material polydioxanone undergoes hydrolysis and complete absorption. It is resistant to enzymatic degradation and phagocytosis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old menopausal woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of a breast lump in her left breast that has gradually grown and has been associated with mild pain and itching for the last 6 months. On examination, a 3 cm breast mass is found in her left breast with axillary lymph node involvement. Her left breast is mildly swollen and edematous. She is diagnosed with locally advanced breast cancer. She has no prior personal history of any cancer or family history of breast cancer or any other cancer in her family. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sporadic breast cancer

  • The most common cause of breast cancer is due to sporadic mutation.
  • A sporadic mutation is usually the cause of breast cancer in patients who do not have a family history of breast cancer or familial cancer syndromes such as Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • The table given below depicts the most common causes of breast cancer based on their incidence in the general population
Breast cancer Incidence
Sporadic breast cancer 65-75 %
Familial breast cancer 20-30 %
Hereditary breast cancer 5-10 %
BRCA1 mutation 45%
BRCA 2 mutation 35%
p53 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome) mutation 1%
STK11/LKB1a (Peutz-Jeghers syndrome), PTEN (Cowden disease), MSH2/MLH1a ( Muir-Torre syndrome), Ataxia telangiectasia  <1%
Unknown 20%

Option A: PTEN gene mutation (Cowden disease)

  • Mutations in the PTEN gene cause Cowden disease.
  • A rare inherited disorder characterized by the presence of many benign growths called hamartomas and an increased risk of cancer.
  • Hamartomas form in many body parts, especially the skin, mouth, and gastrointestinal tract. Other benign tumors may also occur in the breast, thyroid, uterus, soft tissues, and brain. 

Option C: p53 gene mutation

  • p53 is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • Mutations in the p53 gene may cause cancer cells to grow and spread in the body.
  • Mutations in the p53 gene cause a genetic condition called as Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • It can cause ovarian, esophageal, colorectal, head and neck, larynx, lung cancers, malignant melanomas, invasive cervical cancer, and leukemias.

Option D: BRCA1/ BRCA2 gene mutation

  • These genes are most commonly affected in hereditary breast and ovarian cancers.
  • They usually run in families, and more than one family member is affected by breast or ovarian cancer.

Option E: Familial breast cancer

  • Familial breast cancer occurs in patients with one or more family members affected by breast, ovarian, or related cancer, such as primary peritoneal cancer.
  • In familial breast cancer, gene abnormalities play a minor role in the risk of breast cancer, whereas, in hereditary forms such as BRCA1/BRCA2, gene mutations have a significant impact.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his deformities. The mother explains that at the time of birth, his weight was more than normal, and she had delivery complications during that time which she did not remember. A diagnosis of Erb's paralysis is made after a thorough evaluation. Which of the following is likely to be present in this patient?


	Loss of abduction of the arm
	Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
	Loss of sensation in the medial two fingers
	Loss of extension of the elbow
questions.solution:
Options A:  1 and 2

  •  Erb's palsy, in which there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid
  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm, and Loss of flexion (not extension) and supination of the forearm.
  • It is caused by injury to C5, C6, and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.
  • Also known as Policeman/Waiter/Porter’s tip hand
  • Arm: adducted and medially rotated
  • Forearm: extended and pronated
  • The arm hangs limply by the side
  • Lost movements—All movements opposite to the deformity
  • Actions that would be lost:
    • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
    • Loss of flexion and supination of the forearm.

Option B: 3 and 4

Option C: All except 4

Option D: All are correct

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the hospital due to right wrist pain. Earlier today, during a baseball game, he landed forcefully on his outstretched right hand with the palm facing down. Since then, the patient has had right wrist pain and swelling. He has had partial relief with acetaminophen and the local application of ice packs, but the pain still limits his activities. The patient's medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows mild swelling at the dorsum of the right wrist. There is maximal tenderness proximal to the base of the first metacarpal, and the pain worsens with radial deviation of the wrist. Radiographs of the wrist in multiple views reveal no fracture or dislocation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Thumb spica splint and repeat radiography in 10 days

questions.solution:
Option E: Thumb spica splint and repeat radiography in 10 days

  • Scaphoid fractures are the most common carpal bone fractures.
  • They frequently result from falls onto an outstretched hand that causes axial compression or wrist hyperextension.
  • The arterial supply to the scaphoid (from the radial artery) enters through foramina in the bone's distal pole before proceeding to the proximal pole.
  • The scaphoid fracture can disrupt the flow to the proximal segment, leading to avascular necrosis and nonunion.
  • Scaphoid fractures are characterized by tenderness in the anatomic snuffbox, a finding that has a high sensitivity for fracture and warrants additional evaluation with imaging.
    • The snuffbox is a shallow depression at the dorsoradial wrist bounded medially by the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus and laterally by the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis Brevis.
  • X-ray at the time of injury has low sensitivity for scaphoid fracture.
  • Therefore, if initial x-rays are negative, a CT scan or MRI of the wrist is recommended to confirm the fracture.
  • As an alternative, the wrist can be immobilized briefly in a thumb spica splint, followed by repeat imaging in 7-10 days.
  • Either approach can be considered, repeat x-ray is associated with lower up-front costs, whereas MRI may allow for an earlier return to normal activity.

Option A: Analgesics and physical therapy

  • Analgesics can be given for pain management.
  • Physical therapy is not recommended for scaphoid fractures.

Option B: Local anesthetic and corticosteroid injection

  • Steroid injection will not heal the scaphoid fracture but will exacerbate this condition.

Option D: Synovial fluid aspiration and analysis

  • Synovial fluid aspiration and analysis are indicated for septic arthritis, not scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He could neither straighten his leg nor extend it. A CT scan of his knee is given below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Wire fixation

  • The CT scan of the patient shows a comminuted transverse fracture of the patella
  • Tension band wiring (TBW) would be the answer if it were present in options (Open reduction and internal fixation with tension band wiring)
  • K-wire is used to fixate the fractured segments of the bone
  • It is placed in a vertical figure of eight.
  • The tension provided by the wire causes early healing of the fractured bone.

Option A: Excision of a small segment

  • In Comminuted Transverse Fracture of the Patella
    • The bone has shattered into three or more pieces.
    • It can be stable or unstable.
    • Some bone pieces may be too small to reconnect when it is unstable and must be removed in surgery.

Option C: Plaster cylinder

  • Undisplaced patellar fractures with minimal joint incongruity and intact extensor retinaculum can be treated by cylinder cast.
  • ORIF and band wiring treat the comminuted transverse fracture of the patella.

Option D: Patellectomy

  • Patellectomy treats severely comminuted fractures where the reduction of the fragments is difficult.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of discomfort and swelling of the right foot for 2 days. He does not have any pain but complains of a burning sensation in both of his feet for several months. He does not recall any trauma to the foot. He has not visited a doctor in the past 20 years. He does not smoke but occasionally consumes alcohol in social gatherings. Vital signs are within normal limits. Foot examination shows localized, unilateral erythematous swelling of the right ankle joint. Neurologic examination of the lower extremities shows impaired vibratory, light touch, and position senses with loss of bilateral ankle reflex. The rest of the neurologic examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Diabetes

NEUROPATHIC JOINT DISEASE/CHARCOT'S JOINT:

Neuropathic arthropathy, called Charcot's joint disease, is a denervation-induced degeneration of the body's weight-bearing joints.

  • It is progressive destructive arthritis arising from loss of pain sensation and proprioception (position sense).
  • When joints are denervated, no sensations are received from them, leading to continued use of injured or traumatic joints causing neuropathic arthropathy.
  • So, these joints lack normal reflex safeguards against abnormal stress or injury, resulting in repeated microtrauma.
  • The most common cause: Diabetes
  • The affected joint shows signs of inflammation, erythema, warmth, and swelling, but the pain is absent in ⅓ of cases.
  • Commonly involved joints are the tarsometatarsal joints and ankle joints of the foot. Midfoot involvement causes collapsed arch, resulting in rocker bottom foot deformity.

Option A: Leprosy

  • Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, an acid-fast, rod-shaped bacillus

  • Joint involved in leprosy: Hand and foot joints

Option B: Tabes dorsalis

  • Tabes dorsalis is a slow degeneration of the nerve cells and nerve fibers that carry sensory information to the brain

  • Tabes dorsalis: The knee joint is most common followed the  by hip, ankle, and lumbar spine

Option D: Traumatic nerve injury

  • Nerve injury can cause neuropathic joints.
  • However, this patent most likely has non-traumatic nerve involvement.

questions.text: Identify the airway tube in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Option D: Nasopharyngeal tube

  • The patient mentioned above is semi-conscious and has an intact gag reflex. The image shown is of the nasogastric tube, which is most suitable for this patient.
  • Nasopharyngeal tube: The nasopharyngeal airway resembles shortened tracheal tube with a flange at the outer end to prevent it from completely passing into the nares.
  • The length of a nasal airway can be estimated as the distance from the nares to the meatus of the ear and should be approximately 2–4 cm longer than oral airways.
  • Nasopharyngeal airways are helpful in the:
    • Semi-conscious patients have intact gag reflexes, making the pharyngeal airway difficult as they need frequent nasal tracheal suctioning patients who clench their jaw.

Option A: Endotracheal tube

Option B: Tracheostomy tube

Option C: Oropharyngeal tube

questions.text: During the surgery for meningomyelocele at birth, strict neurological monitoring is done by the anesthesiologist. Which of the following evoked responses are least likely to be affected during anesthesia?

choices.text: Somatosensory evoked response from the median nerve
Somatosensory evoked response from the posterior tibial nerve

questions.solution:
Option B: Brainstem evoked response

  • An evoked potential/response is an electrical potential recorded from the nervous system following a stimulus.
  • It is done under general anaesthesia, so evoked potential least affected by anaesthetic agents is particularly monitored.
  • The auditory evoked potential is least affected by general anaesthesia.
  • Auditory evoked potentials (AEPs) are used to trace the signal produced by a sound via the ascending auditory pathway.
    • The evoked potential is created in the cochlea, goes along the cochlear nerve, via the cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain, onto the medial geniculate body, and finally to the cortex.
  • Brainstem auditory evoked potentials are small AEPs noted in response to an auditory stimulus from electrodes on the scalp.
  • AEPs serve to the assessment of the functioning of the auditory system and neuroplasticity.
    • They are used to diagnose learning disabilities in children, aiding in the development of tailored educational programs for those with hearing and cognition problems.
  • The brainstem auditory evoked potential measures the functioning of the brain stem's auditory nerve and auditory pathways.
  • The short latency BAEP is primarily used for clinical reasons. The test is performed with the patient under either sedation or general anaesthesia.
  • The most frequent uses of the BAEP are in multiple sclerosis and acoustic neuroma. It is a useful screening test, though it has some limitations.

Option A: Visual evoked response

  • Visual evoked potentials are recorded after monocular stimulation with recording electrodes over the occipital, parietal, and central scalp.
  • These are cortical somatosensory evoked responses that vary with the type of stimulus, part of the retina stimulated, degree of pupil dilation, and patient’s attention level.
  • These are the least commonly used evoked response monitoring techniques intraoperatively.

Option C: Somatosensory evoked response from the median nerve

  • The nerve is stimulated at the wrist to record median nerve somatosensory evoked potentials (SEPs). The anode is placed just proximal to the palmar crease, and the cathode is placed between the tendons of the palmaris longus muscle, 3cm proximal to the anode.
  • Ulnar nerve SEPs are preferred to median nerve SEPs for assessing the lower cervical spinal cord, especially during intraoperative monitoring when this part of the spinal cord is at risk.

Option D: Somatosensory evoked response from the posterior tibial nerve

  • For recording the posterior tibial nerve SEPs, the nerve is stimulated at the ankle, with the cathode midway between the Achilles tendon and the medial malleolus and the anode 3cm distal to the cathode.
  • In the lower limb, posterior tibial SEPs are generally preferred because they are larger and produce less patient movement intraoperatively.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents in the emergency department with sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain and nausea one hour ago. She appears diaphoretic and pale. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness on abdominal examination. The pelvic examination shows a normal vagina, cervix, and uterus with right adnexal tenderness. Why should the dose of local anaesthetics for a peripheral nerve block be decreased in this patient?

choices.text: Preferential perfusion of vital organs in shock predisposes more to local anaesthetics toxicity.
Sensitivity of voltage-gated channel increases in shock

questions.solution:
Option A: Preferential perfusion of vital organs in shock predisposes more to local anaesthetics toxicity

  • The patient is of reproductive age, sexually active, uses OCPs inconsistently, and menstrual cycle is overdue about two weeks; the acute onset of abdominal pain, right adnexal tenderness, diaphoresis, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension suggests that the patient is in hypovolemic shock due to ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • In hypovolemic shock, there is preferential perfusion of vital organs, so whatever drug is intravascularly absorbed goes to vital organs CNS and CVS and causes systemic toxicity. So dose reduction is necessary to avoid systemic toxicity.
  • The plasma content of the local anaesthetic is determined by the rate of tissue distribution and the rate of clearance of the drug.
  • The rate and extent of systemic absorption depend on the site of injection, the dose, and the intrinsic pharmacokinetic properties of the drug.
  • After administration, the drug's plasma concentration is paralleled by an initial high uptake into the lungs and the distribution of the local anaesthetic to highly perfused tissues ( brain, heart, kidneys).
  • Lipid solubility is important in this redistribution and a primary determinant of intrinsic local anaesthetic potency.
  • After distributing into the highly perfused tissues, it is redistributed into less well-perfused tissues(Skeletal muscles and fat).
  • Consideration of cardiac output is important for describing the overall tissue distribution.
  • Patient-related factors - Age, Cardiovascular status, and hepatic function influences the absorption and resultant plasma concentration.
  • Protein binding also influences the distribution and excretion. Less protein-bound drugs will give an increased proportion of active forms of local anaesthetic.
  • Protein binding parallels the lipid solubility of local anaesthetic and is inversely related to the plasma concentration of the drug.
  • The risk factors for developing LAST (Local Anesthetic systemic toxicity):
    • Drug
    • Patient factors( age, pregnancy, renal disease, cardiac disease and hepatic dysfunction)

  • Drug:

    • The cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio is "the ratio of drug dose which is required to cause catastrophic cardiovascular collapse to the medicine dose required to produce seizures."
    •  A low cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio can be associated with more cardiotoxic agents, while L.A.s with a higher cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio have a greater safety margin.
    • This is due to the earlier presentation of CNS features can expedite earlier diagnosis of LAST before cardiovascular collapse ensues.
    • Ropivacaine and levobupivacaine, for example, have a higher cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio than racemic bupivacaine, so it seems logical to preferentially use these medications when long-acting L.A.s are desired. Vigilance is always required, however, as all L.A. drugs may cause LAST.

  • Patient factors: Age

    • Patients with old age have consistently been shown to be at a higher risk of LAST.
    • Newborn infants have immature hepatic enzyme systems, and elimination is prolonged.
    • The potential for toxicity with lidocaine infusions is also increased by the accumulation of its principal metabolite, monoethylglycinexylidide(MEGX), which can cause seizures.

  • Pregnancy:

    • The pregnancy effects on local anaesthetic potency can reflect a combined effect of mechanical factors in pregnancy and (dilated epidural veins decrease the volume of the epidural and subarachnoid spaces) direct effects of hormones, especially progesterone, on the susceptibility of the nerves to conduction blockade.
    • Hormone changes are more important than these two as the susceptibility is noted in the first trimester itself before gross changes in vascular dimensions of epidural or subarachnoid spaces occur.
    • So the dose should be reduced in all stages of pregnancy.

  • Renal disease:

    • Patients with severe renal disease not only have hyperdynamic circulation and reduced clearance of L.A.s but also have an increased α1-acid glycoprotein concentration.
    • As a result, free plasma concentrations are highly unchanged, and dose reduction is mostly unnecessary unless the patient is uremic with metabolic acidosis.

  • Cardiac disease:

    • Dose reduction is unnecessary in mild to moderate heart failure, where tissue perfusion can be preserved, but it is recommended in severe heart failure.
    • The rate of disappearance of lignocaine from blood markedly prolonged in patients with congestive cardiac failure

  • Hepatic dysfunction:

    • Decreased hepatic blood flow are impaired hepatic enzyme function can produce an elevation of blood levels of aminoamide local anaesthetics. So dose reduction is necessary.

Option B: Drugs cannot be metabolized

  • In hypovolemic shock, the drug metabolizes and enters the vital organs.
  • The high dose or the normal dose of anaesthetic can lead to systemic toxicity.

Option C: Sensitivity of voltage-gated channel increases in shock

  • The sensitivity of voltage-gated channels decreases in hypovolemic shock.
  • So that the anaesthetic or any intravenous drug can perfuse and enter the vital organs more easily.

Option D: All of the above

  • In hypovolemic shock, there is preferential perfusion of vital organs, so whatever drug is intravascularly absorbed goes to vital organs CNS and CVS and causes systemic toxicity.
  • So dose reduction is necessary to avoid systemic toxicity.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida, term, severe pre-eclamptic woman on magnesium therapy was posted for emergency lower segment caesarean section under general anaesthesia with rapid sequence induction (RSI). Neuromuscular monitoring with a peripheral nerve stimulator was used, and the maintenance doses were given accordingly during the intraoperative period. At the end of the surgery, when the train of four (TOF) ratio > 0.9, the patient was reversed with Inj. Neostigmine and glycopyrrolate were then extubated. Which of the following anaesthetic shows the absence of fade in TOF response?
questions.solution:
Option A: Succinylcholine

  • Depolarising neuromuscular blockers (Succinylcholine) do not show fade in a train of four response.
  • Non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers (Vecuronium, Mivacurium, Rocuronium) show fade in a train of four response.
  • Single twitch:  Application of a single supramaximal stimulus every 10 seconds. The twitch height falls steadily to zero as the nicotinic postsynaptic receptor occupancy increases from 25% or 80% up to 100%
  • Train of four: Train of four stimulation is the application of four supramaximal stimuli, each similar to the single twitch, administered at 2Hz every 0.5 seconds. The degree of neuromuscular blockade was assessed by calculating the ratio of fourth (T4) and first(T1) measured twitch heights(T4/T1)
  • Post-tetanic count: It describes counting responses to single twitch stimulation following tetanic stimulation of 50Hz or 100Hz for 5 seconds. This method can produce a response at relatively high levels of receptor occupancy under a post-tetanic count of less than 5, indicating profound neuromuscular blockade.
  • Double burst stimulation: It is introduced to remove the manual assessment of fade. This consists of two tetanic bursts at 50Hz each burst is separated by 750milliseconds, two contractions (T1, T2). The ratio of T2/T1 is more sensitive in detecting fade than the train of four ratios.

Option B: Mivacurium

  • Mivacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; it shows a fade of a train of four response.

Option C: Vecuronium

  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; it shows the fade of a train of four responses.

Option D: Rocuronium

  • Rocuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; it shows a fade of a train of four responses.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband 30 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Over the past 3 months, she has had recurrent headaches and worsening early-morning vomiting. She has no personal or family history of a seizure disorder. A brain MRI is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Glioblastoma

  • The given image is a contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain as the grey matter is white and the white matter is black, with CSF appearing dark.
  • The given image shows an intraparenchymal aggressive lesion with a thick wall and area of necrosis causing compression of ventricles which are all features of Glioblastoma multiforme.
  • Glioblastoma multiforme has enhancing lesions with some areas of fibrosis that can cross the midline and invade the corpus callosum, also called a "Butterfly shaped lesion”.

  • Characteristic features on MRI and CT
    • Irregularly shaped, homogeneous mass.
    • Perifocal vasogenic edema
    • Mass Effect: midline shift, ventricular distortion 
    • Possibly hemorrhage
  • Glioblastoma Multiforme is derived from glial cells (e.g., astrocytes).
  • Glial fibrillary acid protein (GFAP) is an important diagnostic marker for astrocytomas; it is almost always positive in glioblastoma multiforme.
  • Biopsy shows dense, pleomorphic anaplastic cells that form pseudopalisades due to central necrosis or hemorrhage and microvascular proliferation.

Option A: Ependymoma

    • Ependymoma arises from the ependymal cell of the floor of the fourth ventricle and foramen of Luschka and, less commonly, from the roof.
    • 70 % are infratentorial and 30% are supratentorial.
    • Male > Female
    • An important clinical feature is a non-communicating hydrocephalus causing features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema, headache)
    • Imaging shows an intra-parenchymal tumor with calcifications and cystic components due to necrosis and hemorrhage.

    • It is a childhood primary tumor.

  • Biopsy shows
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes 
  • Rod-shaped bodies (blepharoplasts) near the nucleus.

 

Option B : Meningioma

    • Dural-based tumor.
    • It is extra-axial & intradural.
    • It has the dural tail sign.
    • On myelography, with contrast - shows a meniscus-like appearance
    • Also shows the "Mother-in-law” sign, a contrast enhancement pattern that shows early enhancement and delayed washout.
    • Meningiomas are usually asymptomatic. However, convulsions or focal neurologic signs may be present.
    • Histology displays psammoma bodies and spindle cells concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern.

Option D : Hemangioblastoma

    • Benign, highly vascularized neoplasm
    • Associated with Von Hippel Lindau syndrome.
    • MRI shows a sharply demarcated intra-parenchymal cystic mass with a non-enhancing wall and an enhancing mural nodule in the cerebellum.
  • Biopsy shows thin-walled capillary vessels, densely packed together with scarce parenchyma.

questions.text: A 2-month-old boy was brought to the physician's office complaining of cyanosis, poor feeding, and failure to thrive for the past month. On physical examination, there is an incidental heart murmur. Which of the following describes the radiological presentation of the heart on chest x-ray in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Box-shaped heart:

Ebstein anomaly

  • Ebstein anomaly is a rare congenital abnormality involving the tricuspid valve and the right ventricle.
  • It involves the apical displacement (low insertion) of the tricuspid valve due to the atrialization of the right ventricle leading to a small-sized right ventricle.
  • This results in tricuspid regurgitation, right ventricular failure, and arrhythmia.
  • Eventually, there is gross right atrial enlargement and raised right atrial pressure.
  • The patient presents with exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and cyanosis.
  • A combination of the following causes Ebstein anomaly appearance:
    • Huge right atrium filling the entire right hemithorax (huge curved right atrial border)
    • The shelved appearance of the left cardiac contour due to the dilated right ventricular outflow tract or elevated residual right ventricle
    • Small aorta and main pulmonary artery
  • It is associated with ASD (atrial septal defect), and thus right-left shunting at the atrial level leads to cyanosis.
  • On chest-x-ray, the enlargement of the heart resembles a box shape.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Egg on the side:

  • Occurs in the Transposition of great arteries
    • Narrow mediastinum
    • Globular heart
    • “Egg on string” / “Egg on side “ appearance on X-ray

 

Option B - Snowman's appearance:

  • Occurs with Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
  • Supra cardiac TAPVC
  • "Snowman / figure of 8 /cottage loaf appearance" on x-ray

 

Option C - Boot-shaped heart:

  • Boot shaped heart is seen in Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Features of TOF:
    • Pulmonary stenosis
    • Overriding aorta
    • Membranous VSD
    • RVH
    • “Boot shaped of heart” on X-Ray​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text:
A one-month-old male newborn comes to the clinic with his mother with complaints of difficulty in breathing and swallowing. Her mother has noticed his change of voice as well. The child has become more irritable recently. He was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and is exclusively breastfed. His past medical history is significant for severe coughing episodes and vomiting. His immunization history is up to the mark. His father has eczema, and his mother has psoriasis. After baseline tests chest X-ray is formed (which is given below)



 

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Pneumomediastinum

  • Pneumomediastinum is also known as mediastinal emphysema.
  • It is characterized by the presence of air in the mediastinum.
  • It can be caused by traumatic injury or other medical causes, including too much coughing, vomiting, sneezing, etc.
  • The chest X-ray usually shows a Spinnaker sign.
  • Spinnaker sail sign lifts the thymic shadow with the lucency of air between the thymus and heart in cases Of Pneumomediastinum.
  • The spinnaker sail sign is also known as the angel wing sign.
  • The thymus is outlined by air, and the lobes are displaced laterally.

  • The thymic sail sign is the normal appearance of a thymic shadow abutting the heart shadow seen on the chest X-ray of a normal infant.

  • Signs and symptoms of a pneumomediastinum include difficulty breathing, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, change of voice, etc.
  • No treatment is usually required for Pneumomediastinum as air is absorbed from the mediastinum. If the pneumothorax is also present, then a chest tube may be placed.

Option A: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion is characterized by a fluid accumulation between two layers of pleura.
  • It is usually caused by congestive heart failure, cancer, pulmonary embolism, and pneumonia.
  • The spinnaker sail sign is not present in the pleural effusion.

Option B: Pneumothorax

  • Pneumothorax is characterized by air leakage in the space between the lungs and chest wall. It leads to the collapse of the lungs.
  • It is characterized by hypotension, tachycardia, and distended neck veins.
  • The spinnaker sail sign is not present in the pneumothorax.

Option D: Fracture of bronchus

  • It is associated with blunt chest trauma
  • Bronchoscopy is used to diagnose the condition.
  • Spinnaker sail sign is not present in the fracture of the bronchus.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female presents in OPD with complaints of pain and discomfort in her left breast from the last week. A breast examination revealed a 1.5 * 1 cm lump in the left breast, which is non-tender. She underwent surgery for invasive breast cancer 6 months ago. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to differentiate between scar tissue and residual/recurrence of a breast tumour in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: MRI

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a breast cancer survivor who developed pain in the same breast 6-month post-surgery.
  • This pain and lump can be due to either simple scar tissue or residual/recurrent breast cancer.
  • The investigation which can differentiate residual breast cancer from benign scar tissue is contrast-enhanced MRI.

Option A: Ultrasound

  • USG breast can detect breast mass, but USG cannot differentiate between scar tissue or residual/recurrent breast cancer.

Option B: Mammography

  • A mammography is a screening tool for the early detection of breast cancer, but this modality cannot differentiate between scar tissue or residual/recurrent breast cancer.

Option D: HRCT

  • High-resolution CT does not use a contrast agent, so it is very unlikely to differentiate between a simple benign scar or a malignant tumour recurrence.
  • HRCT chest is useful in detecting diseases of the lung parenchyma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea with regular cycles. On examination, the doctor explains that the pain is due to an acute retroverted uterus, which is an abnormal position of the uterus. Which of the following is responsible for maintaining the uterus in a normal anteverted position?
questions.solution:
Option D: Round ligament

  • The normal position of the uterus is anteversion.
  • The Round ligament maintains anteversion of the uterus.
  • Round Ligaments are an extension of the uterine musculature and represent the homolog of the gubernaculum testis.
  • Round ligaments extend from the uterine horn to the labia majora and thus provide major structural support to the uterus in maintaining the anteverted position
  • It travels through the inguinal canal to reach the labia majora

 

 

  • The anatomy and relevant clinical importance of various uterine ligaments are explained in the table given below:

 

 

 

LIGAMENT

CONNECTS

STRUCTURES CONTAINED

NOTES

Infundibulopelvic ligament

Ovary to lateral pelvic wall

Ovarian vessels
  • Also called suspensory ligament of ovary
  • Ovarian vessel ligation during oophorectomy risks damaging the ureter as it is close to the lateral pelvic wall

Ovarian ligament

Ovary to uterine horn

 

Derivative of gubernaculum

Round ligament

Uterine horn to labia majora

 
  • Travels through inguinal canal
  • Maintains anteversion of uterus

Broad ligament

Uterus to lateral pelvic wall

Ovary, fallopian tube, round ligament
  • Fold of peritoneum comprising the mesometrium, mesovarium and mesosalpinx

Cardinal ligament

Cervix to lateral pelvic wall

Uterine vessels
  • Condensation at the base of broad ligament
  • Uterine vessel ligation during hysterectomy risks damaging the ureter
  • Important ligament for prevention of prolapse

Uterosacral ligament

Cervix to sacrum

 
  • Important ligament for prevention of prolapse

 

 

Option A: Cardinal ligament

It extends from the cervix to the lateral pelvic wall and contains ureteral vessels. The ligation of these vessels during a hysterectomy can cause ureter injury

 

Option B: Uterosacral ligament

It is a supportive ligament that extends from the cervix to the sacrum. It is a major support ligament for prevention of prolapse but less important than round ligament for maintaining anteversion

 

Option C: Infundibulopelvic ligament

It contains ovarian vessels and is also called the ovarian suspensory ligament. It has no role in uterine support

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute lower abdominal pain for 45 minutes. She states that she has had cyclical pain for the last 6 months and has not yet attained her menarche. On examination, a painful mass is palpable in the lower abdomen with normal breast development and a tense bluish bulge is seen in the region of the hymen. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Imperforate hymen

  • This patient's symptoms of cyclical abdominal pain, tender abdominal mass, tense bulge at the hymen and amenorrhea are highly consistent with the diagnosis of imperforate hymen.
  • Imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where a hymen without an opening completely obstructs the vaginal outflow.
  • It is a serious cause of abdominal pain in females, making cyclical abdominal pain the most common symptom.
  • It also presents with amenorrhea due to failure to menstruate.
  • Menstrual blood accumulates in the vagina (hematocolpus) and uterus (hematometra) because of obstruction of the vaginal outflow due to the imperforated hymen.
  • Gynaecological examination reveals a bluish bulge at the hymen due to hematocolpus, and the abdominal pain and mass are due to hematometra.
  • It may also lead to compressive symptoms due to mechanical effects of the retained blood on the urethra, bladder, bowel, blood vessels etc.
  • It may result in urinary retention, constipation, and oedema of the legs.

Option A: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

  • Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome (MRKH) presents with primary amenorrhea with vaginal and uterine agenesis.
  • It is due to embryonic growth failure resulting in the underdevelopment of the uterus and vagina. External genitalia is normal.
  • It is not associated with cyclical abdominal pain, tender suprapubic mass or a tense bulge at the hymen.

Option C: Ashermans syndrome

  • Asherman syndrome presents with secondary amenorrhea, with no such tense bulge.
  • It occurs due to trauma to the uterine lining.

Option D: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) presents primary amenorrhea with androgen excess features.
  • It is not associated with cyclical abdominal pain, tender suprapubic mass or a tense bulge at the hymen.

questions.text: A woman is using combined oral pills containing estrogen + progesterone for 2 years regularize her menstrual cycles. The drug also prevents her from pregnancy due to all of the following mechanisms, except?
questions.solution:
Option D : Oral contraceptive pills do not interfere with placental functioning.

Options A, B, C : Mechanisms of action of oral contraceptive pill

  • Suppresses pituitary hormones, FSH and LH peak and through their suppression prevents ovulation.
  • Progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium and prevents nidation.
  • Progestogen also acts on the cervical mucus making it thick and tenacious and impenetrable by sperms.
  • Increases the tubal motility, so the fertilized egg reaches the uterine cavity before the endometrium is receptive for implantation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who is a non-smoker, non-alcoholic, and has no chronic illnesses is diagnosed with a second-degree uterovaginal prolapse. She had two previous vaginal deliveries 8 and 10 years ago. All of the following historical points could have led to the present condition, except?
questions.solution:
Option D : Episiotomy

  • The main cause of prolapse is abnormal conduct of labour.
  • Pelvic organ prolapse is uncommon in nulliparous women, and the incidence increases with increasing parity.
  • Episiotomy will not cause prolapse. In fact, it is used as a protective measure to prevent uterine prolapse in future.
  • Abnormal conduct of labor
    • Prolonged labour
    • Premature bearing down
    • Faulty instrumentation
    • Large perineal tears, cervical or muscle lacerations
    • Pudendal nerve injury

 

Option A: Precipitate labor

  • A delivery occurring within less than 2 hours of onset of labor pains is known as precipitate labor. It is associated with excessive uterine contractions and excessive perineal stretching, cervical and perineal lacerations, all of which are associated with subsequent development of prolapse.

Option B: Prolonged second stage of labor

  • It is associated with excessive perineal stretching, muscular and soft tissue injuries, all of which are associated with subsequent development of prolapse.

Option D: Premature bearing down

  • It is also associated with undue perineal stretcing and cervical lacerations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. The patient has been infertile for 3 years. The patient has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations show no abnormalities. The semen analysis of the patient is suggestive of azoospermia. FSH normal testosterone is in the normal range. Which of the following is the most probable cause of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Vas deferens obstruction

  1. This is a case of infertility in the patient who presents for fertility evaluation.
  2. The most likely cause of infertility in this patient is the obstruction of vas deferens.
  3. Normal follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and testosterone will be seen in obstructive azoospermia, such as obstruction of vas deferens.
  4. When the male vasa deferens are blocked, it prevents the sperm from entering the seminal glands or the ejaculate (semen). No sperm in the semen means no fertilization with the egg.
  5. Another cause of obstructive azoospermia is vasectomy.

Option A: Undescended testis

  • Undescended testes will have high levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

Option B: Klinefelter’s syndrome

  • Klinefelters syndrome will have
  • Testicular atrophy
  • High FSH

Option C: Kallman syndrome

  • Kallman syndrome will have:
  • Hypothalamic failure,
  • Low FSH

questions.text: An obstetrician, while performing a vaginal delivery of a 25-year-old woman, gravida 1, encounters excessive blood loss in the third stage even after infusion of oxytocin, so she inserts 4 tablets of a certain drug rectally while performing a uterine massage. This drug is found to be effective in all of the following conditions, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Option C: Menorrhagia

  • The drug referred to here is misoprostol (PGE1), used rectally to prevent and treat postpartum haemorrhage.
  • Misoprostol is not indicated in menorrhagia.

Misoprostol:

  • It is used for induction of abortion in the early pregnancy for medically induced abortions in doses ranging from 400 to 800 mcg, then also in the second trimester where abortion with prostaglandins is the mode of choice in doses from 200 to 400 mcg.
  • Also, misoprostol is an efficient way to induce labour, even with doses ranging from 25 to 50 mcg.
  • In cases of PPH, misoprostol given orally or rectally is an excellent mode of reducing bleeding and might as well be used as the most effective drug for PPH.
  • Misoprostol will act when there are prostaglandin receptors, which are more in number when there is a pregnancy in the uterus. This is not an effective drug in menorrhagia, and the vasodilator action may worsen the bleeding.

 

Option A: Missed abortion

Misoprostol can be used for induction of abortion in the early pregnancy for missed abortions in doses ranging from 400 to 800 mcgs.

Option B: Induction of labour

misoprostol is an efficient way to induce labour even with doses ranging from 25 to 50 mcgs.

Option D: Prevention of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).

  • The most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage is uterine atony can be prevented by uterine massage or uterotonic agents like oxytocin, methylergonovine, misoprost or carboprost.
  • n cases of PPH, misoprostol given orally or rectally is an excellent mode of reducing bleeding might as well be used as the most effective drug for PPH.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of primary amenorrhea. Her pelvic ultrasound revealed the presence of bilateral ovaries with a dominant follicle in the right ovary.  Which of the following could be a possible cause of the patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mayer Rokitansky kuster Hauser

  • The patient has primary amenorrhea with functional ovaries.
  • Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome (Mullerian agenesis) is congenital hypoplasia or absence of the vagina, which is a characteristic feature in combination with the abnormal or absent uterus. It is the second most common cause of primary Amenorrhea with Karyotype- 46XX.
  • MRKH is a woman with normal ovaries but no uterus.
  • Gonads and ovarian function are normal. It is responsible for normal external feminization.
  • Features include:
    • Primary amenorrhea.
    • Partial or complete absence of the vagina.
    • Wide array of uterine abnormalities.
    • Skeletal/renal and other associated abnormalities.
    • A normal female appearance and secondary sexual characteristics absent uterus.
    • Karyotype 46XX

Option A: Turner's syndrome

  • It is a disorder that affects only females, resulting when one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing.
  • Turner’s syndrome has streak ovaries.

Option C: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a genotypic male 46 XY with testes and a female phenotype (insensitivity to androgens produced by testes).                                       

Option D: Sweyer's syndrome

  • Sweyer’s syndrome is a 46 XY female whose testes are nonfunctional; hence, a default female form is made.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a fibroid uterus presents at the gynecology department for infertility follow-up. She is asymptomatic and declines treatment The doctor explains possible changes that may occur in the fibroid. What is the least likely change in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Malignant change

  • Sarcomatous degeneration(malignant transformation) is extremely rare, and the incidence is not more than 0.5%
  • Secondary Changes (Degenerations) and Complications Associated with Leiomyomas:
    • Hyaline change
    • Cystic degeneration
    • Atrophy
    • Calcareous degeneration
    • Red degeneration
    • Sarcomatous change(Rarest)
    • Torsion, haemorrhage
    • Infection/ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

Option A: Calcium deposition

  • It is a common change that occurs in the fibroid uterus.

Option C: Infection and haemorrhage

  • These may occur in fibroid uterus, not very commonly but more common than malignant change.

Option D: Atrophy

  • Atrophy is once again a common change.

questions.text: What serotype of HPV is most commonly associated with cervical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option B : More than 90% of CIN is attributed to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

Only certain types of HPV cause high-grade intraepithelial lesions and cancer

(HPV-16, -18, -31, -33, -35, -39, -45, -51, -52, -56, -58, -59, -68).

Type 16 is the most common form of HPV found in invasive cancer and in CIN 2 and CIN3;

HPV-18 is more specific than HPV-16 for invasive tumors i.e. HPV 18 is the most malignant.

Please note:

Usually, HPV infections do not persist. Most women who are exposed have no clinical evidence of disease, and the infection is eventually suppressed or eliminated.

Other women exhibit low-grade cervical lesions that mostly regress spontaneously. In the vast majority of cases, the infection will clear in 9 to 15 months. A small minority of women exposed to HPV develops persistent infection that may progress to CIN.

Option A : HPV 11 has less risk of causing invasive cervical cancer than type 16,18. It is more commonly associated with genital warts.

Risk Category

HPV Serotype

Relation to Cervical Cancer

Low

6,11

Rarely associated with cervical cancer and mostly causes genital warts

Intermediate

,

Present in around  cases and are rarer than the high-risk serotypes

High

Present in around 75% of cases, the commonest types being 16 and 18

Option C : Type 31 is associated with increased risk of cervical cancer, however risk is less than type 16.

Option D : Type 18 is associated with increased risk of cervical cancer, however risk is less than type 16. Type 18 is more specifically associated with cervical cancer than type 16.

questions.text: What is the most beneficial screening test for a 21-year-old female who has been sexually active for the past three years, has no familial history of cancer or cardiac diseases?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pap smear

  • There is an increased risk of CA cervix due to the early age at the first sexual intercourse.
  • A Pap smear should be done as a screening test.

Time to do PAP smear:

  • Any women >21 yrs of age.
  • Any woman 3 years after 1st sexual exposure in India
  • From 21 to 29, sexually active women should have cytology every 3 years.
  • From 30 to 65 years: Co-test (PAP+ HPV): If negative, then 5 yearly. If only cytology did, then once in 3 years if cytology is negative.
  • High-risk females (who have recently been treated for cervical dysplasia or are HIV positive) should undergo a Pap smear examination annually, provided the previous few consecutive Pap smears are normal.
  • After 65 years: no more Pap smear if 3 cytology are negative or 2 co-tests are negative.

Option A: Colonoscopy

  • Average risk individuals must be screened at age 50-75 years while those with positive family history must be screened from 40 years with colonoscopy and FIT. This patient here doesn't fit in either category.

Option B: Mammography

  • The USPSTF recommends that women who are 50-74 years and are at average risk for breast cancer must get a mammogram every two years. Women with positive family history must be screened earlier. This patient here doesn't fit in the age criteria nor has a positive family history.

Option D: Pelvic scan

  • The pelvic scan is done if the patient has any symptoms of pelvic pathology.
  • It is not used for screening of cervical cancer.
  • Ovarian or endometrial cancers are not screened for in normal population

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1L1 at 24 weeks presents for a routine check-up. Patient has no major complains except for occassional palpitations. Her blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. There is no pedal edema or breathlessness, and her ECG is normal. All of the following are physiological changes in pregnancy causing such presentation, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increase in peripheral vascular resistance

  • Peripheral vascular resistance decreases in pregnancy.
  • Cardiac output increases as early as the fifth week and reflects a reduced systemic vascular resistance and an increased heart rate.
  • Compared with the pre-pregnancy measurements, brachial systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, and central systolic blood pressure are all significantly lower 6 to 7 weeks from the last menstrual period.

Option A: Increase in intravascular volume

  • The well-known hypervolemia associated with normal pregnancy averages 40% to 45% above the non-pregnant blood volume after 32 to 34 weeks.
  • The maternal blood volume begins to increase during the first trimester. 
  • By the 12 menstrual weeks, the plasma volume increased approximately 15% as compared to the pre-pregnancy state.

Option B: Increase in cardiac output

  • During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease while blood volume and basal metabolic rate increase.
  • As a result, cardiac output at rest increases significantly beginning in early pregnancy when measured in the lateral recumbent position.

Option C: Increase in heart rate

  • The resting pulse rate increases by approximately l0 beats/min during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, G1P0, presents to the antenatal clinic for her first ultrasound examination at 10 weeks of gestation. She is eager to know the estimated age of her developing fetus. Which parameter would you rely on for the most accurate estimation of fetal age during early pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option C : CRL is the best USG parameter to determine gestational age in first trimester

Crown rump length - it is the longest straight line measurement of the embryo from the other margin of cephalic pole to rump mid-sagittal plane with fetus in neutral , non fixed position

  • - Best seen on TVS
  • - Overall best USG parameter to assess the fetal age
  • - Ideal time to measures CRL is 7 – 10 weeks
  • - can be done upto 14 weeks

Option A : Uterine size on pelvic examination only provides a rough estimate of period of gestation.

Option B : Serum HCG levels cannot detect gestational age.

Option D : Progesterone levels also do not detect gestational age. Serum progesterone estimation can be helpful in assessing whether the pregnancy is healthy or is failing and needs progesterone support.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female complains of heavy vaginal bleeding. She delivered a male baby 3 days ago. She denies any pain or fever. A diagnosis of postpartum hemorrhage is made. Which of the following is not a cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Option A:

This patient has presented with secondary PPH. Placenta previa causes antepartum hemorrhage.

Placenta previa

  • Features of Placenta previa:
  • Sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding
  • Usually occurs during the 3rd trimester (before rupture of the membranes), stops spontaneously after 1–2 hours, and recurs during birth
  • Often causes preterm delivery (∼ 45% of cases)
  • Soft, non-tender uterus, Usually no fetal distress

Primary postpartum haemorrhage:
Haemorrhage occurs within 24 hours following the birth of the baby.

Causes:

1) Atonic uterus (commonest cause) – 80 %

2) Retained tissue

3) Traumatic

4) Blood coagulopathy 

Secondary postpartum haemorrhage occurs after 24 hours

Cause:

1) Retained bit of placenta ( most common cause )

2) Endometritis

3) Infection and separation of slough over a deep>4) Secondary haemorrhage from c-section

5) Withdrawal bleeding following estrogen therapy for suppression of lactation

6) Chorioepithelioma

Option B: Retained parts of the placenta

  • Retained pieces of conception or placenta can cause PPH

Option C: Endometritis

  • Endometritis is one of the causes of postpartum haemorrhage

Option D: Placental polyp

  • A placental polyp can bleed after the delivery.

questions.text: Pregnancy involves an extensive change in vessels of the uterus and placenta by means of trophoblast invasion. Physiological changes include which of the following:

choices.text: Conversion of Low resistance to high resistance.
Conversion of High resistance to low resistance

questions.solution:
Option B : Remodeling converts narrow-lumen, muscular spiral arteries into dilated, low-resistance uteroplacental vessels by means of trophoblast invasion into spiral arteries.

Uteroplacental vasculature development proceeds in two waves or stages.

The first wave occurs before 12 weeks post fertilization and consists of invasion and modification of spiral arteries up to the border between the decidua and myometrium.

The second wave is between 12 and 16 weeks and involves some invasion of the intramyometrial segments of spiral arteries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation presents in emergency department with vaginal bleeding. The uterus is relaxed. On per-vaginum speculum examination, blood is found in the vagina, and the cervical canal is closed. Her vitals are BP=90/70, pulse=105/min and respiratory rate = 17/min.  Her abdominal Ultrasound (USG) shows complete placenta previa (grade 4). All of the following are appropriate next steps, except?

choices.text: Arrange 4 units of packed red blood cells
