Monitor the urine output strictly from now

questions.solution:
Option A: Administer intramuscular terbutaline

  • Bleeding from a placenta previa at 36 weeks needs no conservative treatment as the fetal lungs mature after 34 weeks.
  • The patient, in this case, will be vitally stabilized and then proceed for an emergency c-section as she is already at 36 weeks of gestation.
  • Terbutaline or any other tocolysis is contraindicated in Placenta previa management.
  • Terbutaline is associated with maternal tachycardia and vasodilation.
  • The actively bleeding patient should be resuscitated with intravenous fluids while blood is cross-matched for possible transfusion.
  • A Foley catheter is placed because the urinary output reflects the patient's volume status.

Option B: Arrange 4 units of packed red blood cells

  • This patient is actively bleeding and, unless appropriately managed, can develop into haemorrhagic shock at any point.
  • Patients with massive haemorrhagic shock should be given cross-matched blood transfusion as earliest as possible to avoid coagulopathy.
  • The patient is actively bleeding, so as part of in-hospital management, cross-matched blood should be available for her if indicated.

Option C: Administer an intravenous fluid

  • The patient is actively bleeding and has lowered blood pressure and raised pulse, indicating low blood volume.
  • She should therefore be immediately given IV fluid bolus to restore circulatory volume until definitive management of her underlying bleeding cause, i.e. placenta previa, is addressed.​​​​​​​

Option D: Monitor the urine out output strictly from now

  • Patients with or at risk of haemorrhagic shock are passed with a Foleys catheter to monitor urine output.
  • Urine output is an indicator of tissue perfusion.
  • Urine output of more than 0.5ml/kg of body weight is desirable.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A woman presents at 30 weeks with a deranged oral glucose tolerance test(OGTT). She has no past or family history of diabetes and her fasting blood sugar in the first trimester was 78 mg/dL. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Macrosomia

  • A deranged oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) late in pregnancy suggests Gestational Diabetes Mellitus. A normal fasting blood sugar (FBS) in the first trimester is not indicative of overt diabetes.
  • Fetal overgrowth is more typical of gestational diabetes.
  • Maternal hyperglycemia prompts fetal hyperinsulinemia and this, in turn, stimulates excessive somatic growth.
  • Except for the brain, most fetal organs are affected by the macrosomia that characterizes the fetus of a diabetic mother.

 

Option B: Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)

  • Maternal hyperglycemia prompts fetal hyperinsulinemia and this, in turn, stimulates excessive somatic growth.
  • Except for the brain, most fetal organs are affected by the macrosomia that characterizes the fetus of a diabetic mother.
  • Therefore, IUGR is not associated with gestational diabetes.

 

Option C: Postmaturity

  • A pregnancy continuing beyond the 2 weeks of the expected delivery date (>294 days) is called postmaturity or post-term pregnancy.
  • Gestational diabetes is associated with macrosomia but not with postmaturity.

 

Option D: Congenital malformation

  • Congenital malformations are associated with overt diabetes. 
  • It affects the foetus in the first trimester during the process of organogenesis.
  • Gestational diabetes manifests during the second trimester of pregnancy due to insulin resistance affecting the human placental lactogen hormone. Therefore it is not associated with congenital malformations.

questions.text: An HIV-infected pregnant woman under your care presents for her 36-week prenatal visit. She has been taking antiretroviral therapy throughout pregnancy. Laboratory results show mild anaemia. Which of the following points is true regarding the mode of delivery in HIV-infected pregnant women?

choices.text: All HIV-infected women should have a cesarean delivery.
She may have a vaginal delivery only if her viral load is < 100 copies/mL
If her viral load is >1,000 copies/mL, schedule a cesarean delivery for 38 weeks
She can deliver vaginally regardless of the viral load because she is on highly active antiretroviral therapy

questions.solution:
Option C: If her viral load is >1,000 copies/mL, schedule a cesarean delivery for 38 weeks.

  • Human immunodeficiency virus is a retrovirus, enveloped RNA virus, containing 2 molecules of RNA. It infects and replicates in CD4+ T cells and macrophages, leading to eventual immune system dysfunction, opportunistic infections and malignancy, which is also called acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
  • It is transmitted by blood, sexual fluids and breast milk.
  • Pathophysiology: HIV binds to CD4 receptors on helper T cells, macrophages and monocytes by its gp120 envelope and replicate in these cells. The new virions are released that infect new CD4 cells. The continued progress of the infection leads to decreased immune function. It has a reverse transcriptase enzyme, which produces DNA copies from viral RNA. It has no proofreading ability, so multiple mutations occur, accounting for treatment resistance.
  • HIV testing:
    • ELISA for HIV antibody and antigen (p24): Very high sensitivity and specificity.
    • Rapid point-of care-testing.
    • Viral load: Quantification of viral RNA.
    • Nucleic acid amplification test/ Viral PCR: It is a qualitative test for the presence of viral RNA. It is used to test for vertical transmission in neonates as the transfer of maternal antibodies can affect ELISA antibody testing.
    • CD4 count: Used to monitor immune system function.
  • Antiretroviral therapy:
    • It is recommended for everyone with HIV, regardless of CD4 count, and aims to reduce viral load to undetectable levels by standard laboratory techniques. It leads to slowed disease progression and recovery of the immune system.
    • It includes the following medications:
      • Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs): Include Zidovudine, Abacavir, Lamivudine, Didanosine etc. These inhibit reverse transcriptase and conversion of viral RNA and DNA.
      • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs): Delavirdine, Efavirenz, Nevirapine etc. These also inhibit reverse transcriptase enzymes. Nevirapine is safe during pregnancy. 
      • Integrase inhibitors: Raltegravir, Bictegravir. These prevent HIV DNA integration into host DNA by blocking the integrase enzyme.
      • Protease inhibitors: Ritonavir, Indinavir, Darunavir etc. These prevent the maturation of new viruses.
      • Fusion inhibitor: Enfuvirtide. Binds gp41 and inhibits viral entry into the host cell.
      • Entry inhibitor: Maraviroc. Binds CCR5 on the surface of T-cells and inhibits interaction with gp120.
    • For treatment of a patient with HIV, consider 2 NNRTIs with one of these:
      • Ritonavir boosted protease inhibitors.
      • NNRTIs.
      • Integrase inhibitor.
    • Decreased adherence to antiretroviral therapy leads to drug resistance and disease progression. So, adherence support is mandatory.
  • Management of a pregnant woman with HIV: ​​​​​​​
    • The risks of mother-to-child transmission of HIV are related to:
      • ​​​​​​​Increased risk is associated with: advanced maternal HIV disease, high maternal plasma viral load, low CD4 lymphocyte counts, chorioamnionitis, coexisting viral infections (Hepatitis B and C), preterm delivery and breastfeeding.
      • Decreased risk is associated with: low viral counts at the time of delivery, antiretroviral therapy, delivery by Cesarean section and exclusive formula feeding.
    • Interventions that can be done to reduce vertical transmission include:
      • ​​​​​​​Antiretroviral therapy is given antenatally and intrapartum to the mother and the neonate for the first 4-6 weeks of life.
      • Delivery by elective cesarean section in the presence of high viral load.
      • Avoidance of breastfeeding.
    • To prevent HIV transmission from mother to child, triple agent antiretroviral therapy is given to all HIV+ pregnant women irrespective of their gestational age of presentation, CD4 counts and stage of the disease.
    • Obstetric interventions such as amniotomy, fetal scalp electrodes, fetal blood sampling and instrumental deliveries should be avoided in HIV+ pregnant women.
  • There is no particular benefit of doing a cesarean to reduce mother-to-child transmission. However, there are some indications for a cesarean section in an HIV+ mother:
    • ​​​​​​​A cesarean section is recommended when the viral load is heavy >1000 copies/ml.
    • Cesarean delivery is indicated when the woman takes zidovudine (ZDV) monotherapy at or beyond 36 weeks of gestation.
    • Cesarean delivery is also recommended in women with coinfection with hepatitis C, as the risk of transmission is higher.
    • Women with a very high viral load >1000 copies/ml should be given IV zidovudine at the time of delivery if they are undergoing an elective cesarean section or present with spontaneous rupture of membranes.
    • The choice between elective and cesarean delivery can be selected based on the viral loads:
      • ​​​​​​​HIV RNA >1000 copies/ml - c-section at 38 weeks can be done.
      • HIV RNA <1000 copies/ml - vaginal delivery can be done.

Option A: All HIV-infected women should have a cesarean delivery.

  • Cesarean delivery in HIV-positive pregnant women is to be performed only  when the viral loads are high.
  • When the viral loads are low, elective vaginal delivery can be performed.

Option B: She may have a vaginal delivery only if her viral load is < 100 copies/mL.

  • Vaginal delivery in HIV-positive pregnant women can be performed when the viral load is less than 1000 copies/ml.

Option D: She can deliver vaginally regardless of the viral load because she is on highly active antiretroviral therapy.

  • The mode of delivery depends on the viral load; if the viral load is high cesarean section can be performed, and elective vaginal delivery is performed when the viral load is low.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing surgery for an unruptured, live tubal pregnancy in a 23-year-old primigravida. He decided to conserve the tube by opening it to remove the gestational products, then leaving it unsutered. This surgical technique is known as?
questions.solution:
Option B : Salpingostomy:

This procedure is used to remove a small unruptured pregnancy.

A 10 to 15 mm linear incision is made with unipolar needle cautery on the antimesenteric border over the pregnancy.

The products usually will extrude from the incision and can be carefully removed or flushed out using high-pressure irrigation that more thoroughly removes the trophoblastic tissue.

Small bleeding sites are controlled with needlepoint electrocoagulation or laser, and the incision is left unsutured to heal by secondary intention.

SURGICAL MANAGEMENT OPTIONS IN UNRUPTURED ECTOPIC PREGNANCY

  • Linear Salpingostomy
    • Incision is given on the anti-mesentric border (linear) & take out ectopic & leave the tube open i.e. no sutures applied.
    • Reperitonization occurs
    • Best surgical procedure
  • Linear Salpingotomy
    • Incision is given & take out ectopic
    • Sutures are applied to close tube
    • Outdated procedure
  • Resection Anastomosis
  • Milking of Tube [increases Risk of Ectopic Pregnancy - Outdated)

Option A : Salpingotomy is the procedure where the incision (similar to that made in salpingostomy) is sutured after the removal of the products.

Option C : Salpingectomy is removal of the tube affected with ectopic pregnancy, it is the usual surgery done for ruptured ectopic pregnancies as well as for unruptured ectopic pregnancies in multiparous women undergoing surgery.

Option D : Salpingorrhaphy basically means any suturing or repair of fallopian tubes.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman at 36 weeks gestation presents with difficulty in breathing. Ultrasound examination revealed an AFI of 28 centimetres. Fundal height is greater than expected according to gestational age. Which of the following is the next step for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D : For rapidly increasing hydramnios where the patient has acute respiratory distress and overall discomfort, management is done by decompressing the amniotic sac by amniocentesis, but this conservation is best done till 34 weeks. Beyond 34 weeks, when pulmonary maturity is achieved, then an induction of labour with a ‘controlled’ ARM would be a prudent step. It is done under controlled conditions as sudden decompression of the fetus leading to placental abruption.

Management of Polyhydramnios

  • Oral Indomethacin : It acts by decreasing fetal urine production and thereby reduces amniotic fluid volume. This is presumed due to an increase in vasopressin levels and vasopressin responsiveness.However, it may cause constriction of fetal ductus arteriosus, resulting in pulmonary hypertension. Hence, should not be used beyond 32 weeks
  • Therapeutic Amniocentesis : This is done for polyhydramnios presenting before 34 weeks with respiratory distress : in a single setting, 1500 ml of Amniotic Fluid can be aspirated over 30 mins.
  • Management of labour and delivery :
    • Polyhydramnios is Not an indication for LSCS
    • Controlled Artificial Rupture Of Membranes In Labor

Option A : Diuretics have no role in management of polyhydramnios.

Option B : Saline infusion has no role in management of polyhydramnios.

Option C : Therapeutic Amniocentesis may be done for polyhydramnios presenting before 34 weeks with respiratory distress, however in this case delivery should be done as a more definitive step in management, thus ARM is more appropriate.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the maternity emergency with active labor at the 38th week of gestation. The patient is shifted to the labor room and is being managed on escalating doses of oxytocin. The patient's pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 110/70, respiratory rate is 18/min, and temperature is 37.2 C. Pelvic examination shows a fully dilated cervix and vertex positioned above station 0 with caput. CTG shows persistent decelerations after each contraction. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Cesarean section

  • The patient is showing persistent late type of decelerations suggestive of non-reassuring fetal heart status. Therefore delivery must be expedited with either instrumental delivery or caesarean section.
  • Since an important prerequisite for forceps or ventouse application is that the fetal skull should have reached the pelvic floor (+2 station or below), but in this patient, the head is above station 0, so ideal management is emergency LSCS  (lower segment cesarean section).

Indications of LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous cesarean  >2, previous classical cesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumours
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non-cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy or unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option A: Increase oxytocin drop rate

  • Increasing the oxytocin drop rate will increase uterine contractions, which may lead to quick progression towards delivery, but decelerations and non-assuring fetal heart status require immediate delivery.

Option B: Ventouse delivery

  • In ventouse delivery, the plastic or metallic cup is attached to the head of the baby with suction. However, it requires a fetal station of +2 or below. Therefore it cannot be suggested in this case.

Option C: Outlet forceps delivery

  • Forceps delivery is indicated when delivery is arrested while the skull has reached the pelvic floor and is visible without separating the labia.
  • In this case, the fetal head is above station 0, so forceps delivery cannot be done.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to your clinic for evaluation of short stature as reported by her parents. The patient has not yet attained menarche, and her mother reports no breast development. The physician makes a diagnosis of growth hormone deficiency. It is associated with all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A: Early closure of growth plates: This is NOT associated with growth hormone deficiency. Growth hormone deficiency can lead to delayed closure of growth plates, resulting in shorter stature.


Other Options are Incorrect as all the statements are true about growth hormone deficiency

questions.text: A 1-week-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, complaining of seizures, spasms, and rigidity of arms and legs. The baby has had an enlarged head since birth. His vitals are stable. The physician orders an MRI of the baby's head, shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this baby?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hydranencephaly

  • The given image shows the enlarged head with the absence of cerebral hemispheres, which are replaced with fluid-filled sacs. This condition is known as hydranencephaly.

  • In hydranencephaly, cerebral hemispheres are absent or represented by membranous sacs with remnants of frontal, temporal, or occipital cortex dispersed over the membrane.

  • Infants in this condition usually have normal or enlarged head circumference at birth that grows at an excessive rate postnatally.

  • The child with hydranencephaly is irritable, feeds poorly, and develops seizures and spastic quadriparesis.

  • It is also associated with:

    • Visual impairment

    • Lack of growth

    • Blindness

    • Deafness

Option A: Anencephaly

  • Absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp.

  • It results from failure of closure of the rostral neuropore, the opening of the anterior neural tube.

  • It is not compatible with life. It may be caused by interaction among several genetic and environmental factors.

Option C:  Hydrocephalus

  • A condition in which an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) occurs within the brain.

  • It results due to an impairment in circulation or absorption of CSF or may be due to increased production of CSF by choroid plexus papilloma.

Option D: Hydrops fetalis

  • The condition is characterised by the accumulation of large amounts of fluid in tissues and organs of the body, causing extensive swelling (oedema).

  • The main causes of hydrops fetalis include:

    • Heart or lung diseases

    • Severe anaemia

    • Genetic or developmental problems

questions.text: At what age will  a child achieve the milestone shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option C: 15 months

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which a 12-month-old child is brought to the physician by his mother for examination.

  • The child is able to crawl easily and is also able to walk with support.

  • He is also able to copy horizontal and vertical lines. The child doesn’t have any abnormalities.

  • He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.

  • The given picture shows a child creeping upstairs, that comes at around 15 months of age.

  • So, the child, in this case, still has 3 more months to achieve the milestone shown in the image.

  • Another important milestone that appears at around 15 months of age is Jargon speech.

Option A: 6 months

  • At the age of 6 months, the baby starts to roll from tummy to back.

  • Also, pushes up with straight arms when on the tummy

  • Leans on their hands to support him while sitting.

Option B:  12 months

  • At the age of 12 months, the baby can walk, holding onto objects.

  • Walks like a bear.

  • Picks up a pellet with finger and thumb

Option D: 24 months

  • At the age of 24 months, the child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes, turn the doorknob, and use pronouns like I, me, and you.

  • A child can make a tower of 6 cubes in 2 years.

  • Baby can hold a pencil in mid-shaft with a tripod grasp.

  •  Can sit on a small chair.

questions.text: What should be used for the treatment of this child with intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thyroxine

  • The given picture of the child with puffy (myxedematous) facies, protruding tongue, abdominal distension, umbilical hernia and intellectual disability suggest - ‘congenital hypothyroidism’.

C/F of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Birth weight & length- usually normal
  • Wide open anterior & posterior fontanelle
  • Prolonged physiological jaundice
  • Myxedematous facies
  • Large, protruded tongue
  • Skin- dry & scaly
  • Hypotonia, hypothermia, hoarse cry
  • Abdominal distension, umbilical hernia
  • Constipation

Thyroxine is used in the treatment of this disorder.

Option A: Biotin

  • Deficiency is seen in people who have Raw egg consumption.
  • Raw egg contains glycoprotein AVIDIN which forms complex with biotin and decreases its absorption
  • Prolonged TPN
  • High dose valproate use Features of Biotin deficiency
  • Scaly peri-orofacial dermatitis
  • Alopecia and thinning of hair
  • Anorexia and vomiting
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Conjunctivitis
  • CNS: Lethargy, Irritability, Apathy and Hypotonia

Features of Biotin deficiency

  • Scaly peri-orofacial dermatitis
  • Alopecia and thinning of hair
  • Anorexia and vomiting
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Conjunctivitis
  • CNS: Lethargy, Irritability, Apathy and Hypotonia

Option B: Hydroxocobalamin

  • Deficiency is seen in people who have Strict vegetarians or Vegan diets
  • Malabsorption
  • IEMs associated with Vitamin B12 Malabsorption
  • Hereditary IF deficiency
  • Imerslund–Grasbeck disease (Absence of IF receptor)
  • Drugs: Metformin, PPIs, H2 blockers

Features of Vitamin B12 deficiency

Infants:

  • Irritability, Hypotonia, Developmental delay and coarse tumors

Older children:

  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Hyperpigmentation of knuckles and palms
  • Poor growth and poor scholastic performance
  • Oral cavity involvement is rare

Adolescents and Adults :

  • Peripheral Neuropathy (paresthesias, absence of DTRs)
  • Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord affecting posterior lateral columns
  • Psychosis

Option C: Pyridoxine

Pyridoxine deficiency seen commonly in adults but rare in children

  • Malabsorption
  • Prematurity: Conversion of B6 into pyridoxal 5-Phosphate is hampered (CDT 2020)
  • Dialysis patient
  • Drugs: INH, Penicillamine, Corticosteroids, carbamazepine, Phenytoin
  • Females taking OCP’s

Features of Pyridoxine deficiency

  • Neonatal seizures: Refractory to therapy
  • Irritability and FTT in infants and children
  • Microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • Seborrheic dermatitis: Around the eyes, nose and mouth
  • Cheilosis and glossitis
  • Peripheral Neuropathy
  • Immune abnormalities: Leukopenia, Reduced Antibody formation leading to increased risk of infections
  • Oxaluria and Oxalate bladder stones
  • Hyperglycinemia

Learning objective

  • MC preventable and treatable cause of MR is congenital hypothyroidism
  • Most common cause is Thyroid Dysgenesis
  • Secondary / Congenital Hypothyroidism is Usually a rare cause of congenital hypothyroidism it can be due to TSH deficiency a part of generalized pituitary dysfunction and Isolated TSH deficiency IGSF-1 gene mutation

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is curious about the beard of his father and asks how long it will take him to grow a beard like him. The father tries to explain to him that he'll be able to grow a beard like this in a few years, but the child seems unsatisfied and anxious. He takes his son to a paediatrician for a routine check-up and asks him to answer his query. The doctor tells him about the sequence of secondary sexual characters a boy has to go through. What is the proper sequence in the given options?

choices.text: Testicular development- pubic hair- axillary hair-beard
Pubic hair- testicular development- axillary hair—beard
Testicular development- beard- pubic hair- axillary hair
Axillary hair-beard- pubic hair- testicular development

questions.solution:
Option A: Testicular development- pubic hair- axillary hair-beard

  • The sequence of development of secondary sexual characteristics in boys is as follows:
  • Testicular enlargement → Penis enlargement → Pubic hair growth→ Peak growth velocity →Axillary hair →Facial hair
  • The earliest stage of male maturation, seen on physical examination, is increased testicular volume. Boys have an increase in testicular size (volume ≥4 mL and length ≥2.5 cm) approximately six months before penile growth and pubic hair appear. 
  • The appearance of sperm in the urine and the onset of nocturnal sperm emissions occur after the boys reach peak height velocity. 
  • Then there is an increase in testicular volume across pubertal stages.

Option B: Pubic hair- testicular development- axillary hair—beard

  • Pubic hair growth is not the primary event of male puberty.
  • It follows the stage of testicular enlargement. 

Option C: Testicular development- beard- pubic hair- axillary hair

  • The appearance of facial hair is the last step in boys.
  • Pubic and axillary hair appears before it.

Option D: Axillary hair-beard- pubic hair- testicular development

  • The first step in male development is always an increase in the testicular size.
  • Pubic and axillary then appear, followed by facial hair.

questions.text: A premature baby is born to a mother with gestational diabetes. There is prolonged and obstructed labour. In intra-operative findings, there is a double loop of the umbilical cord around the neck. The newborn needed immediate resuscitation. A bag and a mask are used for this purpose. What is the function of the part pointed with the black arrow in the picture shown below?

choices.text: Increase pressure delivered to the baby
Increase O2 delivered to the baby

questions.solution:
Option C: Increase O2 delivered to the baby

  • In this scenario, the mother has gestational diabetes, which is a risk factor for premature birth.
  • Prolonged and obstructed labour leads to fetal distress.
  • Intraoperatively there is a double loop of cord around the neck.
  • Immediate resuscitation is required as the baby is premature.
  • The non-rebreather masks are used for flushing oxygen in emergencies.
  • A black arrow is pointed at the reservoir bag.
  • Reservoir increases the FiO2 delivered to the baby..
  • This reservoir bag is attached to the oxygen tank.
  • One-way valves don’t let the exhaled air re-enter the oxygen reservoir.
  • These non-rebreather masks provide 60-80% of oxygen at a flow rate of 10-15 litres/minute.

Option A: Increase pressure delivered to the baby

  • Increased pressure is delivered to the baby by positive pressure ventilation.
  • Positive pressure ventilation is provided by the umbo-bag.
  • Positive pressure ventilation requires continuous positive pressure manually.   

Option B: Maintain PEEP

  • PEEP positive end-expiratory pressure exists at the end of expiration.
  • It is provided by a mechanical ventilator.

Option D: Coordinate ventilation with chest compressions

  • The oxygen reservoir is not used to coordinate ventilation with chest compressions.
  • It has nothing to do with chest compressions.
  • It is only reserved oxygen in the form of a reservoir.

questions.text: Which of the following fatty acids is considered important for growth and CNS development?
questions.solution:
Option A: Docosahexaenoic acid DHA

  • DHA is an omega-3 fatty acid found in breast milk. It has many health benefits for both mother and baby.
  • DHA plays a central role in the brain's growth, structure and development.
  • The brain and the retina both require DHA in order to properly form and function.
  • Naturally, cow's milk does not have a rich source of DHA.
  • Rumen biohydrogenation (influenced by rumen microbes) reduces DHA in the ruminal environment and reduces DHA incorporation into milk. 
  • The following are some benefits of DHA:
    • Boosts intelligence.
    • Boosts hand-eye coordination.
    • Improves vision and eye health.
    • Increases memory development.
    • Improves attention span.
  • A pregnant and breastfeeding mother should take dietary supplementation of DHA, which results in increasing the DHA level in breast milk; as a result, the mental health performance of breastfed infants will be improved

 

Option B: Palmitic acid

 

  • Palmitic acid is the major saturated fatty acid in human milk and constitutes 20–25 % of human milk fatty acids.
  • The functions of palmitic acid present in breast milk are: 
    • Increase calcium absorption
    • Improves quality of bone matrix 
    • Stool consistency
    • Development of the intestinal microbiome

 

Option C: Vitamin E

  • Vitamin E in breast milk protects the cell membrane in the eyes and lungs.
  • Vitamin E is present in breast milk more than is a requirement for the infant.

 

Option D: Linolenic acid

  • Linoleic acid and α-linolenic acid are present in breast milk.
  • A balanced amount of these fatty acids is required for normal maturation and functioning of the nervous system.
  • DHA in milk is also derived from α-linolenic acid (ALA) in the liver

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and hepatosplenomegaly. His complete blood count showed pancytopenia. The consultant attending ordered a bone biopsy, which revealed histiocytes with a wrinkled paper appearance. What could be the most likely diagnosis of the case mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gaucher disease

  • The given scenario implies Gaucher disease, which is characterised by glucocerebroside buildup in lysosomes.
  • Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder (LSD).
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • It occurs due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency, which causes glucocerebroside to build up inside the lysosomes of cells.
  • The patient usually presents hepatosplenomegaly, bone aches, pathologic fractures, bruising (thrombocytopenia), and anaemia.
  • Neurological characteristics may or may not exist.
  • On an X-ray of the long bone, Erlenmeyer flask deformity may be visible.
  • Bone marrow contains Gaucher cells, lipid-laden macrophages that have cytoplasm with a typical histologic appearance of "wrinkled tissue paper" when stained with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain.

Option A: Niemann Pick disease

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a deficiency of Sphingomyelinase, resulting in progressive neurodegeneration and foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages).
  • Distinguishing features include hepatosplenomegaly and a "cherry-red" spot on the macula.

Option C: Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterised by the monoclonal proliferation of antigen-presenting cells (APC).
  • A Birbeck granule component called langerin (CD207) is expressed in almost all LCH patients. It is believed that Birbeck granules, a hallmark of LCH, are elements of the endocytic recycling process.

Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a defect in proteins that interact with the RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane.
  • Small, round RBCs characterise it with no central pallor, elevated MCHC and increased osmotic fragility.
  • Splenomegaly and gallstones are common presentations.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with a complaint of ear pain (otalgia) and greenish-black discharge. On otoscopic examination, the patient has marked tenderness with multiple granulations in the external auditory canal. The culture of the discharge turns out to be Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following is the best prognostic test for the follow-up of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gallium (Ga-67) Scan is correct

  • This patient is presented with necrotising otitis externa, an inflammatory condition most commonly caused by Pseudomonas infection.

  • It is found in elderly diabetics or immunocompromised patients (immunosuppressive therapy patients with cancer, AIDs, etc.)
  • The main symptoms, as described in the above scenario, are excruciating pain and granulations in the external ear.
  • Diagnosis is made by history and examination, and culture is done to confirm the presence of Pseudomonas.
  • CT scan can be done to check for any necrosis of bones, but Gallium-67 is more useful in the patient's follow-up; it is repeated every three weeks to check the response of the treatment. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells and indicates soft tissue infection.
  • If untreated, malignant otitis externa can cause facial palsy, and infection may spread to the skull base causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • The mainstay of the treatment is controlling blood sugar levels, toileting the ear canal, and removing all granulations, dead tissue debris, or bone, along with antibiotics.
  • Antibiotics found effective are:
    • Gentamicin combined with Ticarcillin.
    • Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime.
    • Ciprofloxacin, Ofloxacin, and Levofloxacin.

Option A: Technetium 99m Scan

  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or more and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Option C:  MRI temporal bone

  • The role of MRI remains unclear in the follow-up of malignant otitis externa.

Option D: CECT Temporal bone

  • CT scan may show bony destruction but is often not helpful.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came to the ENT outpatient department with a complaint of dizziness while waking up from the bed. The patient has no hearing loss and ringing ears. The patient has no family history of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, or others. He had an appendectomy operation at the age of 35. The patient is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the patient developed nystagmus in the below-depicted maneuver. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vestibular exercises

  • 80 % of BPPV (Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) cases can be treated with Epley's maneuver, which is a vestibular exercise.

Epley’s maneuver:

  • The principle of this maneuver is to reposition the otoconial debris from the posterior semi-circular canal back into the utricle. The doctor stands behind the patient and the assistant on the side. The patient is made to sit on the table so that when he is made to lie down, his head is beyond the edge of the table, as is done in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. His face is turned 45° to the affected side.
    • The image depicted here is the Dix-hall pike maneuver.
    • The most common cause of peripheral vertigo.
    • It occurs during sudden head movements - lasts for a sec to a few minutes.
    • Due to faulty otoconia in the semi-circular ampulla.
    • Treatment: Vestibular exercises, Epley's maneuver
  • The maneuver consists of five positions:
    • Position 1: With the head turned 45°, the patient is made to lie down in a head-hanging position (Dix-Hallpike). It will cause vertigo and nystagmus. Wait till vertigo and nystagmus subside.
    • Position 2: The Head is now turned so that the affected ear is facing up at a 90° rotation.
    • Position 3: The whole body and head are now rotated away from the affected ear to a lateral recumbent position in a 90° -rotation face-down position.
    • Position 4: The patient is now brought to a sitting position with the head still turned to the unaffected side by 45°.
    • Position 5: The head is now turned forward, and the chin is brought down.

Option B: Vestibular sedatives

  • The drugs used to sedate the vestibular labyrinth are called vestibular sedatives or anti-vertigo drugs. These drugs do much more harm than benefit and can only provide temporary relief from the symptom of acute vertigo or head spinning.

Option C: Antihistamine

  • Antihistamines are medicines that work against or block histamine. Antihistamines suppress the histamine-induced wheal response (swelling) and flare response (vasodilation) by blocking the binding of histamine to its receptors or reducing histamine receptor activity on nerves, vascular smooth muscle, glandular cells, endothelium, and mast cells.

Option D: Diuretics

  • Diuretics (also called water pills or fluid pills) increase the amount of urine you produce. It relieves symptoms such as ankle swelling and helps to lower blood pressure. The three main types of diuretics are thiazides, loop diuretics, and potassium-sparing diuretics.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the ENT outpatient department complaining of headache, hearing loss, and tinnitus. There is no history of fever or any discharge from both ears. Weber's test is performed on examination to check his type of deafness. In the defective right middle ear, weber's test would lateralize to?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lateralized to the right side

In the case of a defective right middle ear, Weber's test would lateralize to the Lateralized to right ear.

Weber's test is a simple and quick tuning fork test used to help differentiate between conductive hearing loss and sensorineural hearing loss. During the test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient's forehead or midline of the skull. The patient is asked to report in which ear the sound appears louder or where they perceive the sound to be located.

In conductive hearing loss, there is a problem with sound transmission through the outer or middle ear, which can be caused by conditions such as middle ear infections, otosclerosis, or perforated eardrum. When the affected ear has conductive hearing loss, the sound from the tuning fork will be heard better in that ear, and the sound will lateralize or shift towards the defective ear.

In the case mentioned, the patient has defective right middle ear, and the Weber's test would lateralize to the right ear, indicating that the sound is heard better in the right ear, consistent with conductive hearing loss on the right side. The reported symptoms of headache, hearing loss, and tinnitus are suggestive of a middle ear issue that may be contributing to the conductive hearing loss in the right ear.

No lateralization → normal hearing or bilateral hearing loss.

  • In normal Individuals: No sound lateralization occurs as both ear's bone conduction is normal and equal.
  • In conductive deafness (seen in the external ear and middle ear disorders): Lateralization of sound occurs in the diseased ear.
  • In SNHL (seen in the inner ear and neural pathway disorders): Lateralization of sound occurs in the better ear.

Option A: Normal

  • If the weber test is normal, there is normal hearing or bilateral sensorineural hearing loss or bilateral symmetrical conductive hearing loss.
  • So, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Centralized

  • In the weber test, it is centralized in normal persons with normal hearing.
  • So, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Lateralization to the left side

  • It occurs due to sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear, or it is due to conductive hearing loss in the left ear.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a previous history of myocardial infarction presented with nasal discharge. The patient is currently on maintenance therapy for his myocardial infarction. The patient also has a history of intense itching and sneezing when gardening on his lawn. On examination, the nasal cavity has numerous polyps. Which of the following triad is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Samter's triad

  • This patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction is likely taking aspirin as a maintenance medication. His aspirin usage, allergic history, and the presence of nasal polyps on examination give a clue to Samter's triad.
  • Thirty-six percent of the patients with aspirin intolerance may show polyps.
  • Samter’s triad or aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) consists of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin intolerance.
    • It is due to the shunting of arachidonic acid metabolites towards the leukotriene pathway.
    • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits the cyclooxygenase pathway of prostaglandin synthesis. This blockage leads to a backup of arachidonic acid metabolites. These metabolites are then shunted towards the leukotriene synthesis pathway.
    • Increased leukotriene production causes an allergic reaction characterised by nasal congestion, sneezing, and cough after using aspirin.
    • They are difficult to treat.

Option B: Trotter's triad.

  • Trotter’s triad consists of ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia involving the mandibular division of the 5th cranial nerve.
  • Ipsilateral palatal palsy leads to palatal asymmetry due to 10th cranial nerve involvement.
  • Unilateral serous otitis media can lead to ipsilateral conductive hearing loss.

Option C: Sinus of Morgagni syndrome

  • Trotter's triad is present in the sinus of Morgagni syndrome.
  • It is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option D: Melkersson Rosenthal syndrome

  • This syndrome consists of swollen lips, fissured tongue, and recurrent facial palsy.
  • This syndrome is not related to asthma and aspirin use.

questions.text: A 15 years old boy presented with complaints of downward displacement of the eyeball, diplopia, and enophthalmos after trauma to the face by a cricket ball. He has been diagnosed with a blow-out fracture of the orbit. CT Scan of the face shows the following finding. What would be the most common orbital wall involved?
questions.solution:
Option A: Floor

  • The picture shows a " blow out fracture of the orbit (also called  orbital floor fracture)".
  • The adult orbital floor is composed of the maxillary, zygomatic, and palatine bones.
  • The orbital floor is the shortest of all the walls; it does not reach the orbital apex, measures 35-40 mm, and terminates at the posterior edge of the maxillary sinus.

Option B: Medial Wall

  • Patients may be asymptomatic with an isolated medial orbital fracture.
  • Epistaxis, soft tissue signs, and subcutaneous emphysema may be present.
  • In cases with medial rectus muscle or associated soft tissue entrapment, patients may complain of diplopia in horizontal gaze or pain on eye movement.

Option C: Lateral Wall

  • Patients with lateral orbital wall fractures usually present with periorbital swelling and ecchymosis along with variable degrees of mid facial deformity.
  • A displaced lateral orbital wall has a dramatic effect on the globe position and facial asymmetry.
  • Above image is consistent with orbital floor fracture.

Option D: Roof

  • Fractures of the roof of the orbit are typically associated with trauma to the forehead/frontal bone are often extensions of superior orbital rim fractures. Isolated non-displaced orbital roof fractures most commonly seen in children and rarely require surgical intervention.
  • Other symptoms are similar to those seen with other orbital fractures including poor vision, double vision, pain with eye movement and pain with nose blowing.
  • The image showed above is most likely of fracture of orbital floor.

questions.text: Juvenile angiofibroma is a rare benign tumour of the nasopharynx. It commonly presents with profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis. It is locally invasive and destroys adjoining structures. On physical examination, it appears as a pink or purple smooth mass obstructing choanae. Whom of the following is most likely to develop a juvenile angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Option D: A 14-year-old boy

  • Juvenile angiofibroma (JA) is a unique tumour presenting almost exclusively in adolescent males.
  • It is a vascular tumour most commonly supplied by the sphenopalatine artery.
  • It is an androgen-dependent tumour.
  • Clinical features include profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis, progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion, and pink to purple mass in the nasopharynx.
  • Spread to nearby structures causes broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis (frog-face deformity), swelling of the cheek or infratemporal fossa, and involvement of CN II, III, IV, and VI.
  • A biopsy is contraindicated since it might precipitate bleeding.
  • Holman-miller sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary antrum on the CT scan.
  • It is locally invasive, invading the cheek, orbit, brain, and nose.
  • Juvenile angiofibroma is best treated by surgical excision.
  • Patients with advanced and recurrent Juvenile angiofibroma thought not to be amenable to complete resection with acceptable morbidity are ones treated with radiotherapy.

Option A: A 6-year-old boy

  • Juvenile angiofibroma presents in adolescents.
  • It does not present in the first decade of life.

Option B: A newborn girl

  • Juvenile angiofibroma occurs exclusively in males.
  • It presents in the second decade of life.
  • It is not seen in females.

Option C: A 12-year-old girl

  • Juvenile angiofibroma presents in males in the second decade of life
  • Females rarely present with Juvenile angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with complaints of hoarseness of voice for the past month. She is a biology teacher and says that due to workload, she used to take extra classes to complete the syllabus on time. On laryngoscopic examination, the findings seen are as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vocal nodule

The patient presents with hoarseness of voice and a history of occupational voice abuse (biology teacher); based on this and the laryngeal examination, she likely has vocal nodules, i.e., singer's/screamer's nodule.

  • They appear symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords, most commonly at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and the posterior 2/3rd.
  • They are caused by trauma to the vocal cords due to chronic vocal abuse, which results in edema and hemorrhage in the submucosal space, which undergoes hyalinization and fibrosis.
  • The patient presents with hoarseness of voice and voice fatigue.
  • The early vocal nodule is managed conservatively by patient education against voice abuse and using the voice properly. This treatment can completely disappear many nodules.
  • For large nodules or those of persistent standing, microlaryngoscopic surgery is done.

Option B: Vocal polyp

  • Appear as unilateral and localized swelling of the membranous part of the vocal cords.
  • Appear as soft, pedunculated mass

Option C: Reinke's edema

  • Also called smoker's larynx
  • Describes the vocal cords when they become chronically and irreversibly swollen
  • Bilateral and diffuse symmetrical swelling of the whole membranous part of the vocal cords
  • Occurs due to edematous epithelial hypertrophy and polypoidal degeneration
  • Vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent appearance and prominent superficial vessels showing hyperemic and hypertrophic ventricular bands.

Option D: Vocal papilloma

  • Adult-onset papilloma usually occurs as a single, small mass that does not recur after surgical removal.
  • More common in males than females and arises at age 30-50.
  • It arises from half of the vocal cord or the anterior commissure.

questions.text: A 3-year-old, well-immunized boy was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of sore throat, high-grade fever, and noisy breathing with an inability to swallow for the past four hours. The physical examination showed a toxic, tachypnoeic child with inspiratory stridor. There is suprasternal, supraclavicular, and intercostal recession during inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute Epiglottitis

  • It is a case of Acute epiglottitis. The child is well immunized; however, he presents with a high-grade fever, sore throat, and inability to swallow (dysphagia). The examination findings, such as inspiratory stridor and toxic look with respiratory difficulties, support the diagnosis of acute epiglottitis.
  • Epiglottitis is an acute infection of the supraglottis characterized by inflammation of the supraglottic structures.
  • Historically the most common causative organism was Haemophilus influenza type b.
  • TREATMENT:

 

  1. Systemic Antibiotics
  2. Systemic corticosteroids
  3. Nebulization with Adrenaline

Option A: Acute Laryngo-tracheobronchitis

  • It has a similar presentation, but odynophagia and dysphagia are usually absent.
  • The patient presents a croupy cough (barking seal-like cough) and hoarseness.
  • The fever is usually low-grade or absent.

Option C: Diphtheria

  • Diphtheria is ruled out as the child is well immunized, even though he has the symptoms.
  • The presence of a tough pseudomembrane over the larynx and trachea is a differentiating factor not seen in this patient.

Option D: Bronchopneumonia

  • Bronchopneumonia will not have inspiratory stridor. In addition, the patient will not show an inability to swallow and stridor due to involvement of the lower respiratory tract only.

questions.text: A mother presented with her baby with the complaint of drooping of the upper eyelid to the lower eyelid with the blurring of vision. During clinical examination, a resident noticed that amount of drooping of the upper eyelid decreases when the patient opens the mouth. In which type of ptosis the amount of ptosis decreases with mouth opening?
questions.solution:
Option B: Marcus Gunn's ptosis

  • In the above-give case, the drooping of the eyelid, which decreases with mouth opening, indicates Marcus Gunn's ptosis.
  • In this condition, lid drooping decreases when the jaw opens; it is typically Marcus jaw winking phenomenon.
  • It is usually a congenital condition.
  • The child may have other congenital anomalies, too, like cleft lip/cleft palate and renal calculi.
  • It can be managed conservatively or surgically.

Option A: Blepharophimosis syndrome

  • It is a rare congenital anomaly affecting eyelids and ovaries.
  • It has no association with the jaw moments.
  • It is associated with epicanthus inversus and telecanthus.

Option C: Myogenic ptosis

  • In this condition, there is a weakening of the levator muscle due to systemic disorder.
  • It is due to muscular dystrophy.

Option D: Neurogenic ptosis

  • It is a neurological disorder
  • This occurs when there is a problem in the nerve pathway, which controls the movement of eyelids.

questions.text: Congenital cataracts are associated with certain genetic and metabolic disorders. Congenital rubella infection can also lead to congenital cataracts in the baby. Which of the following is true regarding cataracts in congenital rubella syndrome?

choices.text: Can be associated with neurovascular anomalies

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Congenital cataract: Congenital cataracts are indeed associated with congenital rubella syndrome. Rubella infection during pregnancy can lead to various congenital abnormalities, including cataracts in the newborn.

Incorrect Options:

Options B. Associated with macrophthalmos: This statement is incorrect. Congenital rubella syndrome is not typically associated with macrophthalmos (abnormally large eyes).

Option C. Can be associated with neurovascular anomalies: While congenital rubella syndrome primarily affects the eyes, ears, and heart, it is not typically associated with specific neurovascular anomalies.

Options D. Reversible: This statement is incorrect. Congenital cataracts associated with congenital rubella syndrome are not typically reversible without surgical intervention. Cataract surgery may be performed to remove the opacities and restore vision, but it's not a spontaneous reversal.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below :
questions.solution:
Presentation of anterior uveitis :

- Iris nodules :

a) Koeppe's nodules → present on pupillary margin

b) Busacca's nodules → present on surface of iris

Both are seen in granulomatous uveitis

questions.text: The human eye is a specialized sense organ capable of receiving visual images, which are then carried to the brain. Intraocular pressure (IOP) is the pressure in your eyes. When that pressure is higher than normal, it causes ocular hypertension. While ocular hypertension isn't an eye disease in itself, it is an indication that you could develop glaucoma. Your eye pressure is measured in millimetres of mercury, expressed as mm Hg. The Ophthalmic investigation shown in the image below is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tonometry

  • The image given in the question of applanation tonometry. In applanation tonometry, the cornea is flattened, and the IOP is determined by varying the applanating force or the area flattened.

  • The intraocular pressure (IOP) of the eye is determined by the balance between the amount of aqueous humor that the eye makes and the ease with which it leaves the eye.

Option A: Pachymetry

  • Pachymetry is a simple, painless test that quickly measures the thickness of the cornea.

Option C: Biometry

  • Biometry is used to calculate the refractive power of the cornea and the intraocular lens. It also measures the axial length of the eye.

Option D: LASER interferometry

  • Laser interferometry can be used to determine the diameter of fibres with a circular cross-section. The fibre is placed in the beam and the interference fringes projected onto a screen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with severe pain in the left eye after watching a movie. The pain is severe, and there is a progressive loss of vision. The ophthalmic surgeon notices ciliary congestion and a shallow anterior chamber. The pupil is mid-dilated, and the cornea is edematous. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Angle-closure glaucoma

  • Angle-closure glaucoma is caused by a sudden occlusion of the entire angle, resulting in the acute rise of IOP to extremely high levels.
  • Signs of Angle-closure glaucoma: Stony hard eye, corneal edema, Vertically oval mid-dilated non-reacting pupil and shallow anterior chamber.
  • Symptoms: Severe pain, coloured halos, sudden drop in vision and unilateral headache. Symptoms occur late at night.
  • Nd-Yag Laser iridotomy is done for the management of Angle-closure glaucoma.

Option A: CRVO

  • Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) affects the retina. It happens when a blood clot blocks the main vein where blood flows out of the retina. It usually only affects one eye.
  • Based on powerful randomized clinical trials, the most common treatment involves periodic injections into the eye of an anti-VEGF drug to reduce new blood vessel growth and swelling. Anti-VEGF drugs include bevacizumab (Avastin), ranibizumab (Lucentis), and aflibercept (Eylea).
  • CRVO is an ocular emergency, and primary care clinicians should make a consult with the ophthalmologist immediately.
  • Both eyes' visual acuity, pupil constriction, and intraocular pressure should be checked.
  • This patient presents with characteristic features of angle closure glaucoma.

Option C: CRAO

  • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a form of acute ischemic stroke that causes severe visual loss and is a harbinger of further cerebrovascular and cardiovascular events.
  • Emboli dislodged from the carotid artery are the most common cause of CRAO, from either an unstable atherosclerotic plaque or a cardiac source. Embolism, as follows: Cholesterol is the most common type, but it can also be from calcium, bacteria, or talc from intravenous drug use.
  • Ischemic retinal damage can be reversed by hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) if irreversible infarction damage has not developed.
  • This patient presents with characteristic features of angle closure glaucoma.

Option D: Open-angle glaucoma

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a subset of glaucomas defined by an open, normal-appearing anterior chamber angle and raised intraocular pressure (IOP) with no other underlying disease. This is called secondary glaucoma if there is an identifiable underlying cause for raised IOP.
  • A recent, randomized clinical trial demonstrated that laser therapy (the LiGHT trial), specifically selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT), is an appropriate and effective first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma.
  • Common Symptoms & Early Warning Signs
    • Loss of peripheral vision.
    • Sudden blurry vision.
    • Severe eye pain.
    • Headache.
  • This patient presents with characteristic features of angle closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology department for a routine eye check-up. However, she reports frequent headaches and eye strain. Her evaluation for eyesight is done. On Snellen's chart, she reads 6/6 in both her eyes. Suppose a person has visual acuity of 6/6. At what distance will he be able to read the 6/24 line?
questions.solution:
Option A: 24 m

  • A normal person would read the 6/24 line at 24 m, and since the patient has normal visual acuity, he will also read it at 24m.
    • Importance of >6m distance -the light rays are parallel beyond 6m, and the patient exerts minimal accommodation.
    • The chart should be properly illuminated.
    • When the patient can read up a 6 m line, the visual acuity is recorded as 6/6, which is normal.
  • Thus 6/24 line would be read by a normal person at 24 m, and since the patient has normal visual acuity, he will also read it at 24m.

Option B: 36 m

  • A patient without glasses can see the letter at a distance of 6 m which is normal.
  • 6/36 means that a patient should see at 30 meters, but this patient has to be much closer, which means 36 meters.

Option C: 48 m

  • A patient without glasses can see the letter at a distance of 6 m which is normal.
  • 6/48 means that a patient should see at 48 meters, but this patient has to be much closer, which means 48 meters.

Option D: 60 m

  • A patient without glasses can see the letter at a distance of 6 m which is normal.
  • 6/60 means that a patient should be seen at 60 meters, but this patient has to be much closer, which means 60 meters.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient comes to an ophthalmologist with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision. All her vitals are within normal limits. She has no history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The only medication she has been taking is oral contraceptive pills. The fundus image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Central retinal vein occlusion

  • The given image shows mild venous congestion, tortuosity, and multiple dot-blot, superficial flame-shaped hemorrhage suggestive of the non-ischemic type of CRVO.
  • Oral contraceptive pills are known to be a risk factor for cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.

Central retinal vein occlusion:

  • In this condition, the main vein drains the blood into the retina blocks completely or partially. It results in blurred vision and several other eye problems.
  • Many patients have CRVO, mostly in one eye.
  • The following are the predisposing factors of CRVO :
    • Diabetes mellitus 
    • Hypertension
    • Arteriosclerosis
    • Hypercoagulability
    • Oral contraceptives pills users
    • Hyperviscosity of blood

Option B: Diabetic retinopathy

  • It is a complication in diabetes mellitus in which a high sugar level damages the back of the eye.
  • As the patient does not have diabetes, it is not the case.

Option C: Cystoid macular edema

  • It is a condition in which disruption of the blood and retinal barrier causes the thickening of the macula.
  • The images are seen as wavy, and the colors are seen as faded. These are not the conditions in this case.

Option D: Central retinal artery occlusion

  • It is a condition where there is blood blockage in the retinal artery.
  • Embolism is the most common cause of central artery occlusion.

questions.text: A 24-year-old young male who sustained blunt trauma to the face on eye examination had D shaped pupil. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Iridodialysis, in which the iris is torn away from its ciliary attachment for a variable distance, occurs more frequently. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery, and the pupillary edge bulges slightly inwards forming a ‘D’-shaped pupil.

  • In blunt trauma, the substance of the iris is often torn. The most common lesions are minute ruptures in the pupillary margin which are of little significance, while radiating lacerations of the iris, sometimes extending to the ciliary margin, are rare.
  • Iridoschisis - This rare condition occurs most commonly as a degenerative ageing senile phenomenon, though it may follow as a late result of severe trauma. Large dehiscences appear on the anterior mesodermal layer of the iris and strands of this tissue may float into the anterior chamber.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male visits the clinic with a complaint of recurrent episodes of oral ulcers, large areas of denuded skin, and flaccid vesiculobullous eruptions. Which of the following bedside studies is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Gram staining of the blister fluid
Tzanck smear from the floor of bulla

questions.solution:
Option D: Tzanck smear from the floor of bulla

  • This patient with recurrent oral ulcers, flaccid vesiculobullous eruptions, and large areas of denuded skin most likely has Pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • Tzanck smear of the lesions involves opening of the intact roof of a blister along one side
  • Folded back- Floor gently scraped -Material obtained is smeared onto a microscopic slide
  • Stained with Giemsa stain.
  • It is a simple test that can be done at the bedside in a patient with pemphigus.
  • Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells) would be found.

Option A: Gram stain of blister

  • Done in cases of Impetigo and folliculitis (Gram-positive and Gram-negative).

Option B: Culture Sensitivity

  • The culture of pus or discharge or tissue in case of infective etiology.

Option C: Skin biopsy and immunofluorescence

  • It is more conclusive but is laboratory tests. Need a separate setting and instruments and cannot be performed at the bedside.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male presents in the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 3 days. Examination reveals numerous hypopigmented, macular, scaly lesions over the trunk, as shown in the picture.



Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding this rash?

choices.text: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment
Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae
The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

questions.solution:
Option B: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment

  • Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment of pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis versicolor:

  • Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by the development of spreading, hypopigmented, scaly macular lesions most commonly involving the trunk region. Malassezia spp. is the causative organism, which is a yeast-like fungus. The infection remains confined to the stratum corneum.
  • Risk factors affect hot and humid weather.
  • Microscopic examination of the lesions’ scrapings reveals round yeasts with filaments, also referred to as ‘spaghetti and meat-ball’ appearance.
  • Treatment includes topical application of selenium sulfide and/or administration of systemic antifungal agents in resistant cases.

Option A: Trichophyton is the infecting organism

  • Trichophyton belongs to the class of dermatophyte fungi, which are commonly implicated in the development of tinea infections (tinea capitis, tinea corporis, tinea cruris, tinea pedis, etc.).

Option C: Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae

  • Branching septate hyphae are associated with dermatophyte infection.

Option D: The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

  • Vulvovaginitis is caused by Candida albicans which belong to the class of dimorphic fungi.
  • Candida albicans is also associated with the development of oral and esophageal thrush and candidemia in immunocompromised patients

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with a fever and headache. She also complains of vaginal itching and dysuria. When asked, she says that she recently became sexually active. Physical examination reveals tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and red, pustular, painful vesicles on her labia majora. Which of the following additional findings can be caused by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option C: Gingivostomatitis

  • Typical vesicles or pustules or a cluster of painful ulcers preceded by vesiculopustular lesions suggests genital herpes.
  • The pathognomonic findings for herpes infections are painful vesicles.
  • Both HSV-1 and HSV-2 can cause genital herpes, but more than 80% of genital lesions are due to HSV-2.
  • HSV-2 is transmitted by direct contact with the virus with mucosal surfaces or open skin surfaces.
  • Approximately 80% of infected patients are asymptomatic.

C/F:

  • The primary infection presents constitutional symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia.
  • Gingivostomatitis is an oral infection leading to mouth sores and ulcers.
  • Later, genital vesicles may appear that can rupture and leave behind painful ulcers.
  • Other genital symptoms include itching and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Option A: Granuloma inguinale

  • Klebsiella granulomatis also K/a Donovani granulomatis
  • Leads to granuloma inguinale
  • It is having a Beefy red ulcer
  • LF Colonies
    • On CLED: Yellow colonies
    • On MacConkey agar: Pinkish colonies
  • Very mucoid colonies
  • PCR for K. Species
  • NDM-1 (New Delhi Metallo -Lactamase): Resistance to all types of Antibiotics.

Option B: Neonatal pneumonia

  • It is caused by Chlamydia trachomitis
  • Serogroups A, B, Ba, C: Causes TRACHOMA
  • They are known as TRIC agents.
  • Mx Strategy
    • S: Surgery
    • A: Antibiotics
    • F: Face clean
    • E: Environmental Clean
  • Serogroups D-K: Causes
    • Inclusion Conjunctivitis
    • Infantile Pneumonia
    • Genital Chlamydiosis
  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1 -L3 Cause Lympho granuloma venereum

Option D: Gummas

  • It is caused by Treponema pallidum infection
  • Causes syphilis
  • Stages include
    • Primary: Hard, painless chancres, Painless Lymph adenopathy.
    • Secondary: Rashes over the palms & soles are present, and Condylomata lata lesions are seen (Most infectious lesion of syphilis).
    • Tertiary syphilis: Having Gummas (skin lesions), Cardiovascular complications, Neuro syphilis features.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of lesions on his elbow and shaft of the penis. On examination, pinhead-shaped (discrete but grouped papules) lesions over the right elbow are noted as shown below: 



Which of the following is the most likely disorder:
questions.solution:
Option A: Lichen nitidus

Lichen nitidus:

Grouped pinhead-sized papules on

  • Elbow
  • Forearm
  • Dorsum of hand
  • Shaft of penis

Histology shows:

  • Elongated rete ridges
  • Lymphocytic infiltrate
  • Together they give a "claw clutching appearance."

Option B: Lichen planus

  • Lichen planus presents with firm, shiny, polygonal, 1-3 mm diameter papules (isolated or grouped, in a linear or annular grouped, in a linear or annular distribution) with a red to violet color with a lattice of thin white lines - Wickham's striae.
  • Volar aspect of wrist, ankle, lumbar region.
  • Annular lesions- penis

Option C: Scabies

  • The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.
  • Inflammatory pruritic papules or nodules
  • Intense itching at night with a positive family history strongly suggests scabies.

Option D: Phrynoderma

  • Phrynoderma presents with keratotic follicular papules involving the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arm and can spread to the extensor extremities, shoulders, posterior neck, back, buttocks, and abdomen
